The council may appoint up to two (2) auxiliary members of the planning board to serve for three-year terms, said terms arranged to fit the staggered term system as provided herein. Said auxiliary member or members shall sit as active members when and if a temporary vacancy or vacancies so require, upon request of the chairman of the board. Persons appointed to the planning board shall hold no other office in the service of the town. 
(a)  The director of community development in his capacity as executive secretary to the board, shall be free to attend meetings, but he shall not have an official vote nor shall he be counted for purposes of a quorum. The board may adopt its own rules and order of business, but must have at least one regular monthly meeting. 
(b)  The board shall exercise those powers and perform those duties prescribed for such a board now or in the future by the Constitution and laws of the state not inconsistent with this Charter, and such additional powers and duties as may be assigned to it by this Charter or the town council. The board shall consult with the town administrator through the director of community development and the director shall also be responsible for coordinating the work of the board with the other functions carried on by the department of community development. 
Sec. 904. - Housing authority. 
    There shall be a housing authority, which shall function within the department of community development and shall perform the duties and exercise the powers of such authority under the laws of the United States, the laws of the state, and relevant ordinances of the town. The members of said authority shall be selected in accor dance with applicable provisions of state law. Persons appointed to the housing authority shall hold no other office in the service of the town. 
Sec. 905. - Redevelopment agency. 
    There shall be a redevelopment agency, which shall function within the department of community development and shall perform the duties and exercise the powers of such agency under the laws of the United States, the laws of the state, and relevant ordinances of the town. The members of said agency shall be selected in accordance with applicable provisions of state law. Persons appointed to the redevelopment agency shall hold no other office in the service of the town. 
Sec. 906. - Conservation commission. 
    There shall be a conservation commission, which shall function within the department of community development and shall perform the duties and exercise the powers of such commission under the laws of the state and relevant ordinances of the town. The Commission shall consist of the maximum number of members allowed by state law. Members shall be appointed by the Town Council to serve three-year staggered terms. As of December 31, 1998, the Council shall appoint one additional member to a two-year term and one to a three-year term. In the event the State amends the law to provide for any additional members, they shall be appointed by the Town Council after the next regular election to serve for three-year staggered terms by adding the members in a distributed manner to preserve the pattern already established. Duly incorporated and existing wildlife, conservation, sportsmen's, horticultural, or like organizations may present to the council a list of qualified citizens from which lists the council must select at least three (3) members of the commission and from which lists the council may select the remainder. Persons appointed to the conservation commission shall hold no other office in the service of the town. 
(Amend. of 11-3-98) 
Sec. 907. - Recreation board. 
    There shall be a recreation board, which shall function within the department of community development, and shall perform the duties and exercise the powers conferred upon it by the town council. The board shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the council to serve for three-year staggered terms. Of the first members appointed under this Charter, two (2) shall be designated to serve one-year terms, two (2) shall be designated to serve two-year terms, and the remaining one shall serve a three-year term. 
Sec. 908. - Harbor commission. 
    There shall be a harbor commission, which shall perform the duties and exercise the powers conferred upon it by state law or the ordinances of the town. The board shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the council to serve for three-year staggered terms. Of the first members appointed under this Charter, two (2) shall be designated to serve one-year terms, two (2) shall be designated to serve two-year terms, and the remaining one shall serve a three-year term. The council may appoint up to two (2) auxiliary members of the harbor commission to serve for three (3) year terms, said terms arranged to fit the staggered term system as provided herein. Said auxiliary member or members shall sit as active members when and if a temporary vacancy or vacancies so require, upon request of the chairman of the commission. 
(Amend. of 11-2-04; Amend. of 11-2-10) 
Sec. 909. - Zoning board of review. 
    There shall be a zoning board of review, which shall function within the department of community development, and shall perform the duties and exercise the powers of such board under the laws of the state and relevant ordinances of the town. The members of said board shall be selected in accordance with the applicable provisions of state law, provided, however, that the town council may provide, in accordance with laws now or hereafter in effect, for the appointment of auxiliary members. Persons appointed to the zoning board of review shall hold no other office in the service of the town. 
(a)  At least every five (5) years the director of community development shall review the Zoning Ordinance and map to determine whether any changes are necessary, and report his findings to the town administrator for transmission, with the recommendations of the town administrator, to the town council. 
Sec. 910. - Inspectorial functions. 
    There shall be inspectors appointed by the town administrator to perform the following functions: Building inspection, plumbing inspection, electrical inspection, minimum housing inspection, and drainage inspection. The town administrator shall appoint such deputies or assistant inspectors as may be provided for by the council. All such inspectors will serve during his pleasure. All inspectorial functions and the personnel designated to carry them out, which are provided for in this section, and any additional such functions as may from time to time be required by state law or provided for by ordinance, shall fall within the jurisdiction of and be conducted under the auspices of the department of community development, and under the supervision of the director of community development. All inspectors or their deputies or assistants appointed pursuant to this section shall receive such compensation as the town council may prescribe. 
Sec. 911. - Capital project commission. 
    There is hereby created a capital project commission which is authorized to exercise fiscal oversight over the construction of any public building or facility for the town, or any purchase of equipment, which is financed by a bond approved by the voters of the town and the total cost of which shall exceed five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). The capital project commission shall be appointed in the manner provided in subsection (a) hereof. The capital project commission is a permanent, standing commission and shall meet as frequently as appropriate, but no less than four (4) times per year, to review all expenditures made for capital projects. The capital project commission shall provide the town council with a detailed accounting of all expenditures of funds made in connection with a capital project falling within its jurisdiction. Further, the capital project commission shall have any powers and duties delegated to it by state law or town ordinance. 
(a)  The capital project commission will consist of seven (7) members: 
(1)  The town administrator, or his/her designee; 
(2)  The town finance director, or his/her designee; 
(3)  The director of community development, or his/her designee; and 
(4)  Four (4) members of the general public who are qualified electors of the town, who shall be appointed by the town council after solicitation of candidates. The town council shall also appoint one (1) alternate who shall sit and actively participate at a commission proceeding only if a general public member is unable to serve at the proceeding. 
(b)  The town administrator, finance director and director of community development shall serve on the capital project commission only for the duration of their terms of office or employment by the town. 
(c)  The members of the capital project commission appointed by the town council shall serve for terms of five (5) years or until their successors are appointed and qualified, provided, however, that the original appointments are made for terms of one (1), two (2), three (3) and four (4) years respectively. Further, the town council shall endeavor to appoint members of the general public who shall have training or experience in finance, accounting, construction management, architecture, construction or engineering. 
(Amend. of 11-2-10) 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, amended § 911 title to read as herein set out. Former § 911 title pertained to capital project committees. 
Sec. 912. - Director of human services. 
    There shall be a Director of Human Services who shall be appointed by the Town Administrator to serve during his or her pleasure. The duties of the Director of Human Services shall be those duties prescribed by Rhode Island state law, and such additional duties, not inconsistent therewith, as may be assigned by the Town Administrator or the Town Council. 
(Amend. of 11-3-98) 
ARTICLE 10. - PUBLIC WORKS AND ENVIRONMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, amended Art. 10 title to read as herein set out. Former Art. 10 title pertained to public works. 

Sec. 1001. - Department of public works. 
    There shall be a department of public works which shall be responsible for the conduct of all functions relating to the maintenance and improvement of public facilities in the town and the provision of such services of the town as are or may be entrusted to its management by this Charter or by the town council. The functions and services under the jurisdiction of the department of public works shall include the following: Street maintenance, repair, improvement and cleaning; snow removal; streetlighting; the management, maintenance and improvement of the town sewer and storm drainage systems; the care and maintenance of public buildings, parks, commons and other public properties and the collection and disposal of garbage and refuse. The department shall have such internal organization and personnel as the town administrator shall, with the approval of the council, prescribe. 
Sec. 1002. - Director of public works. 
    The head of the department of public works shall be the director of public works who shall be appointed by the town administrator to serve during his pleasure. If authorized to do so by the council, the town administrator may appoint also to serve during his pleasure, a deputy director of public works to whom the director of public works may delegate, with the concurrence of the town administrator, such of the functions carried on by the department as he shall see fit. Upon the recommendation of the town administrator, the council may prescribe that the director and/or the deputy director of public works must be a graduate civil engineer or have equivalent appropriate training. 
Sec. 1003. - Duties of director of public works. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the director of public works to supervise and manage the carrying out of all of the powers, duties and functions assigned to the department of public works under this Charter or by ordinance. 
Sec. 1004. - Maintenance of school property. 
    At the request of the school committee, the town administrator may assign to the department of public works responsibility for the care and maintenance of school buildings, playgrounds, and other school property, provided that the costs of such services be charged against the appropriations for the public schools, such costs to be determined by the town administrator and paid at the direction of the school committee. 
Sec. 1005. - Tree warden. 
    There shall be a tree warden appointed by the town council at its first regular meeting in January of each year, who shall have the qualifications prescribed by state law. He shall perform the functions and duties of his office as prescribed by state law. His office shall be under the direction of the town administrator. 
(Amend. of 11-2-10) 
Sec. 1006. - Water pollution control department. 
    There shall be a water pollution control department that will be responsible for maintenance and improvement of the town sewer systems, plant and the compost facility. 
(Amend. of 11-2-10) 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, amended § 1006 title to read as herein set out. Former § 1006 title pertained to appeals from decisions of director of public works. 
Sec. 1007. - Superintendent of the water pollution control department. 
    The head of the water pollution control department shall be the superintendent who shall be appointed by the town administrator, certified by the State of Rhode Island Board of Certification of Operators of Wastewater Treatment Facilities for the certification grade to that of the Bristol Treatment Facility. 
(Amend. of 11-2-10) 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, amended § 1007 title to read as herein set out. Former § 1007 title pertained to sewer and storm drainage systems. 
Sec. 1008. - Duties of the superintendent of the water pollution control department. 
    The duties of the superintendent of the water pollution control department are to plan, organize, supervise and participate in the work of the staff engaged in the operation and maintenance of the Wastewater Treatment Facility, Wastewater Collection System, Pumping Station and Compost Facility. He/she is responsible for the administration, management, financial planning and budget of the department, and is responsible for supervising general construction matters and personnel with consultative services provided by professional engineering consultants. He/she is responsible for monitoring the Wastewater Treatment and Compost Process for regulatory compliance and is responsible for monitoring industrial/commercial users and pretreatment programs for regulatory compliance; and related work. 
(Amend. of 11-2-10) 
Sec. 1009. - Parks and recreation department. 
(a)  There shall be a department of parks and recreation which shall bring together, conduct and/or coordinate all functions of town government relating to recreation/leisure planning, park development and care, management of all recreation buildings and the protection or development of the natural environment within the town which may from time to time be entrusted to the department by the town council. 
(b)  The department of parks and recreation shall be headed by a director of parks and recreation who shall be appointed by the town administrator from among persons with professional training in recreation/leisure and park development with at least five (5) years experience in the related fields. The duties of said director shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  To supervise and/or coordinate all activities and functions designated by the Charter or ordinance of the town council; 
(2)  To recommend and supervise the necessary personnel for the operation of the department; 
(3)  To report to the town administrator; and 
(4)  Under the supervision/direction of the town administrator, to create applications for grants and supervise the use of such acquired funds. 
(Amend. of 11-2-10) 
ARTICLE 11. - EDUCATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- The Amend. of 11-3-98 repealed the former §§ 1101-1109, and replaced them with §§ 1101-1104 as herein set out. 

Sec. 1101. - Regional school district. 
    In 1991 the Towns of Bristol and Warren agreed to combine their existing school districts in a single district. Beginning July 1, 1992 the school committees were combined into a regional committee whose nine (9) members shall be elected to four (4) year terms by the voters of each town in proportion to the towns' respective populations. 
(Amend. of 11-3-98) 
Sec. 1102. - Budget. 
    It is the responsibility of the Regional School Superintendent to submit a budget to the Regional School Committee each year by the 15th of January. This budget shall be reviewed by the Joint Finance Committee consisting of nine (9) members appointed by the Town Councils of Bristol and Warren in proportion to their respective populations as recorded in the most recent federal census. Members shall include the Town Administrator, the Presidents of the Town Councils and such other persons as the Councils may appoint. 
(Amend. of 11-3-98) 
Sec. 1103. - District financial meeting. 
    A regional district financial meeting shall be called upon petition of six hundred (600) district voters, filed in writing with the regional school committee within fourteen (14) days of the approval of the budget by the joint finance committee. 
(Amend. of 11-3-98) 
Sec. 1104. - Applicable law. 
    All other regulations concerning the operation of the regional school district shall be governed by Rhode Island Public Laws Chapter 91-330. 
(Amend. of 11-3-98) 
ARTICLE 12. - PERSONNEL 

Sec. 1201. - Personnel board. 
    There shall be a personnel board, consisting of five (5) members. Four (4) members thereof shall be appointed by the town council, each to serve for a four-year term, with their appointments so arranged that the term of one member shall expire and therefore one new member be appointed each year. The fifth member of said board shall be appointed by the town administrator at the beginning of his term of office to serve for a two-year term. No person shall serve upon the personnel board who is employed by or is an official of the town, nor any person who is a member of any local, state or national committee of a political party, nor an official or member of a committee in any partisan political club or organization, nor any person who holds or is a candidate for any elective office, nor any official of a labor organization representing employees of the town. Vacancies occurring during a term shall be filled by the town council for the balance of the term. Members of the board shall serve without compensation, but funds will be provided for reasonable and necessary expenses. The board shall elect its own chairman to serve for a two-year term. 
(Amend. of 11-2-10) 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, renumbered former § 1202 as the new § 1201, as herein set out. Former § 1201 pertained to general provisions. 
Sec. 1202. - Duties of personnel board. 
    The personnel board shall: 
(a)  Be responsible for the administration of testing and compiling of scores for all competitive examinations given by town departments for hiring and promotion opportunities. 
(b)  Draft, in consultation with the town administrator, job descriptions for all personnel holding the position of department head with the town government. Such job descriptions shall be sent to the office of the town administrator and kept on file and be reviewed and updated as necessary. 
(c)  Create and update, every two (2) years, an organizational chart of town government. Such organizational chart shall be submitted to the office of the town administrator and kept on file. 
(Amend. of 11-2-10) 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, renumbered former § 1203 as the new § 1202, as herein set out. 
Sec. 1203. - Reserved. 
Sec. 1204. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, repealed § 1204, which pertained to coverage of personnel system. 
Sec. 1205. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, repealed § 1205, which pertained to demotion, dismissals and suspensions. 
Sec. 1206. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, repealed § 1206, which pertained to union agreements. 
Sec. 1207. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, repealed § 1207, which pertained to investigations. 
Sec. 1208. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Charter amendment of Nov. 2, 2010, repealed § 1208, which pertained to general prohibitions. 
ARTICLE 13. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1301. - Dual office holding. 
    No person shall be eligible to hold any elective office in the town who is a member of the general assembly, or who holds any other state elective office, or any elective office in the federal government, provided however, that in any instance in which a member of the general assembly is elected to a town elective office, said member may, upon submission of his or her resignation from the general assembly, assume his or her office in the town as provided in this Charter while a successor in the general assembly is being chosen pursuant to state law. 
Sec. 1302. - Open records. 
    All executive, legislative, regulatory and administrative bodies of the town of Bristol, including but not limited to all departments, divisions, agencies, commissions, boards, offices, bureaus, authorities or other bodies which exercise governmental functions, and any other public or private agency acting on behalf of the town, shall be subject to all state legislative provisions applicable thereto, in G.L. 1956, § 38-1-1 et seq. The public's right to access to records pertaining to the policy-making responsibilities of government, and the individual's right to dignity and privacy are both recognized to be principles of the utmost importance in a free society. Accordingly, it shall be the policy of the town government to facilitate public access to governmental records which pertain to the policy-making functions of public bodies and/or are relevant to the public health, safety and welfare. 
Sec. 1303. - Codification and revision of ordinances. 
    The town council, within two (2) years following the effective date of this Charter, and every fifth year thereafter, shall cause to be prepared a revision or codification of the ordinances of the town which are appropriate for continuation as local laws of the town. Such revision shall be prepared under the supervision of the town solicitor, but the council may authorize the solicitor to contract for the services of persons or organizations experienced in the revision and codification of ordinances and statutes. 
Sec. 1304. - Amendment of the Charter. 
    This Charter may be amended at any time, or a new Charter adopted, in the manner provided by the state Constitution. No proposal for amendment shall be approved by the council unless a public hearing has been held thereon. Should two (2) or more amendments adopted at the same time have conflicting provisions, the one receiving the largest affirmative vote shall prevail. The sections of any amendment added to this Charter shall be numbered by the town clerk and inserted in their appropriate places. It shall not be necessary for the full text of a Charter or amendments to a Charter to be printed upon the ballot. Any digest or description thereof or any question or statement which substantially expresses the purpose or identifies the subject matter to be voted upon shall be sufficient. When any question is to be submitted to the voters, the town council shall approve the statement of the question as it shall appear upon the ballot. A copy of the full text of the Charter or amendments shall be posted in each polling place and such other places as may be designated by the board of canvassers. 
Sec. 1305. - Charter review commission. 
    The council shall, no later than 1995, and at least every tenth year thereafter, appoint a Charter review commission of no more than nine (9) members, chosen to be broadly representative of the town, to review the provisions of this Charter and make such recommendations to the council for revision or amendment as it shall see fit. Said commission shall report its findings no later than one year following the date of its appointment. 
Sec. 1306. - Fees. 
    All fees, penalties and payments collected by town officials or agencies in their official capacities shall be transmitted to the town treasury to be deposited in the general funds of the town, provided however, that the town council may allow the school department to retain and apply directly to appropriate accounts in the school budget, monies received as rental for school facilities and as custodian fees in connection therewith. The compensation paid to each official shall be in lieu of all fees, penalties and payments payable to such official in the performance of his or her duties. 
Sec. 1307. - Annual audit. 
    Prior to the end of each fiscal year, the town council by resolution shall arrange for an annual independent audit of the books, accounts, and other evidences of financial transactions of the town, as of the close of that fiscal year. Such audit shall be conducted either by state auditors or by a certified public accountant holding a certificate from this state and having no personal interest therein. Such examination shall conform with generally accepted auditing standards and the provisions of state law, and shall allow for the auditor to express opinions on the financial condition of the town. The audit report shall be submitted to the town administrator no later than one hundred and fifty (150) days following the end of the fiscal year covered thereby, and another copy filed with the town clerk which shall be a public record. 
Sec. 1308. - Oath of office. 
    Every officer of the town shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe the following oath or affirmation, to be filed and kept in the office of the town clerk: "I solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution and obey the laws of the United States of America and the State of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations; that I will in all respects observe the provisions of the Charter and ordinances of the Town of Bristol and will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of ___________." 
Sec. 1309. - Inventory of town property and equipment. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the head of each department and agency of town government, at the end of every fiscal year, to prepare an inventory of all equipment and supplies under the jurisdiction of his department or agency, and submit the same to the town administrator for transmission to the town council. Said inventories shall be public records with copies available for public inspection at the Town Hall. 
Sec. 1310. - Conflict of interest. 
    All elected and appointed officials of the town, as the same are defined in the statute, shall be subject to the conflict of interest legislation of the State of Rhode Island, G.L. 1956, § 36-14-1 et seq., as amended from time to time. It is the policy of the town of Bristol that no elected or appointed official use his or her office for personal gain in a manner inconsistent with the proper discharge of his duties. To implement this policy, it is the intent of this section to ensure that all such officials be clearly made subject to the standards of conduct and disclosure requirements to be observed by persons owing a responsibility to the people and the government of the town in the performance of their official duties, as set forth in the aforementioned chapter of the General Laws. 
Sec. 1311. - Conviction of crime. 
    Any elected official of the town who is convicted of a felony, and who has exhausted all appeals from that conviction, shall be deemed to have vacated his or her office, and shall not be eligible to fill by appointment or election the remainder of the term which he or she vacated. 
Sec. 1312. - Open meetings. 
    The town council, school committee and all other town departments, agencies, commissions, committees, boards and councils, and all subdivisions thereof, shall conduct all business in accordance with the provisions of the open meetings legislation of the State of Rhode Island, G.L. 1956, § 42-46-1 et seq., as amended from time to time. 
Sec. 1313. - Masculine and feminine gender. 
    Every word in this Charter importing the masculine gender only, shall be construed to extend to and include females as well as males. 
Sec. 1314. - Partial invalidity. 
    If any section or part of a section of this Charter shall be held invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such holding shall not affect the remainder of this Charter nor the context in which such section or part of section so held invalid may appear, except to the extent that an entire section or part of section may be inseparably connected in meaning and effect with the section or part of section to which such holding shall directly apply; and if any section or part of section concerned with election procedures shall be held invalid by such court, the pertinent election procedures set forth in the law of the State of Rhode Island shall apply. 
Sec. 1315. - Complaints by qualified electors of Charter violations. 
(a)  The qualified electors of the town shall have the right to demand a hearing before the town council regarding alleged violations of the Charter. A qualified elector of the town may file a sworn statement in the office of the town clerk charging that: 
(1)  An elected or appointed official or member of a board or commission of the town is serving in office in violation of the provisions of this Charter; or 
(2)  That any elected or appointed official or member of any board or commission, or that any official body, board or commission in its corporate capacity, or any town employee, has knowingly taken an action in his/her official capacity in violation of any of the terms or provisions of this Charter, or of any ordinance, rule, or regulation adopted under the authority thereof. 
(3)  Any such statement shall set forth the particulars as to the charges made. A "sufficiently set forth" complaint shall specify (1) the section or sections of the Charter which are charged to have been violated, (2) the nature of the violation, and (3) the person, persons, or body charged with having committed the violation; and 
(4)  If the town solicitor determines that the charges are "sufficiently set forth," or, if the statement referred to above is accompanied by a petition signed by two hundred fifty (250) qualified electors of the town, the town clerk shall schedule a public hearing before the town council acting in its capacity as the Charter Monitoring and Complaint Review Board, such hearing to be held no later than sixty (60) days from the date on which the charges were filed. If the town solicitor fails to find that the charges are "sufficiently set forth," or if the statement is not accompanied by a petition signed by two hundred fifty (250) qualified electors of the town, he/she shall so notify the complainant in writing, providing the reason(s) for dismissal; and 
(5)  If the complaint is against the town clerk, the town administrator shall fulfill the duties of the town clerk regarding scheduling of the public hearing as presented above. 
(b)  Action by the town: 
(1)  At the public hearing, the town council, acting as the Review Board, shall receive testimony from the complainant and from the official, board, or commission, or members of the official body against whom or which the charges were made and from such witnesses as either party may bring forward. In the event that the complaint is against a member of the town council, such member shall not take part in the review of the complaint; and 
(2)  If, following the hearing, the Review Board, by no fewer than the affirmative vote of two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the members present and voting, concludes that the charges have been supported by the testimony and evidence, it shall consider an appropriate sanction. Such a sanction may include public censure, and for appointees and employees of the town, termination or suspension from employment. Further, a violation of this Charter may be punishable by a fine not to exceed the limit set by state law. 
(c)  Construction of this article: 
    The provisions of this article are in addition to, and do not supplant, any rights, duties or obligations provided by the laws of the United States, or the State of Rhode Island. Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to limit or affect any constitutional, statutory, or common law right or protection granted to the qualified electors of the town. 
(Amend. of 11-2-10) 
ARTICLE 14. - INAUGURATION AND TRANSITION 

Sec. 1401. - Effective date. 
    This Charter shall take effect on July 1, 1971 following its approval by the qualified voters of the town and the certification of said approval by the board of canvassers. 
Sec. 1402. - Continuation of officials and agencies. 
    All officials of the town, elective and appointive, shall continue in office following the effective date of this Charter, and shall exercise the powers and duties of their respective offices as these were constituted at the time of their election or appointment, until successors have been elected and qualified or duly appointed under the terms of this Charter, or until their offices have been abolished by ordinance in implementation of this Charter. 
Sec. 1403. - First elections under this Charter. 
    The first regular election held under and pursuant to the terms of this Charter shall take place at the time of the state general election in November 1972, provided however, that a special election to fill the office of town administrator shall be held on November 2, 1971. Said special election shall be conducted in the same manner and pursuant to the same provisions of the state election law as would be the case if it were being held at the regular general election. The person elected as town administrator at said special election shall take office on the first Monday in December, to serve for a term of three (3) years, or until his successor is elected and qualified. 
Sec. 1404. - Continuation of present personnel. 
    All persons employed in the service of the town at the effective date of this Charter, shall continue in such employment until changed in accordance with the provisions of this Charter. 
Sec. 1405. - Transfer of appropriations. 
    The town council shall have authority to make any changes or transfers in appropriations existing when this Charter takes effect, where such changes or transfers are required for the operation of the town government under the provisions of this Charter. 
Sec. 1406. - Changes in administrative agencies. 
    The town council shall, as soon as practicable following the coming into effect of this Charter, provide for the creation of such new agencies, and the consolidation or elimination of such existing agencies of the town as may be required under the terms of this Charter, or which the council may deem appropriate in achieving the objectives of the Charter, but not inconsistent with its provisions. 
    All records, property, and equipment whatsoever of any office, department or agency or part thereof, all of the powers and duties of which are assigned to any other office, department, or agency by this Charter, shall be transferred and delivered to the office, department or agency to which such powers and duties are so assigned. If part of the powers and duties of any office, department or agency or part thereof are by this Charter assigned to another office, department, or agency, all records, property, and equipment relating exclusively thereto shall be transferred and delivered to the office, department, or agency to which such powers and duties are so assigned. In the event of disagreement over the transfer of the same the town administrator shall make the final decision. 
Sec. 1407. - Continuance of contracts and obligations. 
    All contracts or obligations entered into by the town prior to the effective date of this Charter shall continue in full force and effect. 
Sec. 1408. - Pending actions and proceedings. 
    No action or proceeding, civil or criminal, pending at the time when this Charter shall take effect, brought by or against the town or any office, department, or agency or officer thereof, shall be affected or abated by the adoption of this Charter or by anything herein contained. 
Sec. 1409. - Effect of Charter on existing laws. 
(a)  All laws and parts of laws relating to the Town of Bristol are hereby superseded to the extent that the same are inconsistent with the provisions of this Charter, except such laws as are enacted in accordance with powers reserved to the General Assembly by the Constitution of the state. All special laws for the creation of offices, agencies or boards for the Town of Bristol in effect prior to the inauguration of this Charter shall be deemed to have been superseded by the terms of this Charter unless provision has been made for the continuance of such special offices, agencies or boards under the terms of this Charter. 
(b)  All laws of the state relating to or affecting the town, in force upon the effective date of this Charter and not inconsistent with its provisions, shall remain in force until amended or repealed. 
Sec. 1410. - Continuation of tax obligations. 
    All taxes levied or assessed by the town prior to the effective date of this Charter which have not been collected by the town shall be collected with any interest and penalties thereon by the town government hereby established in accordance with law.

PART IV - CODE 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances contained in this and the following chapters shall be designated and cited as the "Bristol Town Code," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1972, § 1-1) 
Charter reference- Codification of ordinances, § 1303. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all other ordinances of the town, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the town council: 
    Causing an act. Any requirements or prohibitions of any act, shall respectively extend to and include the causing and procuring, directly or indirectly, of such act. 
    Code. The words "the Code" or "this Code" shall mean the "Bristol Town Code" as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. The time in which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; and if the last day is Saturday or Sunday or a legal holiday, that shall be excluded. 
    Construction of permit provisions with ordinances. Any act otherwise prohibited by law or local ordinance shall be lawful if performed under, by virtue of, and strictly within the provisions of a permit or license so to do, and to the extent authorized thereby. 
    Council. The words "the council" or "town council" shall mean the town council of the Town of Bristol, Rhode Island. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean Bristol County, Rhode Island. 
    Crossing. Any crossing whether marked by a pavement or otherwise; the extension to any sidewalk space across any intersecting drive, street or highway. 
    Curb. Any boundary of any street, road, avenue, boulevard or drive, whether or not marked by a curb. 
    Daytime, nighttime. The word "daytime" is the period of time between sunrise and sunset; and nighttime is the period of time between sunset and sunrise, unless otherwise defined herein. 
    Gender. Words used in the masculine gender shall include the feminine and neuter. 
    In the town. The words "in the town" or "within the town" shall mean and include all territory over which the town now has, or shall hereafter acquire jurisdiction for the exercise of its police powers or other regulatory powers. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The words "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and copartnerships, whether acting by themselves or as a servant, agent or employee. 
    Land and real estate. The terms "land" and "real estate" include lands, tenements and hereditaments, and rights thereto and interests therein. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Number. Words used in the singular number include the plural, and words used in the plural number include the singular. 
    Oath. When an oath is required or authorized by law, an affirmation in lieu thereof may be taken by a person having conscientious scruples against taking an oath. An affirmation has the same effect as an oath. 
    Officer, department, etc. Every officer, department, board, commission or similar body mentioned in this Code shall mean an officer, department, board, commission or similar body of the town, unless otherwise specified. 
    Official time. Whenever certain hours are named in this Code, they shall mean Eastern Standard Time or Eastern Daylight Saving Time, as may be in current use in the town. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Pedestrian. The word "pedestrian" shall mean a person afoot. 
    Person. The word "person" shall include a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a natural person. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property. 
    Plural, singular. Words importing the singular shall include the plural, words importing the plural shall include the singular. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" includes real, personal and mixed estates and interests. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall, may. "Shall" is mandatory, and "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean that part of the street exclusively reserved for pedestrians and constructed for such purpose. 
    Signature or subscription. The terms "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    Soliciting. Persons selling goods or services by sample or taking orders for future delivery with or without accepting advance payment for goods. Persons seeking any form of contributions. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state," shall be construed to mean the State of Rhode Island. 
    State law references. Whenever reference is made to the "General Laws" or "G.L. 1956," this shall mean the General Laws of Rhode Island, 1956, as amended. Whenever reference is made to "Public Laws" or "P.L.," this shall mean the Public Laws of Rhode Island. 
    Stopping or standing. When prohibited, such term means any cessation of movement of a vehicle occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with pedestrians or other traffic including horses and bicycles. 
    Tenant or occupant. The words "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies, the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Town. The words "the town" or "this town" shall be construed as if the words "of Bristol, Rhode Island" followed them. 
    Traffic. The word "traffic" shall mean pedestrians and vehicles, either singly or together. 
    Ways, streets, highways. The words "ways," "streets" and "highways" shall be construed as including boulevards, avenues, courts, lanes, alleys, squares, places and sidewalks, and each of these words includes every other of them. 
    Weekday. The word "weekday" shall mean Monday through Friday. 
    Weekend. The word "weekend" shall mean Saturday and Sunday. 
    Written, in writing. The terms "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1972, § 1-2) 
Charter reference- Masculine and feminine gender, § 1313. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections, history notes and references. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code, printed in boldface type, are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section, and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections of the Code and the references and notes scattered throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall have no legal effect. 
(Code 1972, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - Provisions deemed continuation of prior ordinances. 
    The provisions of this Code, so far as they are in substance the same as those ordinances existing on the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1972, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-5. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of any ordinance shall in no case affect any act done, or any right accrued, acquired or established, or any suit or proceeding had or commenced in any civil case before the time when such repeal shall take effect. 
(b)  No suit, prosecution or indictment, pending at the time of the repeal of any ordinance for any offense committed, or for the recovery of any fine, forfeiture or penalty, incurred under the ordinance so repealed, shall in any case be affected by such repeal, but such suit, prosecution or indictment may be proceeded with, and such ordinance shall be deemed to be in force for the purpose of prosecuting the same to final judgment and sentence, as the case may be. 
(c)  The repeal of any ordinance shall not be construed to revive any other ordinance which has been repealed. 
(Code 1972, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-6. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the town council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-7. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
    (a) Except as otherwise expressly provided, whenever in this Code or in any other ordinance or resolution of the town or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the town under authority duly vested in such person, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any other ordinance or resolution of the town or such rule, regulation or order shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00. 
(b)  Except where otherwise provided, every day any violation of this Code or any other ordinance or resolution of the town or such rule, regulation or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1972, § 1-7; Ord. No. 2015-25, 1-6-16; Ord. No. 2017-13, 10-4-17) 
Charter reference- Authority to provide for a penalty, § 208(a)(4). 
State Law reference- Authority to impose penalties for ordinance violations, G.L. 1956, § 45-6-2. 
Sec. 1-8. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to the adoption of this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission thereof from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new code of ordinances by the council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of the Code in substantially the following language: "That section _____ of the Bristol Town Code is hereby amended to read as follows:...(Set out new provisions in full)...." 
(c)  If a new section not then existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Bristol Town Code is hereby amended by adding a section (or article, chapter or other designation, as the case may be), to be numbered _____, which reads as follows:...(Set out new provisions in full)...." 
(d)  In lieu of subsection (c) of this section, when the council desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature embracing a subject not previously existing in the Code, which the council desires to incorporate into the Code, a provision in substantially the following language may be made a part of the ordinance: "It is the intention of the council, and it is hereby ordained, that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made part of the Bristol Town Code, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention." 
(e)  All sections, articles, chapters or other provisions of this Code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number, article number, chapter or other number, as the case may be. 
Sec. 1-9. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by town personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code, but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-10. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following ordinances when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by the town, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the town, or any evidence of the town's indebtedness, or any contract, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument or obligation assumed by the town or creating interest and sinking funds; 
(2)  Any right or franchise, permit, or other right granted by any ordinance; 
(3)  Any personnel regulations; any ordinance or resolution establishing salaries of town officers and employees or civil service rules; 
(4)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, alley or other public way in the town; 
(5)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades in the town; 
(6)  Any appropriation ordinance or any ordinance levying or imposing taxes; 
(7)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(8)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the town; 
(9)  Any ordinance establishing the official plat of the town; 
(10)  Any zoning map amendment or rezoning ordinance; 
(11)  Any ordinance annexing territory or excluding territory from the town; 
(12)  Any subdivision ordinance; 
(13)  Any ordinance creating special districts or assessing taxes therefor; 
(14)  Any ordinance granting specific tax exemptions; 
(15)  Any temporary or special ordinance; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Sec. 1-11. - Comprehensive plan incorporated by reference. 
    The comprehensive plan of the town, as duly adopted and amended from time to time, and as most recently amended (January 12, 2016), is hereby incorporated by reference in its entirety. 
    This section shall take effect for the purpose of conforming municipal land use decisions and for the purpose of being transmitted to the Rhode Island Director of Administration for state review upon public hearing and passage (January 12, 2016). 
    This section shall not become effective for the purposes of guiding state agency actions until it is approved by the State of Rhode Island pursuant to RIGL Ch. 45-22.2, a/k/a the Rhode Island Comprehensive Planning and Land Use Act. 
(Ord. No. 2008-22, 9-10-08; Ord. No. 2016-02, 1-12-16) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration and enforcement of traffic regulations, § 16-41 et seq.; personnel, ch. 20; police, ch. 21; taxation, ch. 27; administration of zoning regulations, § 28-31 et seq.; administration, enforcement and relief of zoning regulations, § 28-401 et seq. 
State Law reference- Cities and towns, G.L. 1956, § 45-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Handicapped grievance procedure. 
(a)  A handicapped grievance complaint should be filed in writing or verbally, contain the name and address of the person filing it, and briefly describe the alleged violation of the regulations. 
(b)  A handicapped grievance complaint should be filed within ten days after the complainant becomes aware of the alleged violation. Processing of allegations of discrimination occurring before this grievance procedure was in place will be considered on a case-by-case basis. 
(c)  An investigation, as may be appropriate, shall follow a filing of a complaint. The investigation will be conducted by the town administrator. These rules contemplate informal but thorough investigations, affording all interested persons and their representatives, if any, any opportunity to submit evidence relevant to a complaint. Under 31 C.F.R. 51.55(d)(2), the town need not process complaints from applicants for employment or from applicants for admission to post-secondary educational institutions. 
(d)  A written determination as to the validity of the complaint and description of resolution, if any, shall be issued by the town administrator and a copy forwarded to the complainant no later than ten days after its filing. 
(e)  The section 504 coordinator shall maintain the files and records of the town administrator relating to the complaints filed. 
(f)  The complainant can request a reconsideration of the case in instances where he or she is dissatisfied with the resolution. The request for reconsideration should be made within ten days to the town council chairman. 
(g)  The right of person to a prompt and equitable resolution of the complaint filed hereunder shall not be impaired by the person's pursuit of other remedies such as the filing of a section 504 complaint with the Office of Revenue Sharing, U.S. Department of the Treasury. Utilization of this grievance procedure is not a prerequisite to the pursuit of other remedies. 
(h)  These rules shall be construed to protect the substantive rights of interested persons, to meet appropriate due process standards and to assure that the town complies with section 504 and the ORS regulations. 
(Code 1972, § 2-3.2) 
Secs. 2-2-2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TOWN COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Councils and governing bodies, G.L. 1956, § 45-5-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-31. - Rules for town council meetings; certain council petitions exempt from action at meetings. 
(a)  In general, order and decorum will prevail in the council chambers during meetings. 
(b)  All matters to come before the council must be filed with the council clerk no later than 4:00 p.m. of the Wednesday preceding the meeting. All matters filed after this deadline will be held over for the next meeting. However, a councilmember has the prerogative to introduce new matters at any meeting. Also, an agenda will be prepared and be available for public inspection at the meetings. 
(c)  In the interests of time and efficiency, the clerk will not read the items in their entirety. Instead, the clerk will first mention whom the item is from. Then the clerk will give a short statement indicating the nature of the request, after which the council will take action on the matter. All items will be made public for those interested in reading the entire text. If, for some reason, any councilmember or the author of the petition or letter is at the council meeting and wants his item read in full, the council will oblige. 
(d)  No petition, letter, or other matter shall appear on the council agenda unless said petition, letter, or other filing shall contain the complete name and address of the applicant or petitioner, fully legible, together with a telephone number, if any. 
(e)  Certain petitions to the town council need not come before the town council but may be handled administratively in the following manner: 
(1)  Petitions for road cuts or utility pole installation shall be approved by the director of public works on behalf of the town council, subject to approval of the town administrator or his designee. 
(2)  Petitions for street lights or sidewalk and curbing installation under the matching fund program shall be processed by the director of public works on behalf of the town council, subject to availability of funds and forwarded to the town administrator for approval subject to funds. 
(3)  All renewals of town-granted licenses, for example, play pool licenses, cesspool pumpers' licenses, Sunday sales licenses, victualling licenses, peddlers' licenses, detective licenses, motion picture licenses, entertainment licenses, etc., shall be processed by the council clerk on behalf of the town council, subject to the payment of the appropriate fee and filing any necessary bonds. 
(4)  All petitions for junk licenses, intoxicating beverage licenses or other licenses requiring public hearing, upon payment of the cost of submitting notice and advertising, shall be set up for a public hearing by the council clerk at the time and place of a regular town council meeting and advertised accordingly. 
(5)  All petitions for Class F or F-1 beverage license (one-day license) or petitions for a religious street parade shall be approved by the council clerk on behalf of the town council, subject to notice to and approval of the director of public safety. 
(f)  Nothing herein shall preclude the town council from acting on requests before it or from taking action where necessary against holders of licenses granted hereunder. 
(Code 1972, § 2-1; Ord. No. 2015-07, 6-10-15; Ord. No. 2015-08, 6-10-15) 
Secs. 2-32-2-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Town officials, § 601 et seq. 
Cross reference- Any personnel regulations, any ordinance or resolution establishing salaries of town officers and employees or civil service rules saved from repeal, § 1-10(3); fire department, § 12-31 et seq.; personnel, ch. 20; police, ch. 21. 

Sec. 2-61. - Platting engineer. 
(a)  There shall be a platting engineer appointed by the town council to serve for a term of three years. The appointment shall be made by selecting one name from a list of not more than three names submitted by the planning board. The platting engineer shall be a graduate civil engineer or have equivalent training. He shall be familiar with the rules and regulations governing the platting or other subdivision of land. The platting engineer shall: 
(1)  Review plats for compliance with the rules and regulations of the planning board, all local ordinances and state laws; 
(2)  Supervise the construction of the subdivision to insure conformity with the technical requirements of the rules and regulations; 
(3)  Submit written reports and recommendations to the planning board prior to the preliminary hearing, final hearing and public hearing; 
(4)  Review divisions of land, other than by subdivision, to determine their compliance with the rules and regulations, local ordinances and state laws. 
(b)  The platting engineer need not be required to devote full-time to the duties of his office. He shall receive such compensation as may be set by the town council at the time of his appointment. 
(Code 1972, § 2-3.1) 
Secs. 2-62-2-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND COMMITTEES[4] 
Footnotes:
