Cross reference- Signs, § 28-371 et seq. 

Sec. 3-1. - Distribution or scattering of advertising material. 
    No person shall scatter, distribute or cause to be scattered or distributed any handbill, circular, program or advertising slip or advertising material of any kind, in or upon any highway, street or sidewalk in the city, or from house to house in the city, except by permission in writing from the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 3-3) 
Sec. 3-2. - Operation of sound machines. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated a sound machine upon any of the highways of the town, except by permission in writing from the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 3-4) 
Sec. 3-3. - Operation of noisemaking mechanical devices. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated any noisemaking mechanical device for advertising purposes upon any highway or street or sidewalk in the town, except by permission in writing from the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 3-5) 
Chapter 4 - ALARM SYSTEMS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 12; false fire alarms, § 17-4; police, ch. 21. 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm system means equipment or devices located on real property within the town, which equipment or devices are arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to which police or fire are expected to respond. In this section, the term "alarm system" shall include, but shall not be limited to, the terms "automatic holdup alarm systems," "burglar alarm systems," "holdup alarm systems," "manual holdup alarm systems," "audible alarm systems" and "fire alarm systems." 
    Direct connect systems means all alarm systems which have the capability of transmitting to any agency maintained by the town, such as the police station and/or the fire department, whether through telephone lines or a signal system. Such terms shall also include any alarm system which transmits a signal to an answering service or a monitoring service, which in turn transmits a signal, whether verbal or otherwise, to an agency maintained by the town. 
    False alarm means the activation of an alarm system, including any direct connect system, to which the police and/or fire department responds and which is not caused by: 
(1)  Fire, a criminal act or other emergency; 
(2)  An act of nature, such as an earthquake, tornado or hurricane, but not including a thunderstorm; or 
(3)  Circumstances occurring off the protected property and not within the control of the subscriber, his alarm company or his answering service including, but not limited to, electrical power failure. 
(Ord. No. 1996-08, § 1, 5-15-96) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-2. - Maintenance of system. 
(a)  The owner of any burglar alarm system in the town shall maintain all components of his alarm system in good working order at all times to ensure that the sensory mechanism is adjusted to suppress false indication of holdups, or intrusions, so that the alarm system will not be activated by impulses due to short flashes of light, wing noises, small animals, vehicular noise or other forces unrelated to genuine alarms. 
(b)  The owner of any fire alarm system within the town shall maintain all components of his system in good working order and in compliance with chapter 8 of the state fire prevention code. 
(Ord. No. 1996-08, § 2, 5-15-96) 
Sec. 4-3. - Audible alarm system. 
    No burglar alarm system within the town shall sound an alarm which is audible off of the premises for longer than 15 minutes without shutting off automatically. 
(Ord. No. 1996-08, § 3, 5-15-96) 
Sec. 4-4. - False alarms-Fines; appeals. 
(a)  The town, acting by and through the police and fire departments, upon responding to any false alarm shall leave written notice at the premises concerning the time and nature of said alarm together with a warning that the alarm system should be inspected by the homeowner and/or the alarm company with section 4-2. 
(b)  The town, acting by and through the police and fire departments, upon responding to any third and all subsequent false alarms within any six-month period of time for any single premises shall notify in writing the owner of the premises of the violation of this chapter and impose a fine in the amount to be set by the town council from time to time. In addition, the owner of the premises shall be required to register the alarm system with the police department and obtain a permit in accordance with section 4-7. Within 15 days of the mailing or hand delivery of the notice of violation of this chapter, the owner may file a written appeal of said charge with the clerk of the municipal court. Said notice of appeal shall contain information to show that the alarm giving rise to the fine was not a false alarm within the meaning of this chapter. 
(c)  Failure to appeal or pay fine. Failure of the owner to pay the imposed fee or file an appeal within 15 days of the mailing or hand delivery of the notice of violation shall result in doubling the amount of the imposed fine. Absent a pending appeal, failure of the owner to pay the imposed fee within 30 days of the mailing or hand delivery of the notice of violation shall result in the tripling of the amount of the imposed fine. In addition, failure to pay any fees imposed shall result in denial of the owner's permit application in accordance with subsection 4-7(c). 
(Ord. No. 1996-08, § 4, 5-15-96; Ord. No. 2001-07, 3-15-01; Ord. No. 2007-11, 3-21-07) 
Sec. 4-5. - False alarms-Compilation of record. 
    The chief of police and the chief of the fire department shall compile a continuous record of all false alarms within their jurisdictions and of all fines imposed pursuant to this chapter. Such records shall indicate the number and frequency of false alarms and shall separately state the amount of fines collected for false alarms in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1996-08, § 5, 5-15-96; Ord. No. 2001-07, 3-15-01) 
Sec. 4-6. - Town liability. 
    The town shall not be liable for the defects in any direct connect system; for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon receipt of an alarm from a direct connect system; for any failure or neglect of any person in connection with the installation, operation, disconnection or removal of alarm system equipment; the transmission of alarm systems signals; or the relaying of such signals or messages. 
(Ord. No. 1996-08, § 6, 5-15-96) 
Sec. 4-7. - Registration and permit required after violation. 
(a)  Any alarm system which is the subject of a notice of violation in accordance with section 4-4(b) must be registered with and obtain a permit from the police department. 
(b)  Registration and permit applications shall be made by the owner of the premises on the appropriate form and shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name, home address and telephone number of the owner. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the alarm company which services and maintains the alarm system, if the alarm is not serviced or maintained by the owner and/or 
(3)  The name, address and telephone numbers of at least two emergency contact people who can gain entrance to the property and turn off the alarm system, which information shall be updated yearly. 
(c)  At the time of registration, a subscriber shall pay a registration fee, the cost of which shall be determined by the town council. The police chief shall issue a permit if the application is complete and signed, all fees and fines are paid and the chief determines that the alarm system meets the requirements of this chapter, any rules and regulations as may be promulgated by either or both departments and state law. 
(d)  Permits may not be transferred. 
(e)  The town may impose an annual fee for monitoring a direct connect alarm system interconnected to the police department and/or fire department. 
(f)  Failure to comply with this section will result in a fine which shall be set and may be amended from time to time by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 2001-07, 3-15-01) 
Chapter 5 - AMUSEMENTS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Purpose of chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to protect the public health, safety and general welfare through the regulation of amusements, shows and exhibitions. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-1, 7-16-97) 
Secs. 5-2-5-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BILLIARD, BAGATELLE, POOL, SCIPPIO TABLES AND GAMEROOMS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Bowling alleys, billiard tables and shooting galleries, G.L. 1956, § 5-2-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-31. - Pinball or gameroom defined. 
    The words "pinball" or "gameroom" as used in this chapter shall mean any public place, building, or room where ten or more gaming devices, machines, or apparatuses are kept for the use and entertainment of the public; or any place where the main purpose of such business is to maintain machines which upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disk may be operated by the public generally for use as a game or amusement whether or not registering a score and whether its operation demands skill or chance or both or neither. The definition of "gameroom" shall be limited to those places which derive their principal source of income from such machines. 
(Code 1972, § 3.1-32) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 5-32. - Regulations and restrictions. 
    All licenses issued under this article shall be subject to such regulations and restrictions as the town council may from time to time make and prescribe. 
(Code 1972, § 3.1-36) 
Sec. 5-33. - Limit on number of licenses. 
(a)  The maximum number of licenses to be issued to saloons, shops or places of business for the keeping of billiard table, bagatelle table, pool table, scippio table or any table of similar character is fixed at 50. 
(b)  The maximum number of licenses for operation of a pinball or gameroom to be issued by the town is fixed at two. 
(Code 1972, § 3.1-38) 
Sec. 5-34. - Penalty for unlicensed operation. 
    Every person who shall keep a billiard table, bagatelle table, pool table, scippio table or any table of a similar character, or other gaming or amusement coin-operated device, in any saloon, shop, or place of business, or own or keep any such table for public use or profit, or operate a pinball or gameroom, without first obtaining a license, or in any place other than that specified in a license, or any violation of this article, shall be fined $100.00 for each offense. Each day of operation shall constitute a separate offense. 
Secs. 5-35-5-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 5-56. - Required. 
    No person shall keep a billiard table, bagatelle table, pool table, scippio table or any table of similar character in any saloon, shop or place of business or own or keep any such table for public use or profit or operate a pinball or gameroom within the town without first obtaining a license from the town council to do so. 
(Code 1972, § 3.1-33) 
Sec. 5-57. - Term, expiration. 
    Every license issued under the provisions of this article shall specify the name and address of the person licensed, or if a corporation, the names and addresses of all stockholders and officers, and the address where said tables shall be kept. All licenses shall be issued for a term of one year beginning on December 1 of each year. Regardless of the date issued, all licenses shall expire on November 30 of each year; and all licenses shall be paid in full with no proration because issued for less than a year term. 
(Code 1972, § 3.1-35) 
Sec. 5-58. - Fees. 
    The fee for a license under this article shall be as set out in section 11-1. 
(Code 1972, § 3.1-34) 
Secs. 5-59-5-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SHOWS, EXHIBITIONS AND ENTERTAINMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult-only establishment means any establishment customarily not open to the public at large but only to one or more classes of the public or which excludes any minor by reason of age as a prevailing practice. 
    Applicant means a person, partnership or corporation. 
    Show, exhibition or similar form of entertainment means any theatrical performance, show, exhibition, concert, dances and balls, or any other entertainment, whether indoors or outdoors, but shall exclude parades or other events regulated under section 25-4. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-10, 7-16-97) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 5-72-5-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 5-91. - Required. 
    No person shall maintain, operate or conduct any show, exhibition or similar form of entertainment within the town without first obtaining a license from the town council. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-11, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 5-92. - License application; information required. 
    Any person applying for a license for a show, exhibition or similar form of entertainment shall file an application on a form approved by the town council. The application for a license shall set forth the following information and such other information as may reasonably be required: 
(1)  The name, residence, mailing address and telephone number of the person making the application (where the person making the application is a partnership, corporation or other association), this information shall be required for all partners, officers, directors or members. 
(2)  The days and hours during which the proposed show, exhibition or similar entertainment is to be conducted. 
(3)  The nature and types of activities that will occur. 
(4)  The approximate number of spectators and participants reasonably expected to be present or participate in the event. 
(5)  A plan, drawn to scale, depicting the exact location of the event including the exact size and dimensions of the entertainment area and its approximate distance and relative location from the public entrance of the building or other enclosed area where applicable. 
(6)  The location and number of health and sanitation facilities. 
(7)  Written proof that the applicant is 18 years of age or older. 
(8)  Other information as may be required by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-12, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 5-93. - Fees; contents; terms. 
    The fees for licenses for a show, exhibition or similar form of entertainment shall be as set out in section 11-1. Such fees shall be assessed on an annual or biannual basis. The licensing fee shall be waived for any nonprofit, educational or charitable organization providing a show, exhibition or similar form of entertainment. Every license issued under this article shall specify the name and address of the person licensed, or if a corporation, the names and addresses of all stockholders and officers, the address where the show, exhibition or entertainment will take place and the hours, and the expiration date of the license. The term for a license under this article shall not exceed one year. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-16, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 5-94. - Approval. 
    Upon receipt of the properly prepared application and fee, the town clerk shall forward copies of the application to the director of public safety, the chief of police, the fire chief, the zoning enforcement officer and the building inspector and other such officials as the director of public safety may deem necessary. Such officials shall review and investigate matters relevant to the application and, within 30 days of its receipt, shall make any pertinent reports, comments or recommendations about the application to the town council in writing. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-11, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 5-95. - Prerequisites for obtaining a license. 
    The town council shall approve the issuance of a license under this article after a public hearing unless the town council finds one or more of the following to be true: 
(1)  The applicant has not provided all the information requested under section 5-92 or has not complied with all other obligations as set forth in this article. 
(2)  The applicant has falsely answered any question or request for information reasonably necessary for issuance of the license. 
(3)  The applicant is overdue in payment of any town taxes, fees, fines or penalties as of the date of application. 
(4)  The applicant has not submitted a zoning certificate indicating that the use is permitted. 
(5)  The applicant has maintained, operated or conducted any show, exhibition or similar form of entertainment within the last 12 months and has demonstrated an inability to operate or manage such show, exhibition or entertainment in a peaceful or law abiding manner, thus necessitating action by police or other law enforcement. 
(6)  The issuance of the license or the place where the license is to be utilized presents a danger to the public health, safety or welfare. 
(7)  The town council finds other just cause to conclude that the issuance of a permit would be inconsistent with the purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-14, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 2011-21, 11-30-11) 
Sec. 5-96. - Adult-only establishment. 
    In addition to the requirements under section 5-95, the following requirements shall apply to the licensing of adult-only establishments offering shows, exhibitions or similar forms of entertainment: 
(1)  All adult entertainment shall cease no later than 12:00 midnight. 
(2)  An applicant who has been convicted or whose spouse has been convicted of a crime of moral turpitude or any felony may qualify for a license under this section only after five years have elapsed since the date of conviction or the date of release from the confinement imposed for conviction, whichever is the later date. 
The town council has the discretion to impose other requirements, terms and conditions on a permit, which are reasonably necessary to control the secondary effects of adult-only entertainment in keeping with the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-15, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 2012-02, 2-1-12) 
Cross reference- Nudity on premises where alcoholic beverages are offered for sale, § 17-54. 
Sec. 5-97. - Restrictions. 
(a)  The chief of police and fire chief may restrict the number of persons allowed in the entertainment area as deemed necessary for the protection of the public health, welfare and safety. 
(b)  In granting a license under this section, the town council may make such restrictions as are necessary for the protection of the public health, welfare and safety, for the prevention of nuisances, excess noise and maintenance of public peace, including but not limited to prohibiting amplified music, limiting the number of musicians to no more than three, and requiring that all entertainment cease by 10:00 p.m. on nights from Sunday through Thursday, and by 12:00 midnight on Friday and Saturday nights. 
(c)  The director of public safety shall determine whether and to what extent additional police protection reasonably necessary for the purposes of traffic, crowd control and security will be required for the event or entertainment. Payment of all police officers assigned or provided by the director of public safety shall be paid by the applicant according to the director's instructions. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-13, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 2012-02, 2-1-12) 
Sec. 5-98. - Compliance with other laws. 
    Every applicant for a license under this article shall comply with all laws of the state and all other ordinances of the town. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-17, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 5-99. - Revocation or suspension. 
    All licenses granted under this article may be revoked at the sole discretion of the town council. Sufficient cause to refuse further licenses under this article and to suspend or revoke any licenses issued under this article or deny renewal of a license originally issued under this article shall include but is not limited to the failure of the licensee to strictly comply with the provisions of this article and the laws of the state and of any terms and conditions imposed by the town council on the licensee. Upon denial, suspension or revocation of such license, the licensee shall be ineligible to reapply for a license for a period of two years from such denial, suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-18, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 5-100. - Operation without a license and penalties for violation of this article. 
    In addition to any action pursuant to section 5-99, any person who maintains, operates or conducts any show, exhibition or similar form of entertainment within the town without first obtaining a license from the town council, or in any location other than that specified in the license, and any licensee in violation of this article, shall be fined pursuant to section 11-1. The continuation of a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute, for each day the violation is continued, a separate and distinct violation hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1997-09, § 3.1-19, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 2011-21, 11-30-11; Ord. No. 2017-13, 10-4-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-21, adopted Nov. 30, 2011, amended § 5-100 title to read as herein set out. Former § 5-100 title pertained to operation without a license. 
Secs. 5-101-5-114. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BINGO 

Sec. 5-115. - License provisions. 
    The provisions of G.L. 1956 § 11-19-30 et seq. shall apply to organizations requesting a license to conduct bingo games. 
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 10; noise from animals and birds, § 10-47; health and sanitation, ch. 13; rat control, § 13-106 et seq.; hunting prohibited, § 17-7. 
State Law reference- Animals generally, G.L. 1956, title 4. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adequate food means the provision at suitable intervals, not to exceed 24 hours, of a quantity of wholesome foodstuff suitable for the species and age, sufficient to maintain a reasonable level of nutrition in each animal. The foodstuff shall be served in a sanitized receptacle, dish or container. 
    Adequate water means the constant access to a supply of clean, fresh, potable water provided in a sanitary manner or provided at suitable intervals for the species and not to exceed 24 hours at any interval. 
    Animal control officers means the persons employed by the town as its enforcing officers for the purpose of the enforcement of the town's municipal ordinances, and any state laws relating to the licensing of dogs, control of dogs, seizure and impoundment of dogs and the implementation of the state rabies mandates as set forth by the state rabies control board. 
    Animal shelter means the facility designated by action of the town administrator for the purpose of impounding and caring for, in a humane manner, any dog that is found running at large in violation of this chapter, or any dog or cat seized for the purpose of quarantine, as set forth by the state's rabies control board. 
    Back yard feeder cats means any feline which, while maintained, fed and/or harbored by any individual, partnership, firm, corporation or other legal entity maintains, by parentage and upbringing, the traits and characteristics of a feral cat. 
    Dog means a domesticated canine, and shall include both the male and female of the species. 
    Domestic cat means any cat which, by upbringing, is tame and adapted to and totally dependent upon human living conditions. 
    Enclosure means a fence or structure of at least six feet in height, forming or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young children, and suitable to confine a vicious dog in conjunction with other measures which may be taken by the owner or keeper, such as tethering of the vicious dog. The enclosure shall be securely enclosed and locked and designed with secure sides, top and bottom, and shall be designed to prevent the animal from escaping from the enclosure. 
    Feral cat means any feline, which by limited or no exposure to humans, react and act as any wild animal, and do not depend upon humans for their primary source of food. 
    Impounded means the taking into custody of a dog by an officer of the town. 
    Owner means any person owning, keeping, maintaining, or harboring dogs or cats, and/or has any dog or cat in his care or control, or who acts as its custodian, and any person who has, or permits, dogs or cats to remain on or about any premises owned and/or occupied by such person. 
    Rabies target species means any raccoon, skunk, fox, bat, woodchuck or any carnivorous wild animal. 
    Restraint means a dog confined within a vehicle, confined within the property limits of its owner or on a leash under the control of a competent person. A dog is not considered confined if it can escape from the property limits due to open windows or doors or if fences are not properly maintained or of a sufficient height. 
    Sanitize means to make physically clean and to remove and destroy, to a practical minimum, agents injurious to health and well-being. 
    Vicious dog (as used in sections 6-101 and 6-102) means: 
(1)  Any dog which, when unprovoked, in a vicious or terrorizing manner, approaches any person in an apparent attitude of attack upon the streets, sidewalks or any public grounds or places; 
(2)  Any dog with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury to or to otherwise endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals; 
(3)  Any dog which bites, inflicts injury, assaults or otherwise attacks a human being or domestic animal without provocation on public or private property; or 
(4)  Any dog owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of dogfighting or any dog trained for dogfighting. 
No dog may be declared vicious if an injury or damage is sustained by a person, who, at the time that injury or damage was sustained, was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon premises occupied by the owner or keeper of the dog, or was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. No dog may be declared vicious if an injury or damage was sustained by a domestic animal which at the time that injury or damage was sustained was teasing, tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog. No dog may be declared vicious if the dog was protecting or defending a human being within the immediate vicinity of the dog from an unjustified attack or assault. 
(Code 1972, § 4-5; Ord. No. 2001-32, 10-24-01) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-2. - Animals at large. 
    No cattle, sheep, goats, swine, horses, rabbits and domestic fowl shall be at large, loose or unfastened in any public street or highway or elsewhere in the town, and every owner of any such animal found at large shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 4-1) 
Sec. 6-3. - Registration of bovine, horses, livestock, rabbits and domestic fowl required. 
    The owner, harborer and/or keeper of any cattle, sheep, goats, swine, horses, rabbits and domestic fowl housed, kept or boarded within the town must register with the town police department/division of animal control. Registration information must include the name, address and phone number of the owner, emergency contact name and phone number location where the animals are housed and the number of, and type of, animals kept. 
(Code 1972, § 4-1.1) 
Sec. 6-4. - Cleanliness and sanitation of premises where animals and fowl kept. 
    The owner or person in control of any building or premises in which cows, goats, sheep, swine, poultry, horses and/or rabbits are maintained shall keep the building and premises clean and free from decaying food, dirt, water and fecal matter. Buildings and pens shall be whitewashed and disinfected and put in such sanitary conditions as may be ordered by the animal control officer. 
(Code 1972, § 4-2) 
Sec. 6-5. - Feeding of birds, domestic animals. 
(a)  No person shall place food in the open for the feeding of any domesticated fowl, bird or animal, except in such containers as will prevent the scattering of such food upon the ground. After such feeding, such food shall not be allowed where it is accessible to rats. 
(b)  No person shall feed wild birds other than in suitable containers for the food, elevated at least 48 inches above the ground level. 
(Code 1972, § 4-3) 
Sec. 6-6. - Feeding of wildlife. 
    No person shall feed, or place food or refuse in such a manner as to cause a food source for any wild animal. 
(Code 1972, § 4-3.1) 
Sec. 6-7. - Requirements for stables. 
    The owner or other person having control of any building erected for or converted into a barn for the stabling of horses or other domestic animals shall keep such barn, stable and yard clean, and shall provide a pit constructed of cement or other suitable material for the reception of manure and other refuse matter. Such pit and premises shall be so maintained that adequate control of fly breeding is obtained. Wherever a public sewer is accessible, the town council, after consultation with other relevant officials, will decide as to the advisability of connecting such buildings to such public sewer. 
(Code 1972, § 4-4) 
Secs. 6-8-6-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS AND CATS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-41. - Enforcement of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the animal control officer provided that agents on behalf of the animal control officer may, from time to time, be designated by the town administrator to assist the animal control officer in the enforcement of this article. Animal control agents shall be empowered to issue citations in conformance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 4-6; Ord. No. 2000-12, 5-31-00) 
Sec. 6-42. - Payment of fines. 
    All fines due and owing on account of violations of any section in this article shall be payable to the treasurer's office. 
(Code 1972, § 4-6.2) 
Sec. 6-43. - Impoundment; disposition of unredeemed dogs and cats. 
(a)  The animal control officer shall take up any dog found not under restraint and impound it in the animal shelter, and confine it there in a humane manner for five days, unless sooner redeemed by the owner. The animal control officer shall impound any cat found on public property that is determined to be sick or injured. 
(b)  Upon impounding a dog or cat, the animal control officer shall make a reasonable effort to notify the owner of such dog or cat so impounded and inform such owner of the conditions whereby he shall regain custody of the animal. The animal control officer shall inform the owner or keeper that he shall thereafter be liable for all fines, fees and all expenses incurred in the care and impoundment of such dog or cat. 
(c)  After the legal detention period has expired and such dog or cat has not been claimed by its owner, the animal control officer may, at his discretion, euthanize the dog or cat in a humane manner, or the animal control officer may place such dog or cat in the care and custody of some person deemed to be a responsible and suitable owner, who shall agree to comply with the provisions of all dog laws and ordinances effective in their town, and/or as set forth by state law. 
(d)  Any dog over three months old found within the limits of the town without evidence that such dog has been vaccinated or inoculated in accordance with the provisions of this article shall be impounded by any animal control officer for a period not exceeding five days, during which time such dog may be returned to its owner upon proof of ownership, vaccination of the dog, payment by such owner of the fees provided in section 11-1. At the expiration of such five-day period any dog not so claimed by its owner shall be disposed of in accordance with this section. 
(e)  If the owner or keeper of a dog or cat fails to reclaim such dog or cat, as set forth in this section, he shall be fined according to section 11-1, and be liable for all fees and expenses incurred in the impoundment and care of the animal. Such fines and fees shall be recovered by action of debt, or by complaint and warrant. These fines and fees shall be payable to the treasurer's office. 
(Code 1972, § 4-8) 
Sec. 6-44. - Redemption of impounded dogs and cats. 
    The owner shall be entitled to regain possession of his impounded dog or cat upon the payment to the town treasurer of the fee set forth in section 11-1. 
(Code 1972, § 4-9) 
Sec. 6-45. - Unvaccinated dogs and cats. 
(a)  No dog or cat over three months old shall be permitted within the town limits unless such dog or cat shall have been vaccinated or immunized in the manner set forth in section 6-46. If such dog or cat shall have been vaccinated with its primary vaccine, such vaccine shall be valid for a 12-month period, and each subsequent vaccine administered to the dog or cat thereafter shall be valid for a 24-month period. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or harbor any dog or cat over three months old within the town unless such dog or cat shall have been vaccinated or inoculated in accordance with the provisions in section 6-46. This section shall apply to all dogs and cats including, but not limited to, any dog or cat that is maintained primarily as an indoor house pet. 
(c)  The owner or keeper of any dog or cat not properly vaccinated or inoculated shall be fined according to section 11-1. Such fines shall be recovered by action of debt, or by complaint and warrant. These fines shall be payable to the treasurer's office. 
(Code 1972, § 4-10.1) 
Sec. 6-46. - Vaccination requirements. 
    The vaccination or immunizations referred to in section 6-45 shall be by the vaccine approved by the state department of health, and shall be certified to by a licensed veterinarian. Such certificate shall be dated as of the date of inoculation or vaccination, shall, where applicable, show the rabies tag number, the sex and breed of the dog or cat and the owner thereof, and whether the vaccine given is a one-year or two-year vaccine, together with such other information as may reasonably be required by the health officer or the veterinarian administering the inoculation. Such certificates issued for verification of rabies vaccinations shall follow the format of the National Association of State and Public Health Veterinarians (NASPHV), form 51. 
(Code 1972, § 4-10.2) 
Sec. 6-47. - Dogs and cats to be reported and quarantined for biting or being bitten. 
(a)  Every dog or cat which bites any individual, or other domestic animal shall be promptly reported to the animal control officer. 
(b)  The animal control officer shall then follow the rules and regulations set forth by the state rabies control board, as listed in the state rabies management and protocol manual, and be quarantined when required. 
(1)  If any dog or cat that bites any human or domestic animal is current on its rabies vaccination, such dog or cat shall be placed in quarantine, for a period of 14 days. The place of quarantine shall be at the discretion of the animal control officer, and may include quarantine on the owner's premises, or, at the owner's expense, at the animal shelter, or in a state-approved kennel or veterinary hospital of the owner's choice. 
(2)  If any dog or cat that bites any human or domestic animal does not have a current rabies vaccination, the animal control officer shall order the animal to be placed in quarantine for a period of 14 days. The place of quarantine shall be off the owner's premises; and, at the owner's expense, the dog or cat shall be quarantined at the animal shelter, or in a state-approved kennel or veterinary hospital of the owner's choice. 
(c)  The owner or keeper of any dog or cat that bites, or is bitten by, a rabies target species must report that contact and/or bite to the animal control officer. 
(1)  If any dog or cat bites, or is bitten, by a target species animal and is current on its rabies vaccination, the animal control officer shall order the owner, at the owner's expense, to immediately booster the rabies vaccination of the dog or cat, and shall order the dog or cat placed in strict confinement for 45 days. Strict confinement may be held on the owner's premises. 
(2)  If any dog or cat bites, or is bitten, by a target species animal and does not have a current rabies vaccination, the animal control officer shall place the dog or cat in quarantine for a period of three months, to be followed by strict confinement for three months. Such place of quarantine shall be off the owner's premises. At the owner's expense, such dog or cat shall be quarantined at the animal shelter, or in a state-approved kennel or veterinary hospital of the owner's choice. Three months' strict confinement shall immediately follow the three months' quarantine. Such place of strict confinement shall be at the discretion of the animal control officer, and may include the owner's premises, the animal shelter or a state-approved kennel or veterinary hospital of the owner's choice. The animal control officer shall order the dog or cat to be rabies vaccinated prior to its release from quarantine. 
(d)  The owner or keeper who fails to quarantine such dog or cat as ordered by the animal control officer shall be charged with a misdemeanor and fined not less than $200.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense, and be subject to confiscation of the animal which is the basis of the violation. Such fines shall be recovered by action of debt, or by complaint and warrant. These fines shall be payable to the treasurer's office. 
(e)  The animal control officer shall confiscate and impound any dog or cat found to be in violation of an order of quarantine, and the duration of the quarantine shall be served at the animal shelter. The owner or keeper of such dog or cat shall be responsible for all expenses incurred during the animal's impoundment. 
(Code 1972, § 4-11.2; Ord. No. 2017-13, 10-4-17) 
Sec. 6-48. - Abandoned dogs, cats and domestic animals. 
    The owner or keeper of a dog, cat or other domestic animal who shall move from his place of residence and leave behind such dog, cat or other domestic animal shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and be fined no less than $50.00 and no more than $500.00 for each offense. Such fines shall be recovered by action of debt, or by complaint and warrant. These fines shall be payable to the treasurer's office. 
(Code 1972, § 4-12.1; Ord. No. 2017-13, 10-4-17) 
Secs. 6-49-6-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DOGS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 6-71. - Dogs restricted on July 4. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or owner to permit or cause any dog, rather licensed and/or leashed, to be on or along the parade route during the July 4 parade from the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m., and/or cause or permit any dog to be present on private or public property, not owned by such person, at the July 4 fireworks display. 
(Code 1972, § 4-4.2) 
Sec. 6-72. - Citations. 
    The animal control officer shall issue citations to the owner of dogs for the violation of any animal control ordinance, which citations may be paid by mail to the treasurer's office. 
(Code 1972, § 4-6.1) 
Sec. 6-73. - Restraint required. 
    The owner or keeper of any dog shall keep his dog under restraint at all times. 
(Code 1972, § 4-7) 
Sec. 6-74. - Leashed restraint required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper to permit his or her dog to go upon any public property, including any park, beach, sidewalk, street, or public playground area, or to go upon any school grounds without such dog being physically restrained on a leash or lead, not to exceed ten feet in length, and under the control of a competent person. 
(Code 1972, § 4-7.1; Ord. No. 2001-33, 11-14-01) 
Sec. 6-75. - License to be according to state law. 
    Every dog in the town shall be licensed according to G.L. 1956, § 4-13-4, as well as the provisions of section 6-81, as may be applicable. 
(Code 1972, § 4-10; Ord. No. 2001-24, 9-12-01) 
Sec. 6-76. - Certificate prerequisite to license. 
    No license shall be issued for any dog required to be licensed in the town unless the person making application therefor shall first present to the town clerk, or other duly authorized person to issue such license, a current certification of vaccination or inoculation, as provided in this article, for the dog for which such license is requested. Such certificate shall certify that the dog for which the license is to be issued has been properly vaccinated or inoculated in accordance with the provisions of this article. Public clinics providing inoculations at a nominal charge shall be made available once a year by the department of police. 
(Code 1972, § 4-10.3) 
Sec. 6-77. - Unspayed female dogs to be confined. 
(a)  The owner or keeper of a female dog which has not been spayed shall keep such dog confined while the dog is in heat. It shall be a violation of this section for such dog to be allowed to run at large or be restrained out of doors. 
(b)  The animal control officer shall direct that such confinement be within a building on the owner's premises, or at the owner's expense, in a kennel or veterinary hospital of the owner's choice. 
(c)  The animal control officer shall fine the owner or keeper in violation of this section according to section 11-1. Such fines shall be recovered by action of debt, or by complaint and warrant. These fines shall be payable to the treasurer's office. 
(d)  Any dog in heat, found running at large shall be impounded by the animal control officer in accordance with section 6-43. 
(Code 1972, § 4-11.3) 
Sec. 6-78. - Barking dogs. 
(a)  No person shall keep or harbor any dog, whether licensed or not, which by habitual howling, yelping or barking does disturb the quiet of any person residing in the neighborhood, and each day of disturbance shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  When one or more persons in a neighborhood shall affirm in writing that any dog is a nuisance as a result of such habitual howling, yelping or barking, the animal control officer shall, if he finds such nuisance to exist, fine the owner or keeper of such dog according to section 11-1. Such fines shall be recovered by action of debt, or by complaint and warrant. These fines shall be payable to the treasurer's office. 
(Code 1972, § 4-12) 
Sec. 6-79. - Sanitary conditions for keeping. 
(a)  The owner or person in control of any building, kennel or premises in which a dog is kept and maintained shall keep the building and/or premises clean and free from decaying food, dirt, fur, stagnant water and fecal matter. 
(b)  The owner or keeper of any dog that is kept out of doors or in a kennel shall provide the dog with appropriate shelter from the weather. Appropriate shelter shall be defined as a dog house. 
(c)  The owner or keeper of a dog shall, when physically restraining such dog out of doors, secure such dog on a lead not shorter than 15 feet in length. 
(d)  The owner or keeper of a dog shall provide the dog with adequate food, water and shelter. 
(Code 1972, § 4-13) 
Sec. 6-80. - Canine waste removal. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each person who owns, possesses or controls a dog to remove and dispose of any feces left by his dog on any sidewalk, street, park or other public area. It shall further be the duty of each person who owns, possesses or controls a dog to remove and dispose of any feces left by his dog on any private property neither owned nor occupied by such person. 
(b)  No person who owns, possesses or controls such dog shall appear with such dog on any sidewalk, street, park or other public area, or on any private property neither owned nor occupied by such person without such means of removal of any feces left by such dog. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding $25.00 for the first offense, not exceeding $50.00 for the second offense, not exceeding $100.00 for the third offense and any subsequent offenses within a year to be recovered by action of debt or by complaint or warrant, to use as such town council may prescribe. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to a licensed dog accompanying any handicapped person, who by reason of his handicap is physically unable to comply with the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1972, § 4-4.1; Ord. No. 1997-13, 10-1-97; Ord. No. 2000-12, 5-31-00) 
Sec. 6-81. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-03, adopted April 9, 2014, repealed § 6-81, which pertained to registration of certain breeds of dogs required. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Sec. 6-82. - Number of dogs limited. 
    No person shall keep, other than in a duly licensed breeding kennel, in any household (or on the premises thereof) occupied by such person more than three dogs over the age of six months without first obtaining a kennel license from the town. 
(Ord. No. 2001-24, 9-12-01) 
Sec. 6-83. - Penalties. 
    Any violation of this article shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 2001-24, 9-12-01) 
Secs. 6-84-6-100. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Vicious Dogs 

Sec. 6-101. - Findings and declarations. 
(a)  It is hereby declared that vicious dogs have become a serious and widespread threat to the safety and welfare of residents of the town. 
(b)  The number and severity of these attacks are attributable to the failure of owners to register, confine and properly control vicious dogs. 
(c)  It is further declared that the owning, keeping or harboring of vicious dogs is a nuisance. 
(d)  It is further declared that because of the danger posed to the public health, safety and welfare by vicious dogs, this section and section 6-102 constitute a measure providing for the immediate preservation of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1972, § 4-11) 
Sec. 6-102. - Control. 
(a)  Enclosure required. All vicious dogs shall be confined in an enclosure. It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper to maintain a vicious dog upon any premises which does not have a locked enclosure. It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper to allow any vicious dog to be outside of the dwelling of the owner or keeper or outside of the enclosure unless it is necessary for the owner or keeper to obtain veterinary care for the vicious dog or to sell or to give away the vicious dog or to comply with commands and directions of the animal control officer with respect to the vicious dog. In such event, the vicious dog shall be securely muzzled and restrained with a chain having a minimum tensile strength of 300 pounds and not exceeding three feet in length, and shall be under the direct control and supervision of the owner or keeper of the vicious dog. Such person must be a competent adult that has full control over the vicious dog. 
(b)  Application of provisions of section 6-101 and this section. The provisions of section 6-101 and this section shall not apply to K-9 or other dogs owned by the police department or any law enforcement officer which are used in the performance of police work. 
(c)  Disposal. A vicious dog shall be disposed of as follows: 
(1)  Any vicious dog which is not maintained on property with an enclosure; or 
(2)  Which shall be outside of the dwelling of the owner or keeper, or outside of an enclosure, except as provided for in this section; 
shall be confiscated by an animal control officer and euthanized in an expeditious and humane manner after the expiration of a five-day waiting period, exclusive of holidays. In addition, the owner or keeper shall pay a $250.00 fine to the town. 
(d)  Dogs injuring or killing human beings; fine and euthanization. If any vicious dog shall, when unprovoked, attack, assault, wound, bite, or otherwise injure or kill a human being, the owner or keeper shall pay a $1,000.00 fine. The owner shall then be ordered to relinquish the dog, and the dog shall, after a five-day waiting period, be humanely euthanized. No person shall be charged under subsections (c) or (d) of this section, unless the dog, prior to the offense alleged, shall have been declared vicious pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Fees for violations regarding licensing. Every owner or keeper of any dog, having been declared vicious, found to be in violation of any town ordinance governing the licensing of such dogs, shall for the first offense be fined $25.00, and for a second violation of this subdivision shall be fined $200.00, and for a third or subsequent offense shall be fined $500.00. 
(f)  Liability in situations where minor is owner. If the owner or keeper of the vicious dog is a minor, the parent or guardian of that minor shall be liable for all injuries and property damage sustained by any person or domestic animal caused by an unprovoked attack by such vicious dog. 
(Code 1972, § 4-11.1) 
Sec. 6-103. - Presence on public playground or schoolground. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or keeper to allow any dog that has been declared vicious or dangerous to be upon any public playground or upon any schoolgrounds. 
(Code 1972, § 4-7.2) 
Secs. 6-104-6-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CATS 

Sec. 6-126. - Keeping of feral and/or back yard feeder cats. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain and/or keep feral cats or back yard feeder cats without having such cats properly rabies vaccinated. Such cats must also be spayed or neutered. 
(b)  The owner or keeper shall incur all expenses to rabies vaccinate and alter the cats. 
(c)  Any owner or keeper who fails to comply with this section shall be ordered, by action and/or decree of the town council, to remove and destroy the cats, as such cats, when unaltered and unvaccinated, present a nuisance and health risk to the public. 
(d)  The owner or keeper shall incur all expenses in meeting any order set forth by the town council. 
(Code 1972, § 4-14) 
Chapter 7 - BICYCLES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 16. 

Sec. 7-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bicycle means any bicycle, tricycle, tandem bicycle or any other similar vehicle, unless the context indicates to the contrary. 
(Code 1972, § 5-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 7-2. - Application of general traffic laws. 
    Every person propelling a bicycle on any public highway or in any public park, square, street, lane or alley in the town shall have, except as provided in this chapter, the same rights and be subject to the same restrictions and duties as provided with regard to the use of other vehicles as set forth in chapter 16 of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 5-2) 
Sec. 7-3. - Signal bell. 
(a)  Required; attachment to handle bar. In addition to the regulations of section 7-2, every person propelling any bicycle or other vehicle in any public highway or in any public park, square, street, lane or alley in the town shall cause a signal bell to be attached thereto, and to be used for the purpose of giving warning of its approach. Such signal bell shall be capable of being heard when at rest a distance of not less than 250 feet, and shall be so attached to the handle bar that it can be positively and directly operated by the fingers of one hand of the rider without removing such hand from the handle bar. 
(b)  Duty to sound. Such signal bell as required in subsection (a) of this section shall always be sounded with several rapid strokes whenever the rider is approaching any person or any other vehicle, and shall be used in all cases where there is any danger of collision. 
(Code 1972, §§ 5-3, 5-4) 
Sec. 7-4. - Riding abreast. 
    No more than two persons using any bicycle shall be allowed to ride abreast of each other. 
(Code 1972, § 5-5) 
Sec. 7-5. - Method of riding to ensure control. 
    No person riding any such bicycle shall remove his feet from the pedals except in case of accident or for the purpose of braking or dismounting. Every person riding any bicycle shall at all times keep at least one hand upon the handle bar, and except as stated in this section, both feet upon the pedals, in order to retain complete control of such bicycle. 
(Code 1972, § 5-6) 
Sec. 7-6. - Riding, propelling, moving or trundling upon sidewalk or footwalk. 
    No person shall ride, propel, move or trundle any bicycle upon any sidewalk or public footwalk in the business district of the town, unless it is for the purpose of necessarily crossing such district. 
(Code 1972, § 5-7) 
Sec. 7-7. - Leaving on sidewalk or footwalk. 
    No person shall allow any bicycle belonging to him or under his care to stand or remain on any sidewalk or public footwalk. 
(Code 1972, § 5-8) 
Chapter 8 - BOATS, DOCKS AND WATERWAYS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Harbor commission, § 908. 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 25; zoning, ch. 28; setback of individual sewage disposal facilities from bodies of water, § 28-145; performance standards for commercial and industrial uses in the waterfront for manufacturing zoning, § 28-155. 
State Law reference- Waters and navigation, G.L. 1956, title 46; regulation of boats, G.L. 1956, § 46-22-1 et seq.; local regulation of boats, G.L. 1956, § 46-22-14. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Purpose of chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(1)  Manage the waters of the town and balance the diverse uses of the waters and waterfront; 
(2)  Maintain and improve shoreline public access and water quality; 
(3)  Continue to support opportunities for commercial fishing and recreational boating; and 
(4)  Remain consistent with the goals and policies of the town harbor management plan, the town comprehensive plan, the state coastal resources management program, the state department of environmental management, and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-1; Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Anchoring means to secure a vessel temporarily to the bottom of a waterbody by dropping an anchor or other ground tackle from a vessel. 
    Boat launching ramp means any manmade or natural facility used for the launching and retrieval of boats. (article 300.4, state coastal resources management program) 
    Channel means any water areas reserved for unobstructed movement of vessels. 
    Commercial fisherman means an active, full-time fisherman with a current commercial license and a working commercial vessel. 
    Commercial marine business owner means an active, full-time marine business owner with a current marine business certificate/license issued by the State of Rhode Island whose dock slip and/or mooring are used directly for company marine related activities. 
    Commercial means any organization or business entity which does not meet the definition of the word "resident." 
    Fairway means any locally designated and/or maintained water areas reserved from unobstructed movement of vessels. 
    Harbor commission means the body, the members of which are appointed by the town council, established to carry out the provisions of this chapter and to bear the responsibility of advising the town council and town administrator on harbor and waterfront management, according to the policies set forth in the harbor management plan. See section 908 of the Town Charter. 
    Harbor department means the body, the members of which are appointed by the town council and report to the town administrator, the function of which is to coordinate and administer all activities taking place in the harbors and waterways contiguous to the coastal shoreline of the Town of Bristol. See section 803 of the Town Charter. 
    Harbormaster means that person appointed by the town council. 
    Marina means any dock, pier, wharf, float, floating businesses, or combination of such facilities, that service five or more recreational boats as a commercial enterprise or in association with a club. (article 300.4, state coastal resources management program) 
    Mean high water (MHW) means the average height of the high waters over a 19-year period. 
    Moor means to permanently secure a vessel to the bottom of a waterbody by the use of mooring tackle. 
    Mooring means that location within a waterbody duly permitted by the town and registered to the applicant. 
    Mooring tackle means all hardware used to secure a vessel at a mooring. 
    Nonprofit sailing school means any Bristol-based nonprofit organization dedicated to providing education and instruction about sailing. 
    Nonresident means any individual which does not meet the definition of the word "resident." 
    Nonwater dependent use means those activities which are not dependent upon the waterfront for continued use (e.g. restaurants and residential development). 
    Nonwater related use means those activities which are in no way dependent upon or even related to the waterfront for its continued use. 
    Private mooring means a mooring for the mooring owner's personal boat. The mooring owner must own 50 percent or greater of the boat which would be placed on the mooring. The owner must provide documentation to the harbormaster to ensure true ownership and residency. (Examples of documentation include drivers license and boat registration). 
    Qualified inspector means any person or business approved as an inspector of mooring tackle by the harbor commission. 
    Recreational boating facility means marinas, launching ramps, residential boating facilities, recreational wharves, piers and slips, floats or floating docks, and recreational mooring areas. (article 300.4, state coastal resources management program) 
    Resident means any permanent, full-time individual inhabitant of the town. Proof of residency is required at the request of the harbormaster. A post office box is not a legal address for this purpose. 
    Right-of-way means an unobstructed path or corridor from a public thoroughfare or facility leading to or along the waters of the town and shoreline areas below the mean high-water mark. 
    Shellfish transplant area means as defined by the state DEM, fish and wildlife. 
    Vessel means every description of watercraft, used or capable of being used as a means of transportation on water. (Specifically excluded by this definition are floating homes.) 
    Water dependent use means those waterfront activities, solely dependent upon the waterfront for their continued use (e.g. commercial fishing, marinas and boat building). 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-2; Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01; Ord. No. 2011-20, 11-30-11; Ord. No. 2017-06, 6-7-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 8-3. - Penalties for violation of chapter. 
    The town council herein establishes penalties for boating violations, consistent with state law, based upon the recommendation of the harbor commission. 
    Every owner, master, or person in charge of any vessel who shall neglect or refuse to obey the direction of the harbormaster or an assistant harbormaster, or violates any rule or regulation promulgated under G.L. 1956 §§ 46-4-1 et seq. or 46-22-1 et seq., not specifically set forth in Rhode Island Department of Environmental Management's penalty schedule shall be subject to a fine under this chapter of $100.00.

Sec. 8-4. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Harbormaster and harbor patrol. A harbormaster and harbor patrol shall enforce this chapter as follows: 
(1)  The town council shall appoint a harbormaster and assistant harbormasters as authorized by and with the duties set forth in G.L. 1956, § 46-4-1 et seq. 
(2)  A harbor patrol, made up of the harbormaster, appointed for a term of three years commencing January 1, 2018, and assistants appointed annually by the town council, shall patrol the waters under its jurisdiction. The harbor patrol shall come under the direction and control of the harbormaster. 
(3)  All harbor patrol boat crew members must qualify in boat handling and water safety in a manner and degree satisfactory to the harbormaster. 
(4)  The harbormaster and assistant harbormasters of the town are authorized to make arrests and to take other steps to enforce the provisions of this chapter and, in the exercise thereof, shall have the authority to stop and board any vessel within the water subject to the jurisdiction of the town pursuant to G.L. 1956, § 46-22-17. 
(5)  Any patrol boat used for the service of the town shall keep a log in a manner satisfactory to the harbormaster. Such log shall indicate the date, time and service, weather conditions, wind conditions, area patrolled at one-half hour intervals, gas consumption and a description of occurrences, incidences and other confrontations. 
(6)  All regulations relating to the town's boating regulation program shall be maintained by the offices of the town administrator and town clerk, and all violations shall be processed by the harbor patrol in accordance with provisions of law applicable thereto. 
(7)  The harbormaster shall appoint a lieutenant who shall take charge in the absence of the harbormaster and shall perform such other duties as delegated by the harbormaster. 
(8)  When on active duty, members of the harbor patrol authorized by the harbormaster, shall have the right to bear firearms while in full uniform, in accordance with the ordinances of the town or laws of the state or the United States. 
(b)  Enforcement of operation and equipping of vessels. The state law provisions concerning operation and equipping of vessels shall be adopted as follows: 
(1)  The town council adopts all of the provisions of G.L. 1956, § 46-22-1 et seq., relating to the operation and equipment of vessels and motorboats within the water subject to the jurisdiction of the town. 
(2)  The town council adopts all of the provisions of G.L. 1956, § 46-27-1 et seq., relating to the operation of personal watercrafts. 
(c)  Hours of operation. The harbor department shall be staffed as determined by the harbormaster in consultation with the town administrator. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-5; Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01; Ord. No. 2009-1, 2-25-09; Ord. No. 2011-20, 11-30-11; Ord. No. 2014-01, 3-5-14; Ord. No. 2017-11, 8-23-17) 
Sec. 8-5. - Areas under jurisdiction. 
    The coastal waters and harbor areas of the town included under the jurisdiction of this chapter include those waters within Bristol harbor and the Bristol Shoreline to the inshore bounds of the federal channel starting at the northwesterly bound of the Warren-Bristol line, southerly around Poppasquash Point, southeasterly to the Mount Hope Bridge, excluding the waters adjacent to Hog Island which are in the Town of Portsmouth, and northerly to the northeasterly point of the Bristol/Warren line. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-3; Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-6. - Deposit of revenue into general fund. 
    All revenue generated by town boat launching fees, mooring permit fees, qualified mooring inspectors, other fees of this chapter, and fines levied under the authority of this chapter shall be deposited into the general revenue fund of the town for general purposes of the town, including the management and implementation of the town harbor management plan and this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-8; Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-7. - Liability. 
    Persons using the coastal waters and harbor areas of the town shall assume all risk of personal injury and damage or loss to their property. The town assumes no risk on account of accident, fire, theft, vandalism or acts of God. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-9; Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-8. - Informal procedure for payment of boating violation fines. 
(a)  Payment without personal appearance. Any member of the Bristol Harbor Patrol and any other duly authorized enforcement officer who charges any person with an offense as set forth in this chapter, in addition to issuing a summons for the offense, shall provide the offending operator with a form which will allow the offender to dispose of the charge without the necessity of personally appearing before the municipal court, provided that any operator who has been guilty of a third or subsequent boating violation within 12 months of the first offense must appear before the municipal court on the date specified on the summons, and may not dispose of the third or subsequent offense administratively. This section shall apply to both resident and nonresident operators. 
(b)  Method of payment. If the offending operator elects to dispose of the charge without personally appearing before the municipal court, he or she shall execute the form indicated and return it to the municipal court not later than 20 days from the date of the summons either by mailing or delivering the form and summons to the municipal court clerk or the clerk's designee with a check or money order in the amount indicated by the fine schedule on the form. 
(c)  Schedule of violations. Those violations set forth in § 8-3 of this chapter may be handled administratively through the method described in this section, provided however that this list is not exclusive and jurisdiction may be conferred on the municipal court with regard to other violations consistent with the Rhode Island General Laws, and these ordinances. 
(d)  Failure to answer. In the event an operator fails to answer within 20 days, then he or she shall have waived his or her right to dispose of the offense without personal appearance, and the person charged with such violation must appear before the municipal court on the date specified on the summons. 
(e)  Adjudication. Adjudication of boating violations contained in this chapter shall be in the same manner as for cases involving motor vehicle violations as set forth in section 2-215 of these ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-9. - Qualifications and requirements of harbor department personnel. 
(a)  Harbormaster. The qualifications and requirements of the harbormaster are defined in the job description which has been generated by the Bristol Personnel Board, approved by the town council and filed with the office of town administrator. 
(b)  Assistant harbormasters and auxiliary harbormasters. 
(1)  All applicants for appointment to assistant harbormaster or auxiliary harbormaster shall be interviewed and evaluated by a screening board of superior officers who shall rate all applicants and shall list them in the numerical order of standing and then be presented to the town council for appointment based on this evaluation. 
(2)  A member must be a resident of the town and must never have been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude. 
(3)  A member, at the member's expense, must successfully pass a physical examination. 
(4)  A member must be a high school graduate or its equivalent and shall be tested for educational background. 
(5)  All members must attend and successfully complete training to the standards of the Rhode Island Harbormasters Academy. 
(Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01; Ord. No. 2011-20, 11-30-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-20, adopted Nov. 30, 2011, amended § 8-9 title to read as herein set out. Former § 8-9 title pertained to qualifications and requirements of assistant harbormasters. 
Secs. 8-10-8-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HARBOR REGULATIONS 

Sec. 8-41. - Vessel speed zones. 
    The town hereby designates the following vessel speed zones, to be established and marked immediately by town council petition to the state department of environment management, division of enforcement: 
(1)  Navigation fairways. Vessel speed shall not exceed five miles per hour, nor create wake in any navigation fairway, as established and described in this article and in the harbor management plan. 
(2)  Mooring fields. Vessel speed shall not exceed five miles per hour, nor create wake in any mooring field, as established and described in the harbor management plan. 
(3)  Dock areas. Vessel speed shall not exceed five miles per hour, nor create wake in any dock areas, as established and described in the harbor management plan. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(a); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-42. - Vessel operations. 
    Vessels used alone or engaged in activities including, but not limited to, water skiing, jet skiing, paragliding, and other like uses are not allowed within 200 feet of any swimming area, mooring area, shoreside facility, rights-of-way ingress and egress point, launching ramp or navigation fairway. Vessels used in these manners are allowed within 200 feet of shoreside facilities when the sole purpose is to begin or end such activity. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(b); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-43. - Navigation fairways, regulatory buoys and aids to navigation. 
(a)  Navigation fairways. The following designated navigation fairways have been approved by the U.S. Coast Guard and shall be maintained by the harbor department. 
(1)  Bristol Harbor-East; 
(2)  Bristol Harbor-West; and 
(3)  Kickemuit River. 
(b)  Regulatory buoys. Regulatory buoys shall be defined by the harbor department and be submitted to the U.S. Coast Guard for approval. The harbor department shall also submit proper notification to the department of environmental management and coastal resources management council and submit the proper registration documents to the Rhode Island Secretary of State. The harbor department shall maintain these regulatory buoys. 
(c)  Aids to navigation. Aids to navigation shall be defined by the harbor department and be submitted to the U.S. Coast Guard for approval. Except for any federally maintained aid to navigation, the harbor department shall maintain these aids to navigation. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(c); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01; Ord. No. 2011-20, 11-30-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-20, adopted Nov. 30, 2011, amended § 8-43 title to read as herein set out. Former § 8-43 pertained to navigation fairways. 
Sec. 8-44. - Obstruction of channels, fairways and berthing spaces. 
    No vessel shall be moored or anchored so as to interfere with the free and unobstructed use of channels, fairways or berthing spaces within the areas under town jurisdiction as detailed in section 8-5. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(d); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-45. - Swimming and waterskiing. 
    Swimming is prohibited in all navigation fairways, town dock areas and launching areas. In mooring fields and transient anchorage areas swimming is prohibited, with the exception of vessel owners or crews or persons contracted to do maintenance on the boat or its mooring tackle within a reasonable distance of said boat. Waterskiing shall be prohibited in all designated channels, fairways and mooring areas. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(e); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01; Ord. No. 2005-03, 2-2-05) 
Sec. 8-46. - Fishing and placement of fishing gear. 
(a)  The placement of fish nets are prohibited in all navigation fairways and mooring fields. 
(b)  Fishing is prohibited on Rockwell Dock and on the finger piers of Church Street Dock. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(f); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-47. - Boat sewage waste no discharge zone. 
    The disposal of untreated boat sewage wastes by any means into the coastal waters of the town is prohibited. 
    No person shall operate a marine sanitation device at any time so as to create or permit to pass or to be discharged any sewage into the waters of the town. Penalty for violation of this section shall be a fine of $500.00 for the first offense. The second offense will result in a fine of $1,000.00 and forfeiture of all mooring permits and/or dock slips in the name of the offender. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(g); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-48. - Marine debris. 
    The discharge of any waste, garbage, plastic, cardboard, chemicals, refuse, petroleum product or byproduct, paint varnish, dead animals, fish, bait or any other debris into the coastal waters of the town is prohibited. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(h); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-49. - Towing and moving of vessels. 
    If any vessel berthed, moored, or anchored in the coastal waters of the town is found to be in violation of any provision of this article, the harbormaster is directed to move, relocate or tow such vessel. In addition to any fines such violation may incur, a fee of $50.00 shall be collected from the vessel owner for such harbormaster action. This fee shall be set by the town council, upon recommendation from the harbor commission. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(i); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01; Ord. No. 2009-1, 2-25-09) 
Sec. 8-50. - Rafting. 
    Vessels may raft on a single mooring when such activity does not interfere with the proper functioning of adjacent single moorings or vessel anchorages. Vessels at raft shall have a person aged 16 years or older on boat at all times. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(j); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-51. - Abandoned vessels, structures and moorings. 
(a)  Upon determination of the harbormaster, the harbormaster may take custody and control of abandoned vessels, structures and moorings located in the coastal waters and harbor areas of the town and remove, store or otherwise dispose of such vessel, structure or mooring at the expense and sole risk of the owner of the abandoned vessel or structure. Reasonable notice of such removal, storage, or disposal shall be publicly advertised. 
(b)  The harbormaster shall assume all of the duties and powers of the commissioner of wrecks and shipwrecked goods as detailed in the G.L. 1956, § 46-10-1 et seq. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(k); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-52. - Special events. 
    The harbormaster, shall be notified in writing of certain special events, such as swimming races, regattas, marine parades, or other marine and maritime activities that may from time to time be held on or in the coastal waters and harbor areas under the jurisdiction of the town. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(l); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-53. - Boat standards. 
    Every vessel entering the coastal waters and harbor areas of the town shall be equipped as required by G.L. 1956, § 46-22-1 et seq. and all similar federal laws, rules and regulations. Consistent with G.L. 1956, § 46-22-1 et seq., the harbormaster shall have the authority to enforce all provisions of G.L. 1956, § 46-22-1 et seq. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(m); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-54. - Rights-of-way to the water. 
(a)  No person shall block, barricade or in any way impede the public use of or access to designated public rights-of-way to the water as defined by the coastal resources management council or the town. 
(b)  No person shall park or store a vessel, vehicle or structure on a designated public right-of-way to the water as defined by the coastal resources management council or the town. 
(c)  Any person in violation of this section shall be subject to a fine in accordance with section 8-3 of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(n); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-55. - Transient anchoring and anchorages. 
    A vessel may anchor on its own anchor in the coastal waters and harbor areas of the town except in federal navigation channels, navigation fairways, shellfish transplant beds, mooring fields, swimming areas, rights-of-way ingress and egress areas, and launching ramp areas. No vessel anchored under such conditions shall be left unattended. Owners and/or operators of such vessels may go ashore, but must be available to tend the vessel in the event of heavy weather. It shall be the vessel owner's and/or operator's responsibility to remain clear of all moored vessels, and other structures. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(o); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01; Ord. No. 2009-1, 2-25-09) 
Sec. 8-56. - Failure to stop. 
    It shall be a violation of this article for any person to refuse to move or stop on oral command or order of the harbormaster or assistant harbormasters operating from a patrol boat identified as such and exercising the duties lawfully assigned to him. 
(Code 1972, § 5.1-4(p); Ord. No. 2001-38, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 8-57. - Mooring inspections. 
(a)  All new moorings in the coastal waters and harbor areas of the town must have the chain, tackle and anchor inspected by the harbormaster or his designee prior to setting the mooring. 
(b)  Every permit holder shall be required to maintain his mooring in safe condition. Any chain, shackle, swivel or other tackle which has become warped or worn by one-third its normal diameter shall be replaced. Failure to maintain a safe mooring shall be cause for revocation of the mooring permit and shall be deemed a violation of this article. The harbormaster or his designee may inspect any moorings at any time to determine compliance with this section. 
(c)  All moorings shall be inspected every other year. Odd permit numbers, shall be inspected, on odd years and even permit numbers on even years, and the results of such inspection shall be reported to the harbormaster by June 1. A qualified inspector shall perform mooring inspections. Either by raising the mooring to the surface, underwater inspection by a diver, or other method approved by the harbor commission shall make the inspection valid. Mooring inspections shall be performed by a qualified inspector. The inspection shall be made by either raising the mooring to the surface, underwater inspection by a diver, or other method approved by the harbor commission. Such inspection shall determine compliance with the mooring and mooring tackle standards of the mooring regulations of this article. 
(d)  Any mooring or component of a mooring reported not in compliance with the mooring regulations shall be replaced, or repaired and re-inspected within 15 days of such notice. After a mooring and/or its mooring tackle has been deemed to violate any requirements of the mooring regulations of this article, a second mooring inspection must be completed to determine if the violation has been corrected and meets the standards detailed in the mooring regulations of this article. The results of such second mooring inspection must be reported to the harbormaster.
