(2)  In the areas of the town subject to such snow emergency, if any owner, operator or person in charge of a motor vehicle parked upon a public street or highway therein is unable, refuses or fails to remove such motor vehicle there from, any police officer of the town is hereby authorized and directed to call upon an approved towing service, and direct that such motor vehicle be removed to a suitable place within the town. Any motor vehicle thus removed from the public streets or highways of the town shall not be further removed from the location to which it is towed, without the written consent of the owner, operator or person having charge thereof, or an agent of such owner, operator or other person duly authorized, in writing. In addition to other remedies, a person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine as adopted by the town council in section 11-1 of this Code. 
(3)  Every motor vehicle removed from the public streets or highways of the town during a snow emergency under the provisions of this section and towed to a place of storage on public property of the town shall not be removed there from by the owner, operator or other person having charge thereof, except upon the payment to the chief of police, or his/her duly authorized agent for such purpose, or to the person performing such towing service, as evidenced by a written receipt of payment of a towing charge as established by the Public Utilities Commission (P.U.C.) of the State of Rhode Island. 
(4)  Vehicles which have been placed in emergency parking lots during a snow ban emergency must be removed within one hour from the lifting of the snow ban. Persons violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine as adopted by the town council in section 11-1 of this Code. 
(5)  During any snow emergency, the police officer directing the towing away of a motor vehicle parked on the public streets or highways shall call only upon towing service companies which have indicated by a writing deposited with the chief of police, agreeing to abide by the provisions of this section respecting such towing charges and other regulations, and shall have further agreed to remove motor vehicles for storage, if other than upon the premises of or under the direct control of such towing service companies, only to the public location as directed by such police officer. Towing service companies so registered with the chief of police shall be listed in alphabetical order and shall be called upon for their services by such police officers to the greatest possible extent in the order of their appearance on such list. Violations of this section, by any towing service company or by the owner, operator or person having charge of a motor vehicle parked upon the public highways of the town during a snow emergency declared by vote of the town council as aforesaid, shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine of $5.00 for each offense, and the owner or operator of a towing service company shall be subject, upon conviction of a violation of this section, to a removal of his name from the approved list of eligible towing service companies. 
(6)  Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to prohibit the owner, operator or person having charge of a motor vehicle parked upon the public streets or highways of the town during a snow emergency, from entering into a private arrangement with a towing service company for the towing and removal of a motor vehicle from such public street or highway to a place of storage without the limits thereof, upon such terms and conditions as such person may agree upon; provided, however, that such towing under private arrangement shall be completed and such vehicle towed away prior to the time a direction by a police officer of the town shall have been issued to have such motor vehicle towed away by an approved service company under the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Deposit of snow on public property prohibited. Depositing or placing snow on public property, including streets, highways, rights-of-way, easements, and sidewalks is prohibited. Application of this section shall not be limited to snow emergencies but shall apply for all snow events. Persons violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine as adopted by the town council in section 11-1 of this Code. 
(Code 1972, §§ 11-5, 11-6; Ord. No. 2005-59, 1-5-06; Ord. No. 2008-19, 9-10-08) 
Sec. 16-4. - Clinging to moving vehicles. 
    No person traveling upon any bicycle, coaster sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle or other vehicle shall cling or attach himself or his vehicle to any other moving vehicle upon the street. 
(Code 1972, § 11-7) 
Sec. 16-5. - Unlawful riding on vehicles. 
    No person shall ride on any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers, when the vehicle is in motion. This section shall not apply to the interiors of truck bodies in the space intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1972, § 11-8) 
Sec. 16-6. - Manner of stopping buses for receiving or discharging passengers. 
    Except at a loading zone, no operator of a bus shall bring the bus to a stop to receive or discharge passengers at any other place than close to the curb or side of the traveled way when the same is accessible, or when the same is not accessible to stop for such purpose in any position such that there is room for another vehicle to pass on the side where passengers are to be received or discharged. 
(Code 1972, § 11-9) 
Sec. 16-7. - One-way streets designated and parking restrictions established. 
    The following streets are hereby designated as one-way streets. Traffic shall proceed on such streets only in the direction indicated. Vehicles shall be parked only on the side of the street indicated as follows: 
    Bourne Street, east from High to Woods Street; no parking south side. 
    Congregational Street, west from Wood to High Street; no parking south side. 
    Cooke Street, south from Constitution Street to Union Street; no parking east side. 
    Cottage Street, west from Wood to High Street; no parking on the south side. 
    Court Street, easterly from Hope to High Street; no parking north side. 
    John Street, westerly from Hope Street to Thames Street; no parking south side. 
    Loring Road, north to Curtis Road and west to Brookwood Road. 
    Monroe Avenue, north from Franklin to Bayview Avenue; parking restricted west side from Franklin Street to Lincoln Avenue; no parking on east side. 
    Pearse Avenue, south from Church Street to Constitution Street; no parking either side except as designated as follows: 
    At a point beginning 30 feet south from the southwest corner of Church Street and Pearse Avenue and extending 20 feet south on the west side of Pearse Avenue. 
    At a point beginning 110 feet south from the southwest corner of Church Street and Pearse Avenue and extending 20 feet south on the west side of Pearse Avenue. 
    At a point beginning 150 feet south from the southwest corner of Church Street and Pearse Avenue and extending 20 feet south on the west side of Pearse Avenue. 
    At a point beginning 206.8 feet from the southeast corner of Church Street and Pearse Avenue and extending 20 feet south on the east side of Pearse Avenue. 
    At a point beginning 357.8 feet from the southeast corner of Church Street and Pearse Avenue and extending 20 feet south on the east side of Pearse Avenue. 
    At a point beginning 457.8 feet from the southeast corner of Church Street and Pearse Avenue and extending 20 feet south on the east side of Pearse Avenue. 
    At a point beginning 487.8 feet from the southeast corner of Church Street and Pearse Avenue and extending 20 feet south on the east side of Pearse Avenue. 
    At a point beginning 517.8 feet from the southeast corner of Church Street and Pearse Avenue and extending 20 feet south on the east side of Pearse Avenue. 
    Prospect Street, south from Mt. Hope Avenue to Richmond Street; no parking east side. 
    Rock Street, north from State Street to Shaws Lane; no parking west side. 
    Roma Street, west from Gray Street to Wood Street; no parking on the north side. 
    St. Elizabeth Street, east from Wood Street to Magnolia Street; no parking north side. 
    Shaws Lane, west from Ryan Avenue to Wood Street; no parking north side from 6:30 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. 
    Sherry Avenue, north from corner to Perry Street. 
    Wardwell Street, westerly from Central Street; no parking south side. 
    Wilson Street, north from Franklin Street to Roma Street; no parking west side. 
(Code 1972, § 11-10) 
Sec. 16-8. - Limited egress from Gooding Plaza to Hope Street. 
    Vehicles are prohibited from exiting onto Hope Street from Gooding Plaza which is located at the corner of Hope Street and Gooding Avenue on that land leased to Gooding Realty Corporation by the town on October 16, 1958. 
(Code 1972, § 11-10.1) 
Sec. 16-9. - Violations and arrest. 
    The provisions of section 16-45 shall apply with equal force to section 16-8 and are hereby made a part thereof. 
(Code 1972, § 11-10.2) 
Secs. 16-10-16-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 16-41. - Enforcement of chapter; direction of traffic by police officers. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the provisions of this chapter. Police officers are hereby authorized to direct all traffic either in person or by means of visible or audible signal in conformance with the provisions of this chapter; provided, however, that in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may temporarily direct traffic, as conditions may require, notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Traffic aids, individuals designated as such by the town administrator, from time to time, shall be empowered to issue parking tickets and violation notices in conformance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 11-11) 
State Law reference- Town authorized to regulate traffic by means of police officers, G.L. 1956, § 31-12-12. 
Sec. 16-42. - Promulgation of traffic regulations by chief of police. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized and empowered to make and enforce regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter, and to make temporary regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. 
(Code 1972, § 11-12) 
Sec. 16-43. - Compliance with directions, orders or signals of police officers required. 
    No person shall refuse or fail to comply with any order, signal or direction of a police officer, either in uniform or displaying an official police badge. This section shall apply to members of the permanent police department and members of the reserve staff who have been officially assigned to duty only. 
(Code 1972, § 11-13) 
Sec. 16-44. - Applicability of chapter provisions to public employees. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the operator of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the U.S. government, this state or town or any other political subdivision, and it shall be unlawful for any such operator to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 11-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, §§ 31-12-3, 31-12-4. 
Sec. 16-45. - Informal procedure for payment of parking fines. 
(a)  Payment without personal appearance. Any member of the town police and any other duly authorized enforcement officer who charges any person with an offense as set forth in this section, in addition to issuing a summons for the offense, shall provide the offending operator with a form which will allow the offender to dispose of the charge without the necessity of personally appearing before the municipal court; provided that any operator who has been guilty of a third or subsequent parking violation within 12 months of the first offense must appear before the municipal court on the date specified on the summons, and may not dispose of the third or subsequent offense administratively. This section shall apply to both resident and nonresident operators. 
(b)  Method of payment. If the offending operator elects to dispose of the charge without personally appearing before the municipal court, he or she shall execute the form indicated and return it to the municipal court not later than 14 days from the date of the summons either by mailing or delivering the form and summons to the municipal court clerk or the clerk's designee with a check or money order in the amount indicated by the fine schedule on the form. 
(c)  Schedule of violations. The following violations may be handled administratively through the method described in this section; provided, however, that this list is not exclusive and jurisdiction may be conferred on the municipal court with regard to other violations consistent with the Rhode Island General Laws, and this Code: 
Parking Violations Schedule 
Violation Fine  (1) Overtime parking ..... $20.00 (2) Parking prohibited area ..... 10.00 Parking prohibited area, Old Ferry Road ..... 35.00 (3) Double parking ..... 10.00 (4) Parking loading zone ..... 10.00 (5) Parking on sidewalk ..... 10.00 (6) Obstructing driveway ..... 10.00 (7) Angle parking ..... 10.00 (8) Parking within 15 feet of corner ..... 10.00 (9) Parking with left wheels to roadside ..... 10.00 (10) Parking within eight feet of fire hydrant ..... 20.00 (11) Parking in excess of one foot from curb ..... 10.00 (12) Parking on marked crosswalk ..... 15.00 (13) Parking in street sweeping zone ..... 25.00 (14) Parking in official's designated zone ..... 10.00 (15) Parking unregistered vehicle on street ..... 10.00 (16) Parking in fire lane ..... 20.00 (17) Parking of vehicle overnight which weighs one ton or more in a residential zone ..... 10.00 (18) Parking during snow ban ..... 25.00 (19) Parking without permit on State Street dock ..... 25.00 (20) Parking without permit on Church Street dock ..... 25.00 (21) Parking in violation of traffic control device ..... 25.00 (22) Parking without a trailer in designated areas at Independence Park ..... 20.00 (23) Failure to remove vehicle during snow emergency parking ban ..... 25.00 (24) Parking unattached trailer on street ..... 20.00 (25) Failure to pay daily rate parking fee on Prudence Ferry Dock ..... 25.00 (26) Parking without permit in a reserved space on Prudence Ferry Dock ..... 25.00  
(d)  Failure to answer. In the event an operator fails to pay the amount stated on the notice of parking violation or fails to enter a plea of not guilty to the citation within 14 days from the date of summons, then said fines shall be doubled and the operator shall have waived his or her right to dispose of the offense without personal appearance, and must appear before the municipal court on the date specified on the summons. Absent a municipal court hearing, failure to pay the foregoing stated fines within 28 days from the date of summons shall result in triple the stated amount of the fine. 
(e)  Adjudication. Adjudication of parking violations contained in this chapter shall be in the same manner as for cases involving motor vehicle violations as set forth in section 2-215 of this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 11-15; Ord. No. 1999-19, 8-25-99; Ord. No. 2000-10, 5-31-00; Ord. No. 2002-15, 7-17-02; Ord. No. 2002-20, 9-12-02; Ord. No. 2007-12, 3-21-07; Ord. No. 2008-03, 5-7-08; Ord. No. 2008-31, 11-12-08; Ord. No. 2015-04, 4-29-15) 
State Law reference- Town to provide for payment of traffic fines to police department, G.L. 1956, § 12-14-4. 
Sec. 16-46. - Towing authorized for multiple violations. 
    If the owner of any motor vehicle has received three parking citations and has failed to either pay the fines or appear in court in accordance with section 16-45, the police may cause the vehicle to immediately be towed and impounded until all outstanding fines, court costs, towing charges, and storage charges are paid. Notwithstanding the above, if the owner of any motor vehicle violates section 16-45(26), "Parking without permit in a reserved space on Prudence Ferry dock," the harbormaster may cause the vehicle to immediately be towed upon notification to the police department and the vehicle shall be impounded until all outstanding fines, towing charges and storage fees are paid. 
(Ord. No. 2003-03, 4-2-03; Ord. No. 2015-04, 4-29-15) 
Secs. 16-47-16-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIGNS, SIGNALS AND MARKINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Town authorized to regulate traffic by means of traffic-control devices, G.L. 1956, §§ 31-12-12, 31-13-3. 

Sec. 16-76. - Placing, maintaining or displaying of unauthorized signs and signals. 
    No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any street, any unofficial sign, signal or device, which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, other than signs denoting construction or obstructions in the street, or which hides from view any official traffic sign or signal. Every such prohibited sign, signal or device is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and the police department is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed, without notice. 
(Code 1972, § 11-16) 
Sec. 16-77. - Moving, defacing, interfering with, obstructing or injuring signs and signals. 
    No unauthorized person shall wilfully deface, injure, move, obstruct or interfere with any official traffic sign or signal. 
(Code 1972, § 11-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, G.L. 1956, §§ 31-13-10, 31-13-11. 
Sec. 16-78. - Marking of crosswalks. 
    The police department is hereby authorized to establish and to designate and shall thereafter maintain, or cause to be maintained, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in its opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as it may deem necessary. 
(Code 1972, § 11-18) 
Secs. 16-79-16-110. - Reserved.

Sec. 16-113. - Stop required before entering throughways. 
    Every operator of a vehicle traveling upon any street intersecting or joining any street designated as a throughway shall bring such vehicle to a full stop at or near the place where such street meets the prolongation of the nearest property line of such throughway, subject to the direction of any traffic control sign or signal or any police officer at such intersection or junction. The operator of any vehicle who has come to a full stop as required upon entering the throughway, as well as the operators of any vehicles on such throughway, shall be subject to the usual right-of-way rule prescribed by law and applicable to vehicles at intersections or junctions. 
(Code 1972, § 11-20) 
State Law reference- Town authorized as to through streets and requiring vehicles to stop before entering the same, G.L. 1956, §§ 31-12-12, 31-20-6; stopping at through highways, G.L. 1956, § 31-17-3.

Sec. 16-115. - Driving on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive the vehicle on any sidewalk, except for the purpose of crossing the sidewalk when necessary, and then only in the shortest way between the street and the abutting estate. 
(Code 1972, § 11-22) 
Sec. 16-116. - Driving on Bristol Common and parks and playgrounds. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive the same upon the Bristol Common and all parks and playgrounds except in designated areas. 
(Code 1972, § 11-23) 
Sec. 16-117. - Driving through processions. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive between or attempt to cut across the line of a hearse and other vehicles and pedestrians constituting a funeral procession, or other duly authorized processions. 
(Code 1972, § 11-24) 
Sec. 16-118. - Driving on streets closed to traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to drive over that part of any street being mended, repaired or paved, if wholly closed to travel. 
(Code 1972, § 11-25) 
Sec. 16-119. - No through commercial and/or industrial trucks. 
    Commercial and/or industrial trucks are prohibited from through passing on the following streets: 
Christopher Drive. 
Herzig Street. 
Through trucking is prohibited on Washington Street between High Street and Monroe Avenue. 
(Ord. No. 2007-22, 8-29-07; Ord. No. 2007-28, 10-10-07) 
Secs. 16-120-16-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Stopping, standing and parking, G.L. 1956, § 31-21-1 et seq. 

Sec. 16-141. - Parking to allow for all necessities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on streets during a declared emergency, or during special events, or when conditions exist that may require prohibiting parking on certain public streets at the time specified. 
(b)  The chief of police shall have the power to declare emergency or designated routes for planned special events, and to have signs posted, and to take actions necessary to clear those streets of vehicles. 
(c)  The days and location during which this parking prohibition shall be in effect shall be based upon the schedule as designated by the chief of police. 
(d)  All streets regulated in this section may be posted to notify motorists of regulations imposed. 
(e)  The penalty for violation of this section shall be as set forth in section 16-45. 
(f)  The police department and all members thereof, in addition to issuing a parking violation ticket, are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked in violation of this section. Cars so towed away shall be stored in a safe place, and shall be restored to the owner or operator of such vehicle upon payment of the parking fine, and the charge for towing and storage. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the vehicle to ensure timely retrieval and care of the vehicle. 
(g)  It shall be a prima facie evidence, that a vehicle is under the care and control of the person or corporation to whom it is registered during the time such vehicle is parked in violation of this section. 
(Code 1972, § 11-25.1) 
State Law reference- Town authorized to regulate the standing or parking of vehicles, G.L. 1956, § 31-12-12. 
Sec. 16-142. - Overnight parking prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park a vehicle on any public street, public lot, town leased lot, the town common, or any restricted area overnight without a residential sticker as provided by article IX of this chapter. It shall be unlawful to park any vehicles, buses, trailers or trucks over a Class 3 GVWR on any public street or in any residential area overnight. Overnight is defined as a period of time from 12:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to park overnight any vehicle on the property located on the corner of Thames Street and Church Street, Assessor's Plat 10, Lot 32. 
(Code 1972, § 11-26; Ord. No. 1998-29, 10-28-98; Ord. No. 2006-12, 5-31-06; Ord. No. 2009-08, 7-15-09; Ord. No. 2018-09 , 6-13-18)

Sec. 16-144. - Parking prohibited on streets being cleaned. 
(a)  So as to make possible the cleaning of streets to the curbline without hindrance, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any public street in the compact part of town at the times specified in this section. 
(b)  This parking prohibition shall be effective during the months from May 1 through October 30 of each year within the compact part of town and on the dates specified for street cleaning. 
(c)  The compact part of town is that area bounded by Thames Street on the west; by Washington Street and Bayview Avenue on the north; by Metacom Avenue on the east and by Hope Street and Woodlawn Avenue on the south. 
(d)  The days and location during which this parking prohibition shall be in effect shall be based upon the following schedule, as limited by subsection (b) of this section: 
(1)  For all streets running east and west, no parking on the north side on the first day of each month and no parking on the south side on the 15th day of each month; and 
(2)  For all streets running north and south, no parking on the east side on the seventh day of each month and no parking on the west side on the 22nd day of each month. 
(e)  All streets regulated in this section shall be posted so as to notify motorists of this section. 
(f)  The penalty for violation of this section shall be $25.00 for each violation. 
(g)  The police department and all members thereof, in addition to issuing a parking violation ticket, are hereby authorized to remove and tow away, or have removed and towed away by a commercial towing service, any car or other vehicle illegally parked in violation of this section. Cars so towed away shall be stored in a safe place and shall be restored to the owner or operator of such vehicle upon payment of the parking fine and the charge for towing and storage. 
(h)  It shall be prima facie evidence that a vehicle is under the care and control of the person or corporation to whom it is registered during the time such vehicle is parked in violation of this section. 
(Code 1972, § 11-27.1)

Sec. 16-147. - Restricted parking on school days. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to park the vehicle in the following designated areas, on school days, so called, between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:30 p.m., unless otherwise specified herein. 
(1)  On the west side of Wood Street, in front of Elizabeth's auditorium, so called, between utility pole number 18 and utility pole number 20, between which there are approximately 60 feet. 
(2)  On the north side of Church Street, approximately 100 feet east of High Street, except for the purpose of the dropping off and picking up of students of the Byfield School. 
(3)  No parking/no standing zone from Sherry Avenue east to the eastern most portion of the bus circle and from the western curb of the cafeteria access driveway to Leila Jean Drive, and the entire length of the on the south side of Chestnut Street during school hours. 
(4)  No parking on Leila Jean Drive during school hours. 
(5)  At the intersection of Wardwell and Central Streets. 
(6)  On the north side of Chestnut Street between the eastern most portion of the bus circle and the western curb of the cafeteria access driveway except for the purpose of the dropping off and picking up of students of Mt. Hope High School. 
(7)  On the east side of High Street from its intersection at State Street, north 112 feet; between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(b)  The appropriate town department is hereby directed to erect signs consistent with the provisions of this section. 
(c)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to the sanctions contained in section 16-45. 
(Code 1972, § 11-28.1; Ord. No. 1998-25, 8-26-98; Ord. No. 1998-29, 10-28-98; Ord. No. 2002-27, 10-23-02; Ord. No. 2015-20, 10-21-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-20, adopted Oct. 21, 2015, set out provisions adding subsection 16-147(a)(5). To maintain existing subsections 16-147(a)(5) and (6), and at the editor's discretion, said provisions have been included herein as subsection 16-147(a)(7). 
Sec. 16-148. - Handicapped parking. 
(a)  No person, other than an ambulatory handicapped person as defined by RIGL 1956, § 31-28-7, shall park a vehicle in a parking space designated for the handicapped. All handicapped parking areas shall be designated by suitable and conspicuous signs and are tow-away zones. 
(b)  Handicapped parking restrictions adopted by the town council shall not be printed in this Code, but shall be kept on file in the town clerk's office. The town clerk shall maintain a list of all handicapped parking restrictions approved by the town council. 
(c)  All amendments to the list of handicapped parking restrictions shall be made by resolution of the town council; provided however, that no such resolution shall be adopted at the meeting at which it is introduced but shall, rather, be referred to a subsequent regular or special meeting at least seven days thereafter for a vote. 
(d)  All areas designated as handicapped parking spaces pursuant to this chapter as of the date of enactment of this section shall remain in full force and effect and be filed with the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1972, § 11-28.2; Ord. No. 1996-01, 1-24-96; Ord. No. 1997-16, 1-15-98; Ord. No. 1999-09, 4-21-99; Ord. No. 1999-10, 4-21-99; Ord. No. 2000-02, 1-26-00; Ord. No. 2000-13, 5-31-00; Ord. No. 2000-21, 8-2-00; Ord. No. 2000-29, 10-4-00; Ord. No. 2001-01, 1-24-01; Ord. No. 2001-21, 8-1-01; Ord. No. 2001-25, 10-3-01; Ord. No. 2001-30, 10-24-01; Ord. No. 2001-41, 1-2-02; Ord. No. 2002-02, 2-13-02; Ord. No. 2002-17, 8-21-02; Ord. No. 2003-02, 1-29-03; Ord. No. 2003-19, 10-8-03; Ord. No. 2003-20, 10-8-03; Ord. No. 2003-21, 10-8-03; Ord. No. 2003-26, 12-10-03; Ord. No. 2004-09, 4-21-04; Ord. No. 2004-14, 6-2-04; Ord. No. 2004-16, 6-23-04; Ord. No. 2004-19, 6-23-04; Ord. No. 2004-21, 6-23-04; Ord. No. 2004-22, 7-14-04; Ord. No. 2004-26, 8-4-04; Ord. No. 2004-30, 9-15-04; Ord. No. 2004-31, 9-15-04; Ord. No. 2004-39, 11-17-04; Ord. No. 2005-06, 3-16-05; Ord. No. 2005-13, 4-6-05; Ord. No. 2005-25, 7-20-05; Ord. No. 2005-27, 8-10-05; Ord. No. 2005-28, 8-10-05; Ord. No. 2005-33, 9-21-05; Ord. No. 2005-45, 11-30-05; Ord. No. 2005-47, 11-30-05; Ord. No. 2005-51, 12-14-05; Ord. No. 2006-02, 2-16-06; Ord. No. 2006-06, 3-29-06; Ord. No. 2006-18, 7-19-06; Ord. No. 2006-29, 9-13-06; Ord. No. 2007-02, 1-31-07; Ord. No. 2007-15, 4-11-07; Ord. No. 2007-17, 5-23-07) 
Sec. 16-149. - Parking time limited in designated places between 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
    No vehicle shall be parked on any of the following streets or portions thereof in excess of ten minutes between 8:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m.: 
    Franklin Street, north side, adjacent to Batista Bakery. 
    Franklin Street, north side, adjacent to Mt. Hope Liquor Store. 
    Wood Street, west side, adjacent to Viola's Liquor Store. 
(Code 1972, § 11-29; Ord. No. 2012-03, 6-27-12) 
Sec. 16-150. - Parking time limited in designated places between 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. 
    Parking shall be permitted between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m., on Sundays only, in the following areas where parking is otherwise prohibited during certain specified hours: 
    High Street, both sides, between Church Street and Franklin Street. 
    State Street, both sides, between Wood Street and Hope Street. 
    Wood Street, both sides, between Mt. Hope Avenue and Bayview Avenue. 
(Ord. No. 1998-19, 6-3-98; Ord. No. 2000-27, 9-13-00; Ord. No. 2012-03, 6-27-12; Ord. No. 2014-11, 1-7-15) 
Sec. 16-151. - Parking on Church Street and State Street Docks; violations and fines. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person not a resident of the town to park a motor vehicle or boat trailer or a combination thereof on that property located at the western extremity of State Street owned by the town and known as State Street Dock, or on that property west of the western edge of Church Street and known as Church Street Dock. 
(b)  Town residents are allowed to park motor vehicle and/or boat trailers on State Street Dock, and town residents are allowed to park motor vehicles on Church Street Dock; however, vehicles of residents may be towed, as described below, and subject to towing charges, unless a current and appropriate sticker is displayed. Such sticker is to be designed and issued annually by the town clerk. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle overnight on the State Street Dock with the exception of those parking boats, trailers and material pursuant to section 16-158 of this chapter. Overnight is defined as a period of time from 12:00 midnight to 5:00 a.m. 
(d)  Each person violating this section or any owner of a motor vehicle parked on State Street Dock or Church Street Dock in violation of this section shall be subject to a fine of $25.00. Each and every day shall constitute a new offense. In addition to a fine, the chief of police is authorized to have any unauthorized vehicle and/or boat trailer towed to a suitable place within the town. Any motor vehicle thus removed shall be released to the owner, operator or other person having charge thereof only after payment of towing and storage charges. 
(e)  The entrance to State Street Dock and Church Street Dock shall be posted to the effect that parking is restricted to residents only, sticker is required, and all others are subject to tow away at the owner's expense and/or a $25.00 fine. 
(Code 1972, § 11-29.2; Ord. No. 2000-10, 5-31-00; Ord. No. 2018-05 , 5-2-18) 
Sec. 16-152. - Curb loading zones. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pick up and loading of materials in any place marked as a curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. 
(b)  The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily at a place marked as a curb loading zone for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, the loading or unloading of passengers when stopping does not interfere with any motor vehicle used for the transportation of materials which is waiting to enter, or about to enter, such zone. 
(c)  The following curb loading zones are hereby established: 
(1)  St. Elizabeth Street, the corner of Wood Street on the South side, between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m., except Sundays and holidays. 
(2)  John Street, north side, adjacent to the driveway providing access to Plat 10, Lot 25 at 14 John Street between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., except Sundays and holidays. 
(Code 1972, § 11-30; Ord. No. 2001-17, 6-20-01; Ord. No. 2004-12, 5-12-04; Ord. No. 2008-33, 1-7-09; Ord. No. 2012-03, 6-27-12) 
Sec. 16-153. - Parking so as to obstruct passage of other vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator of a vehicle to place the same in any street so as to prevent or obstruct the passing of other vehicles, unless for a reasonable time when necessary, but not exceeding five minutes at a time. 
(Code 1972, § 11-31) 
Sec. 16-154. - Parking of vehicles for sale purposes. 
    No person shall park upon a street any vehicle for the purpose of sale. 
(Code 1972, § 11-32) 
Sec. 16-155. - Manner of parking vehicles generally. 
    Except where necessary, in case of an accident to a vehicle, or in obedience to traffic regulations or traffic signs or signals, the operator of a vehicle shall not park such vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway, headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within one foot of the edge of the roadway. 
(Code 1972, § 11-33) 
Sec. 16-156. - Restricted parking zones. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to park the vehicle for any one consecutive period of time longer than specified within or upon any streets or parts thereof designated as restricted parking zones. 
(Code 1972, § 11-34) 
Sec. 16-157. - Liability of vehicle owners for parking violations. 
    No person shall allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stand or park in any street or highway in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 11-35) 
Sec. 16-158. - Parking of boats and trailers. 
(a)  Except as otherwise permitted pursuant to section 16-151, it shall be unlawful to park any boat and/or trailer on any public street in a residential zone (as defined in chapter 28 as SR, SRR, SRR-2, LR, GR zones) or on any sidewalk. 
(b)  The parking or storing of boats, trailers and material for over three days at the Church Street and State Street dock parking areas as described in section 16-151 and the Independent Park parking areas is prohibited unless the harbormaster or police department has given prior written approval for a longer duration and such approval has been filed with the police department. 
(c)  The parking or storing of trailers on the property located on the corner of Thames Street and Church Street, Assessor's Plat 10 Lot 32, is prohibited. 
(d)  The police department and all members thereof, in addition to issuing a parking violation ticket, are hereby authorized to remove or tow away by a commercial towing or material removal service, any boat, trailer, or material illegally parked or stored in violation of this section. Any boat, trailer, or material towed or removed shall be stored in a safe place and shall be restored to the owner of such boat, trailer or material upon payment in full of any parking fine and the charge for towing or removal and storage. 
(Code 1972, § 11-35.1; Ord. No. 2009-09, 7-15-09) 
Sec. 16-159. - Parking at Independence Park. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle without a boat trailer attached thereto in those parking spaces located in Parking Area A at the northerly end of Independence Park. 
(b)  Each person violating this section shall be subject to a fine of $20.00. Each and every day shall constitute a new offense. The police chief is authorized to have any motor vehicle in violation of this section towed to a suitable place in town. Any motor vehicle thus removed shall be released to the owner, operator or other person having charge thereof only after payment of towing and storage charges. 
(Ord. No. 1998-24, 8-26-98) 
Secs. 16-160-16-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - JUNKED OR ABANDONED VEHICLES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 13; storage of junked vehicles, § 13-41; environment, ch. 10. 

Sec. 16-231. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dismantled, junked or abandoned vehicles means major parts thereof, including bodies, engines, transmissions, rear ends, etc. 
    Premises means public or private property, town streets and public highways. 
    Public property means property owned by the town or state property acquired by the town at tax sales and all streets and highways within the town, whether or not they are public highways. 
    Vehicle legally or physically incapable of being operated means one which has not been duly registered according to law or which lacks the equipment in good operating condition as required by law to enable it to be registered. 
(Code 1972, § 11-44) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 16-232. - License required for storage of inoperable vehicles. 
    No person shall deposit, store, keep or permit to be deposited, stored or kept in the open upon public or private property a dismantled, unserviceable, junked or abandoned vehicle, or one legally or physically incapable of being operated, unless a license for such storage has first been obtained from the proper authority. 
(Code 1972, § 11-45) 
Sec. 16-233. - Duty of owner to remove vehicle; removal of vehicles from streets; when vehicles deemed abandoned. 
(a)  The owner of any vehicle described in section 16-232 shall remove the vehicle within seven days after being ordered to do so in writing by the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises where such vehicle shall be found. If the owner of any such vehicle is not known or cannot readily be ascertained, notice to remove may be given by attaching such notice to such vehicle. The police, upon request therefor, shall assist in ascertaining the name and address of the owner of any such vehicle. 
(b)  If the owner of any such vehicle is also the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises, notice to remove as described in subsection (a) of this section shall be given by the police. 
(c)  If any such vehicle is on a town street or public highway, 48-hour notice to remove the vehicle shall be given by the police; provided, however, that if such vehicle constitutes a present hazard or unduly obstructs traffic ingress to or egress from private or public property, the vehicle may be removed by the police without any prior notice. 
(d)  An unregistered vehicle on premises not owned or occupied by the owner of such vehicle may be deemed to be abandoned. 
(Code 1972, § 11-46) 
Sec. 16-234. - Removal of vehicle by owner of premises or police department when owner of vehicle fails to do so. 
    Upon the failure of the owner to remove any vehicle described in section 16-232 within the time limited in section 16-233, the owner, lessee, occupant of the premises where such vehicle is located or the police division shall forthwith remove or cause such vehicle to be removed from the premises to a location to be provided for such purpose by the town. 
(Code 1972, § 11-47) 
Sec. 16-235. - Redemption of vehicles. 
    The owner of any vehicle removed pursuant to this article may regain possession thereof from the town by making application therefor within two months after its receipt by the city, upon paying to the town all reasonable costs of removal, which shall be repaid to the person who paid or incurred such charges, plus an additional charge of $75.00 per day or any portion thereof for storage charges of such vehicle while in possession of the town. 
(Code 1972, § 11-48; Ord. No. 2015-26, 1-6-16) 
Sec. 16-236. - Disposal of unredeemed vehicles; disposition of proceeds of sales. 
    If no claim for a vehicle removed pursuant to this article is made within two months after receipt thereof, the town may sell such vehicle for the best price obtainable as junk or otherwise, and the proceeds thereof shall be available to pay the reasonable charges of delivering the same to the town if a claim therefor is made by the person who paid such charges and the expense of keeping and disposing of such vehicle. Any balance shall be paid into the general fund of the town. 
(Code 1972, § 11-49) 
Sec. 16-237. - Owners of premises and town not liable for damage or loss of removed vehicles. 
    Neither the owner, lessee or occupant of the premises from which any vehicle shall be removed pursuant to this article, or his or its servant or agent, or the town, shall be liable for any loss or damage to such vehicle while being removed, or while in the possession of the town, or as a result of any subsequent sale or other disposition. 
(Code 1972, § 11-50) 
Sec. 16-238. - Failure to remove vehicles. 
    Any person required by the provisions of this article to remove any vehicle described in section 16-232 who shall fail so to do shall be guilty of an offense punishable in accordance with the provisions of section 1-7. 
(Code 1972, § 11-51) 
Secs. 16-239-16-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - VEHICLE USE AT HIGH SCHOOL 

Sec. 16-271. - Authority of school department and committee. 
    The town school department, which has authority over the building and grounds of the Bristol High School, is further empowered to regulate the vehicle use and vehicle parking on the grounds of the Bristol High School. Without limiting the generality of its power, the school committee may establish regulations from time to time, to, for example, limit vehicle speed, designate areas of no parking, designate areas of parking, restrict parking in certain areas as to time, type of vehicle or individual using a restricted parking area, and establish fire lanes wherein parking is prohibited at all times. 
(Code 1972, § 11-52) 
Sec. 16-272. - Committee to file rules with council and post notices. 
    The school committee shall file its vehicle regulations, as amended from time to time, with the town council. In addition, the school committee shall post appropriate notices designed to inform vehicle operators of area restrictions or prohibitions. 
(Code 1972, § 11-53) 
Sec. 16-273. - Enforcement of article. 
    It shall be a violation to use or park any vehicle contrary to regulations established by the school committee. The police department, under its authority to enforce this chapter, shall ticket vehicles violating this article and impose fines as set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 11-54) 
Sec. 16-274. - Vehicles parking in school fire lanes subject to additional fees. 
    If any vehicle violates this article by parking in a fire lane which is prohibited to parking, in addition to issuing a parking violation ticket and fine, the police department is authorized to remove and have towed away any such vehicle illegally parked. Vehicles so towed shall be stored in an appropriate place and returned to the owner or operator upon payment of the parking fine, plus charges for towing and storage. 
(Code 1972, § 11-55) 
Secs. 16-275-16-305. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 16-306. - Established. 
    The following town parking lots acquired and maintained for the parking of vehicles shall be known by the following designations: 
(1)  Patrons' Lot-Shortterm parking: That area on the south side of Court Street, between the Burnside and Town Hall buildings. 
(2)  Employees' Lot: That area on the south side of Court Street, abutting east of the Historical Society building. 
(3)  Patrons' Lot-Longterm: That area on the north side of Court Street. 
(Code 1972, § 11-61) 
Sec. 16-307. - Supervision. 
    The municipal parking lots shall be under the supervision of the town administrator, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1972, § 11-62) 
Sec. 16-308. - Use regulations. 
(a)  Except as provided in this section, within the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. on weekdays, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in any municipal parking lot in violation of any ordinance, or to so park contrary to the rules established by the town council or town administrator. 
(b)  During the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 4:30 p.m., the municipal parking lots shall be restricted to use as follows: 
(1)  The patrons' shortterm lot shall be used by any person vesting or otherwise having business within the town hall. Parking shall be limited to 30 minutes. 
(2)  The employees' lot shall be used by town employees as prescribed by the town administrator. 
(3)  The patrons' longterm lot will be used by any person vesting or otherwise having business within the town hall. Parking shall be limited to one hour. 
(4)  Except that the patrons' shortterm lot may be used by the town council, board officials or commission officials during evening hours when such council, board or commission is in meeting on town business. 
(Code 1972, § 11-63) 
Sec. 16-309. - Fines. 
    The fines for violation of this article shall be imposed as set forth in section 16-45. 
(Code 1972, § 11-64) 
Secs. 16-310-16-340. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - RESIDENTIAL PARKING 

Sec. 16-341. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Resident means any person who lives or resides in a structure approved for residential occupancy or up to two owners of such a structure located on a designated residential parking street. Only one sticker shall be issued to a resident or owner. 
    Residential parking street means a street or a portion thereof where 24-hour curbside parking is limited to vehicles properly displaying a residential parking permit authorized by this article. All other vehicles parking thereon remain subject to parking time restrictions as now and hereafter delineated in the ordinances of the town. Designated streets will be enumerated in this chapter, as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1972, § 11-71; Ord. No. 2000-27, 9-13-00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 16-342. - Penalties for violation of article. 
(a)  The parking of any vehicle in a manner contrary to the residential parking provisions established in this article shall be fined in accordance with this article and the parking violations schedule in section 16-45. Each day of a violation of this article shall be a separate offense. 
(b)  The use of any residential parking permit in a manner contrary to the provisions established in sections 16-341 through 16-352 is prohibited and the same is hereby declared to be unlawful. Whomever violates or fails to comply with any provision hereinbefore mentioned shall be fined not more than $100.00. 
(c)  In addition to those penalties dictated in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the director of public safety shall have the responsibility and authority to revoke the residential parking permit of any resident for the abuse of or use of a residential parking permit in a manner contrary to the provisions established in sections 16-341 through 16-352. Revocation of the residential parking permit or conviction of a violation shall be considered just cause for denial of future residential parking permit to such resident. 
(Code 1972, § 11-79; Ord. No. 2000-10, 5-31-00; Ord. No. 2017-13, 10-4-17) 
Sec. 16-343. - Residential parking zone. 
(a)  Residential parking streets shall be all streets and intersections within and bounded by on the west by Bristol Harbor, on the south by Constitution Street, on the north by Franklin Street, and on the east by High Street (excluding those portions of High Street situated north of Congregational Street and south of the town common). That portion of Thames Street between Franklin Street and Washington Street will be included in the residential parking zone. Ambrose Court, Ambrose Drive and Columban Drive will also be included in the residential parking zone. That portion of Burton Street, between Hope Street and High Street will also be included in the residential parking zone. Constitution Street, from High Street easterly to Wood Street, Cooke Street, High Street from Church Street southerly to Union Street, Hope Street from Union Street to Summer Street, Pearse Avenue, Pleasant Street, State Street from High Street to Wood Street, Union Street, William Street, and Wood Street from State Street southerly to Union Street shall also be included in the residential parking zone. 
(b)  Those streets included within the residential parking zone are limited to two-hour parking, with the exception of: 
(1)  The downtown parking zone which is limited to one hour; and 
(2)  The streets listed in section 16-345. 
(Code 1972, § 11-71.1; Ord. No. 1996-17, § 11-71.1, 9-5-96; Ord. No. 1998-09, 4-22-98; Ord. No. 2001-01, 1-24-01; Ord. No. 2005-29, 8-10-05; Ord. No. 2008-27, 11-12-08; Ord. No. 2010-09, 4-14-10; Ord. No. 2017-14, 10-4-17) 
Sec. 16-344. - Procedures for parking in a residential parking zone. 
(a)  Each violation in the zone will be considered a separate violation, and a vehicle parking in excess of six hours is liable to three citations and removal. 
(b)  All zones in the residential parking section shall be signed warning that it is a tow zone and that towing is strictly enforced. 
(c)  Method of display. Residential stickers shall be displayed in the left rear window of the vehicle. No police officer or traffic aid will be required to look in any other location on a vehicle for a sticker, before citation. If a sticker is displayed in any other fashion, the vehicle will be liable for citation. 
(d)  Residential stickers may be issued for nonresidents of the district who can show a special need if the nonresident has appeared before the town council and the town council has determined that a hardship exists necessitating the issuance of a resident sticker to the nonresident. 
(e)  No vehicle, truck, bus or trailer over a Class 3 GVWR shall be parked on any town street between the hours of 12:00 a.m. to 5:00 a.m. 
(f)  Any member of the fire and rescue department properly displaying an active firefighters or rescue members identification on a vehicle shall be allowed to park without violation in the general vicinity of the station to which they are assigned or are a member. 
(Code 1972, § 11-71.2; Ord. No. 2000-25, 8-23-00; Ord. No. 2001-12, 6-20-01; Ord. No. 2018-09 , 6-13-18) 
Sec. 16-345. - Designated residential parking streets. 
(a)  The following streets are designated as residential parking streets, daily, during the hours of five p.m. to seven a.m.: 
Bradford Street , from Hope Street to Central Street; 
Central Street , from Bradford Street to Wardwell Street; 
Church Street , from Hope Street to Wood Street; 
Constitution Street, from Bristol Harbor to High Street; 
Court Street , from Hope Street to High Street; 
High Street , from Church Street to Congregational Street; 
State Street , from Hope Street to High Street; 
Thames Street , from Franklin Street to Oliver Street; 
Wardwell Street , from Hope Street to Central Street. 
(b)  The following streets are designated as residential parking streets, daily, 24 hours. 
Bradford Street , from Thames Street to Hope Street; 
Bradford Street , from Central Street to High Street; 
Byfield Street ; 
Central Street , from Bradford Street northerly to dead end. 
Church Street, from Thames Street to Hope Street; 
Franklin Street, from Thames Street to High Street, except as set forth in subsection 16-146(4); 
John Street ; 
Milk Street ; 
State Street , from Thames Street to Hope Street; 
Thames Street , from Franklin Street southerly to dead end. 
Wally Street, south side from Hope Street west to the beach area. 
(c)  The following streets are designated as residential parking streets, no overnight parking except with resident sticker: 
Constitution Street, from High Street easterly to Wood Street, both sides; 
Cooke Street; 
High Street, from Church Street southerly to Union Street, both sides; 
Pearse Avenue; 
Pleasant Street; 
State Street, from High Street easterly to Wood Street, both sides; 
Union Street; 
William Street; 
Wood Street, from State Street southerly to Union Street, both sides. 
(Code 1972, § 11-72; Ord. No. 1998-09, 4-22-98; Ord. No. 2000-27, 9-13-00; Ord. No. 2002-16, 7-17-02; Ord. No. 2005-29, 8-10-05; Ord. No. 2010-16, 9-15-10; Ord. No. 2017-07, 7-5-17) 
Sec. 16-346. - Criterion. 
    No street shall be designated as a residential parking street unless the town council determines that such designation is reasonably necessary to achieve the objectives stated as follows: 
(1)  Reduce high traffic volumes in certain congested residential districts, and to encourage the use of public transportation and the use of public and private parking facilities. 
(2)  Protect certain residential districts from polluted air, excessive noise and from litter resulting from the entry, parking and egress or traffic in higher than desirable volumes. 
(3)  Protect the residents of certain residential districts from unreasonable burdens in gaining access to their residences. 
(4)  Preserve the character of such districts as predominantly residential districts. 
(5)  Promote traffic flow and the safety of children and other pedestrians in congested residential districts. 
(6)  Promote the peace, comfort, convenience and welfare of all town residents and visitors. 
(Code 1972, § 11-73) 
Sec. 16-347. - Posting of signs. 
(a)  Following the town council's decision to designate a residential parking street, parking signs shall be erected thereon. 
(b)  Such sign shall inform the vehicle operator that curbside parking on the street is subject to local parking restrictions, unless the vehicle displays a residential parking permit or a general visitor or temporary residential parking permit authorized by this article. Such sign will enumerate all applicable parking restrictions. 
(Code 1972, § 11-74) 
Sec. 16-348. - Issuance of permits. 
(a)  Any resident or property owner over the age of 16 and a licensed driver may apply for a residential parking permit by completing an application, prepared by the town administrator or his designee, which shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the vehicle owner; 
(2)  Name and address of the principal operator of the vehicle (licensee); 
(3)  Make, model, color and registration of the vehicle; and 
(4)  The name of all other licensed drivers within the same residence. 
The driver's license and vehicle registration shall be presented with the application. 
(b)  Whenever the town administrator or his designee shall find that the applicant qualifies for a residential parking permit under the provisions of this article, he shall issue one resident parking permit in the form of a sticker or some other method prescribed by the town council. 
(c)  The town administrator or his designee may issue one or more temporary residential parking permits for use by a bona fide visitor to a dwelling unit on a residential parking street. Application for such permits shall be made only by a resident of a dwelling unit on a residential parking street on such form as shall be prescribed by the director of public safety or his designee shall place a reasonable limit on the duration of such temporary permit, which time period shall not exceed one week. 
(d)  Any business owner may apply for a residential parking permit by completing an application, prepared by the town administrator or his designee which shall include the information required in paragraph (a) above and in addition each business owner shall provide proof of ownership in a business within the town. Each business owner shall be allowed one permit. 
(e)  All permit applications shall be handled administratively by the town administrator or his designee; provided, however, that any resident who is refused a residential parking permit by the town administrator may renew their request to the town council for additional consideration. In rendering a decision the town council shall give reasonable consideration to the request for a residential permit and the recommendations of the town administrator and the chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 11-75; Ord. No. 2000-28, 9-13-00) 
Sec. 16-349. - Renewal or transfer of permits. 
(a)  A holder of a valid permit from the previous year shall be entitled to a new residential parking permit for the current year upon submission of evidence to the director of public safety or his designee that the holder is still qualified for a residential parking permit. 
(b)  The holder of a valid residential parking permit shall receive a new residential parking permit for the purpose of transferring same to another qualifying vehicle upon surrender of the holder's existing residential parking permit and completion of a new application. 
(c)  Such permits shall be issued on a calendar year basis with new permits available in December of each year. 
(Code 1972, § 11-76) 
Sec. 16-350. - Use of permits. 
(a)  A parking permit shall not guarantee or reserve a parking space nor shall it excuse the observance of any traffic or parking regulation. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this article for the holder of a residential parking permit to use such permit when the permit holder no longer fulfills one or more of the applicable provisions of this article controlling the issuance of permits. 
(c)  It shall be a violation of this article for any person to represent, in any fashion, that a vehicle is entitled to a parking permit authorized by this article when it is not so entitled. The display of a parking permit on a vehicle not entitled to such permit shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(d)  It shall be a violation of this article for any person to duplicate or attempt to duplicate a residential parking permit or to display on any vehicle such a duplicate parking permit. 
(Code 1972, § 11-77) 
Sec. 16-351. - Special events. 
    Any resident on a residential parking street who sponsors a special function or event, which special function or event shall be limited to eight hours in duration, shall notify the town police department at least 24 hours in advance as to the address of the function, approximate duration of the function and an estimated number of vehicles to be present. 
(Code 1972, § 11-78) 
Sec. 16-352. - Handicapped parking. 
    Any parking lot that is open to the general public for the purpose of commercial shopping that has spaces for five or more cars, or any lot that services two or more business establishments is required to have handicapped spaces available with these spaces properly marked. The number of spaces required is to follow the formula listed as follows: 
5-25 cars-one space. 
26-50 cars-two spaces. 
51-150 cars-three spaces. 
151-300 cars-four spaces. 
Those shopping centers that have multiple stores with one large parking lot will have at least one handicapped space in front of entrance of each store. Responsibility for the signing of the spaces shall be on the owners of the property and shall be erected according to state regulations. 
(Code 1972, § 11-80) 
Secs. 16-353-16-375. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - HARBOR PARKING ZONE 

Sec. 16-376. - Established. 
    The harbor parking zone shall be limited to the westerly side of Thames Street within the limits set forth herein: 
(1)  On the north bounded by the Ever Ready Fire Station. 
(2)  On the south bounded by Constitution Street. 
    This area as it lies within the residential parking zone is to be considered a dual parking zone. Duly authorized parking permits for the harbor parking zone and/or the residential parking zone shall be honored in the aforementioned area. 
(Ord. No. 1998-09, 4-22-98) 
Sec. 16-377. - Issuance of permits. 
    The parking permits shall be issued by the office of the town clerk upon proof of current slip rental at the Rockwell or Church Street Docks. New permits must be obtained prior to Memorial Day of any given year. The harbor parking zone shall be in effect commencing Memorial Day of any given year and terminating Columbus Day of the same year. 
(Ord. No. 1998-09, 4-22-98) 
Sec. 16-378. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  The parking of any vehicle in a manner contrary to the harbor parking provisions established herein shall result in the imposition of a fine of ten dollars for each day of such violation. 
(b)  The use of any residential parking permit in a manner contrary to the provisions established within this article is prohibited. Whomever violates or fails to comply with such provisions shall be fined not more than $100.00. 
(c)  In addition to those penalties set forth above, the director of public safety shall have the responsibility and authority to revoke the harbor parking permit of any holder for the abuse of or use of a harbor parking permit in a manner contrary to the provisions established within this article. Revocation of the harbor parking permit or conviction of a violation shall be considered just cause for denial of future harbor parking permits to such individual. 
(Ord. No. 1998-09, 4-22-98) 
Secs. 16-379, 16-380. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - MOTORIZED TOY VEHICLES 

Sec. 16-381. - Motorized scooters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motorized device on any public sidewalk or street. For the purposes of this section, a "motorized scooter" means a device that is: (a) designed to allow operation while the operator is standing on the device; and (b) powered by an internal combustion engine that is capable of propelling the device and operator without human propulsion. 
    This section includes, but is not limited to, motorized scooters and similar toy vehicles. It specifically excludes: (a) registered motorized scooters designed for seated operation; (b) electric personal assistive mobility devices, including Segways; and (c) motorized wheelchairs. 
    Any person convicted of willfully violating this article shall be guilty of an offense punishable by a fine not to exceed $100.00 and/or a requirement to perform community service for a total time not to exceed 20 hours over a period not to exceed 30 days, during times other than his or her hours of school attendance and/or employment. Each violation of this section shall be a separate infraction. 
(Ord. No. 2004-25, 8-25-04) 
ARTICLE XII. - PRUDENCE FERRY DOCK PARKING 

Sec. 16-382. - Prudence Ferry Dock parking. 
    Fees for parking at the ferry dock shall be established by the town council for both a daily rate and an annual rate. The town council shall also establish fines for nonpayment of parking fees. 
(Ord. No. 2013-12, 8-28-13) 
ARTICLE XIII. - DAMAGE TO VEHICLES 

Sec. 16-383. - Damage caused by potholes-Claims against the town. 
    If any person shall incur damage to his or her motor vehicle by reason of a pothole on any town road, causeway, or bridge which damage would not have occurred without the existence of the pothole, he or she may recover from the town the amount of damages sustained up to and not more than the sum of $300.00 if the town was on previous notice of the pothole's existence. All claims shall be made within a period of seven days from the date on which the damage was sustained by filing a written report in a manner prescribed by the director of the department of public works. The report shall then be forwarded to the town council for referral to the insurance committee. 
(Ord. No. 2013-13, 8-28-13) 
Chapter 17 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 16; police, ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Criminal offenses, G.L. 1956, title 11. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Bathing in public places. 
    No person shall, in the daytime, bathe in any public place, or within one-eighth of a mile of any public highway or any street, unless properly clothed. 
(Code 1972, § 12-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to prevent the indecent exposure of persons bathing in the town's waters, G.L. 1956, § 45-6-1. 
Sec. 17-2. - Reserved. 
Sec. 17-3. - Consumption of alcoholic beverages or sleeping in public areas. 
    No person shall consume alcoholic beverages in any public area within the town. No person shall sleep in any public area of the town, except those places which provide sleeping accommodations for transient visitors. 
(Code 1972, § 12-3) 
Sec. 17-4. - False fire alarms. 
    No person shall make a false alarm or cry of fire. 
(Code 1972, § 12-6) 
Cross reference- Alarm systems, ch. 4; fire prevention and protection, ch. 12. 
State Law reference- False fire alarms, G.L. 1956, § 11-44-21. 
Sec. 17-5. - Firearms; discharge. 
    No person shall discharge any rifle, pistol, bomb or firearm of any kind whatsoever, except persons under military duty, and except in the lawful defense of his person or property. 
(Code 1972, § 12-7) 
Sec. 17-6. - Games; playing on common during school hours. 
    All persons are hereby forbidden to play baseball, football, soccer or any other game tending to disturb the public schools upon the west half of the public common during the session of the public schools located thereon. 
(Code 1972, § 12-8) 
Sec. 17-7. - Hunting prohibited; exception. 
(a)  No person shall hunt, pursue, take or kill any wild bird or animal, with firearms of any description, within the town, except as provided in this section. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not be operative so as to make it unlawful for a bona fide resident of the state, or his immediate family, to hunt, pursue, take or kill any wild bird or animal with firearms in the town on land owned by him, or on land leased by him and on which he is actually domiciled. 
(Code 1972, § 12-9) 
Cross reference- Animals generally, ch. 6. 
Sec. 17-8. - Laundries. 
    All public laundries, as defined in G.L. 1956, § 5-16-1, shall be required to comply with all pertinent provisions of G.L. 1956, § 5-16-1 et seq. 
Sec. 17-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1999-23, § I, adopted Dec. 15, 1999, repealed § 17-9, which pertained to loitering, obstructing access to public buildings, and prohibited acts, and derived from Code 1972, § 12-12. 
Sec. 17-9.1. - Loitering; prohibited acts; standards for enforcement. 
(a)  Definition. To "loiter" means to knowingly remain idle in one general location by either aimlessly walking, sitting, standing or lying about whether in or out of a motor vehicle. 
(b)  Actions prohibited. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter with the intent to commit a crime or other statute or ordinance violation. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or concern that such actions threaten public safety or a breach of the peace, as pursuant to subsection (d) below. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in a place, at a time, or in such a manner that impedes or tends to impede the passage of pedestrians or vehicles on a public street or sidewalk under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or concern that such impediments threaten public safety or a breach of the peace pursuant to subsection (d) below. 
(4)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to punish conduct which is constitutionally permissible. 
(c)  Condition precedent to arrest. Prior to any arrest or citation hereunder by a law enforcement officer, it shall be a requirement that the law enforcement officer shall have previously ordered the person to disperse and remove himself or herself from the area. 
(d)  Standards for enforcement. In determining whether actions, conduct or circumstances warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or concern that the public safety or a breach of the peace is threatened the following factors must be considered by the peace officer: 
(1)  The place of the activity or conduct and the usual activities which occur at the location. 
(2)  The time of day and duration of the activity or conduct. 
(3)  Whether the person's purpose is lawful or unlawful. 
(4)  Whether the activity or conduct creates an unreasonable risk of harm to persons or property. 
(5)  Whether the activity or conduct is intended to intimidate, annoy, disturb, delay or hinder passersby or persons residing or doing business in the vicinity. 
(6)  If on private property, whether the property owner, tenant, or their agent has posted a sign on the property stating "NO LOITERING" or other statement of similar meaning. 
(7)  Whether the person to be charged with loitering has been asked by the property owner, tenant, or their agent, or by a security officer to leave the property and whether that person failed to do so immediately and peaceably. 
(8)  Whether on other occasions the person to be charged with loitering has been asked by the property owner, tenant, or their agent, or by a security officer or law enforcement officer, to leave the property and whether or not they failed to do so immediately and peaceably. 
(9)  The nature of the activity or conduct complained of and whether it would otherwise be constitutionally protected. 
(e)  Penalty for violation . Any person found in violation of this section shall be fined up to $500.00 and/or voluntary community service for not more than 50 hours or any one offense. 
(Ord. No. 1999-23, § II, 12-15-99; Ord. No. 2017-13, 10-4-17) 
Sec. 17-9.2. - Disorderly conduct. 
(a)  A person commits disorderly conduct if he or she intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly: 
(1)  Act in an intimidating, violent or tumultuous manner toward another or others whereby any person is placed in fear of safety for his or her life, limb, health or well-being; 
(2)  Act in an intimidating, violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being damaged, mutilated, defaced or destroyed, or is, in fact, mutilated, damaged, defaced or destroyed; 
(3)  Behave in an intimidating, violent or forceful manner at any time in, upon or in the proximity of a public place in such a manner that such conduct constitutes a clear and present danger to the free and lawful movement of any person or to the extent that any other person will be, or is likely to be, restrained, enjoined, incapacitated or stopped in the lawful exercise of his or her business, occupation, amusement, recreation or any other lawful pursuit; 
(4)  Cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl or tumultuous or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health or well-being of another; 
(5)  Urinate or defecate on any public street, alley or sidewalk or the floor of any public place or public building or any place or building where the public has the right to gather or to which it has access, or any private property not owned by the party; 
(6)  By acts of violence, interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; 
(7)  Wilfully, knowingly, or recklessly make a false alarm or cry of fire or a false request for the assistance of any firefighting apparatus or personnel, or wilfully, knowingly, or recklessly make a false report or request for assistance of any public or private rescue or assistance services, or, similarly, make a false cry, alarm or request for police assistance; 
(8)  Prowl or wander in or upon the private property of another or, without good reason, or without visible or lawful business with the owner or occupant thereof, peek, peep or peer in any door or window of any building or structure thereon; 
(9)  Display any deadly weapon, or instrument or thing which by its appearance may be considered a deadly weapon, in any public place in a manner calculated or likely to alarm or frighten another or others; 
(b)  The foregoing prohibitions shall be applicable to all persons whether acting alone or in concert with others. 
(c)  In no event shall the subdivisions of this section be construed to prevent lawful picketing or lawful demonstrations. 
(d)  Whomever violates the foregoing provisions shall be fined not more than $100.00. 
(Ord. No. 2004-1, § I, 2-4-04; Ord. No. 2017-13, 10-4-17) 
State Law reference- R.I.G.L. §§ 11-11-1, 11-45-1. 
Sec. 17-9.3. - Underage possession and consumption of alcohol. 
(a)  Any person who has not reached his or her 21st birthday and has in his or her possession any alcoholic beverage as defined in RIGL, Title 3 shall be fined $300.00 to $750.00 for each offense. 
(b)  Any person who has not reached his or her 21st birthday and who has consumed an alcoholic beverage as defined in RIGL, Title 3 shall be fined $300.00 to $750.00 for each offense. 
(c)  This section does not apply to the consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages by a person who has not reached his or her 21st birthday if for religious purposes or if a parent or legal guardian has permitted the possession or consumption of the alcoholic beverage within the home of the parent or legal guardian or at other private places not in view of the public where the parent or legal guardian is present. 
(Ord. No. 2010-18, 9-29-10) 
Sec. 17-10. - Holiday sales. 
(a)  License required . Except for holders of class A liquor licenses, no store, shop or other place of business, trade or entertainment shall be open on any holiday, nor any article sold therein on that day, unless a license therefor is obtained from the town council. 
(b)  Issuance of licenses; terms and conditions . The following regulations set out in this section shall govern the issuance of holiday sales licenses in accordance with the provisions of state statutes, subject to such regulations and restrictions as the town council may from time to time make and prescribe: 
(1)  No application for a holiday sales license shall be in order for hearing by the town council unless the application has been filed with the town clerk and the fee for such holiday license paid prior to a council meeting. 
(2)  The annual fee for each of such holiday sales licenses shall be as set out in section 11-1. 
(3)  The town council may avail itself of the authority given it to suspend or revoke licenses, especially if the licensed premises attract noisy, disorderly or otherwise offensive people. 
(4)  The sale of commodities and articles at places other than as designated, will result in immediate suspension or revocation of such license. 
(5)  In granting any application for a license, the town council may impose such conditions as may be thought wise or useful for the protection of the peace and quiet of the particular holiday for which the license is sought, public convenience or advantage and benefit of the town, and may regulate hours of sale, rental and operation under such licenses, and all other matters connected with their use. 
(6)  Licenses issued under this section shall limit the hours during which the licensee may sell the commodities, articles or privileges therein. The normal hours on a particular holiday during which the licensee may be open for business shall be as set forth in state statutes, except that the town council reserves the right to further regulate the hours. 
(7)  The license shall always be upon the premises and shall be displayed in full view while such premises are open for business. 
(8)  Licensees, on holidays, shall not display their wares beyond the windows of their establishments. 
(9)  Licensees shall keep all kinds of fruit screened or otherwise protected against flies or other insects. 
(10)  Only ice, milk products, food products, and newspapers may be delivered or sold from carts or other vehicles, and a copy of the license shall accompany such vehicles during such deliveries. 
(11)  The town clerk shall establish and publish a deadline for filing a license application pursuant to this chapter. A late fee of $25.00 shall be imposed for failure to file on or before said deadline. 
(c)  Definitions. 
(1)  Holiday , whenever used in this chapter includes: New Years Day, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Victory Day, Labor Day, Columbus Day and Veteran's Day, or on any day which any enumerated holiday is officially celebrated, but does not include Thanksgiving or Christmas. 
(Code 1972, §§ 12-15, 12-16; Ord. No. 2004-44, 1-12-05; Ord. No. 2005-31, 9-21-05; Ord. No. 2005-53, 12-14-05; Ord. No. 2011-01, 5-4-11) 
Sec. 17-11. - Detective license. 
(a)  Submission to state and local record check. In conformity with the state statutes, the town council may license any person whose principal place of business is located in the town to act as a private detective throughout the state, for the detection, prevention, and punishment of crime, for the term of one year, unless sooner revoked for cause. Before issuance of a license, an applicant must submit to a state and local record check and be fingerprinted and submit to an FBI check. The results of these must be certified as satisfactory by the chief of police. 
(b)  Scope of license authority. Nothing in such license shall be construed to confer on a person so licensed any of the authority or power of sheriffs, deputy sheriffs, town sergeants, constables or police officers. 
(c)  Fee. The fee for such license shall be according to section 11-1. 
(d)  License number; ID.
