Every person licensed under this section shall be given a permanent license number and shall be issued an identification card which shall be approximately 21/2 inches wide and 31/2 inches long and shall bear thereon the number assigned to the licensee, the full name, date of birth, residence address, brief description of the licensee, his fingerprints and photograph and a space upon which the licensee shall write his usual signature with pen and ink. 
(e)  Cost of certificate. The cost of this license certificate shall be paid by the licensee in addition to the license fee. 
(Code 1972, § 12-17; Ord. No. 2008-10, 7-9-08) 
Sec. 17-12. - Compliance with building regulations. 
    No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business, and no permit shall be issued for any thing or act, if the premises and building to be used for that purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the Code. No such license or permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance of any act which violates the town's zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2000-20, 8-2-00) 
Sec. 17-13. - Delinquency of applicant for a license in payment of certain taxes. 
    All applicants who are delinquent to the town for fees or in the payment of real or personal property taxes must appear at the town council meeting held to consider their application for a license. All applicants for a town-issued license, including applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses, shall be denied such license unless arrangements satisfactory to the council are made for payment of such taxes and/or fees. 
(Ord. No. 2000-20, 8-2-00) 
Sec. 17-14. - Approval of licenses subject to tax payment, state approval. 
    The town council may approve the issuance of a license subject to the payment of delinquent taxes or the obtaining of any necessary license or permit from the state. 
(Ord. No. 2000-20, 8-2-00) 
Sec. 17-15. - Delinquency of license renewal payment. 
    All holders of any town-issued licenses, including holders of alcoholic beverage licenses, who are delinquent in payments due and owing to the town as of the date of renewal of said license shall be fined $100.00 for each and every day that the license is not issued following the renewal date due to lack of payment of taxes, fees, charges or any other payment owed to the town. The town clerk may, based on the prior history of the payee, require payment of delinquent taxes, fees, and charges to be made in cash, certified check or the equivalent. In the event that a payee makes payment of a license renewal fee or any other outstanding taxes, fees or charges by check and that check is returned unpaid for any reason, the town clerk in conjunction with the town administrator shall have the power to suspend the license. Once a license is suspended, the license holder must reapply to the town council for reinstatement of said license. 
(Ord. No. 2002-01, 2-13-02) 
Sec. 17-16. - Prohibition against business on Thanksgiving and Christmas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any store, shop or other place of business, trade or entertainment to be open for business on Thanksgiving and/or Christmas. 
(Ord. No. 2005-53, 12-14-05) 
Sec. 17-17. - Sunday sales. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any holder of a class A liquor license to be open on Sundays, or to sell any article therein on those days, unless a license therefor is obtained from the town council. 
(b)  Issuance of licenses; terms and conditions . The regulations set out in section 17-10 governing the issuance of holiday sales licenses shall also govern the issuance of Sunday sales licenses for holders of class A liquor licenses in accordance with the provisions of state statutes, subject to such regulations and restrictions as the town council may from time to time make and prescribe, and subject to the following condition: 
(1)  All Sunday sales licenses issued to holders of class A liquor licenses shall restrict the business thereby licensed to the hours of 12:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. 
(2)  Sunday sales licenses issued pursuant to this section shall not be effective for Christmas or New Year's Day. 
(Ord. No. 2005-53, 12-14-05) 
Secs. 17-18-17-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE ESTABLISHMENTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, G.L. 1956, title 3. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-51. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article shall be to promote temperance and the reasonable control of traffic in alcoholic beverages and protect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 1997-07, § 12.1-1, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 17-52. - Closing hour; penalties for violation of section. 
(a)  All establishments that serve alcoholic beverages at retail, unless otherwise specifically authorized, shall be closed no later than 1:15 a.m. All establishments that serve alcoholic beverages at retail, upon authorization from the town administrator, shall be closed on New Year's Eve, December 31, no later than 2:00 a.m. on January 1. The definition of the word "closed" shall mean that all doors of the establishment shall be closed to the general public, that all patrons shall be out, that there shall be no one in the establishment except the owner or, in his absence, any designee of the owner, and no more than five employees necessary to clean and restock. 
(b)  Anyone found guilty of violating this section shall pay a fine of $100.00 for each offense. In addition to fines, the town council shall have the authority to suspend the license of any licensee alleged to be violating this section. After a hearing, upon a finding that a licensee is deliberately or frequently violating this section, the town council, in addition to suspension or revocation of license and in addition to other remedies available at law, may, as a condition to retain a license, order the licensee to hire and maintain a special police officer to be on the premises, at appropriate times, to aid in implementing this section. Such order shall remain until further order of the council. 
(Code 1972, § 12-2.1; Ord. No. 1997-07, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 2009-3, 3-11-09) 
Sec. 17-53. - Service personnel training. 
(a)  At the time of renewal of all class A, B, BV and BVL liquor licenses all management and employee personnel involved with the service of alcohol at all liquor establishments within the town shall have taken and been certified as having completed an alcohol serving training program, administered by a certified agency or corporation. The town substance abuse prevention task force shall certify such agency or corporation and may sponsor the provision of training sessions. Persons currently so certified shall be required to maintain their certification. Any new employees or license holders shall be required to have completed such a course within six months of employment, license award or transfer. 
(b)  Failure of a license holder to provide evidence of completion of such a training program by its employees may result in the nonissuance or suspension of the license, until proof of certification is provided. An extension of time to allow for certification may be granted by the board of license commissioners for good cause. 
(Ord. No. 1997-06, § 12-2.3, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 1997-14, 10-1-97) 
Sec. 17-54. - Nudity on premises prohibited where alcoholic beverages are offered for sale or allowed to be brought onto the premises for consumption. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining, owning or operating a commercial establishment located within the town at which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises, or at which alcoholic beverages are allowed to be brought onto the premises for consumption, to suffer or permit any: 
(1)  Female person, while on the premises of the commercial establishment, to expose to the public view that area of the human breast at or below the areola thereof. 
(2)  Female person, while on the premises of the commercial establishment, to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate such portions of the human female breast as described in subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(3)  Person, while on the premises of the commercial establishment, to expose to public view his genitals, pubic area, anus or anal cleft or cleavage. 
(4)  Person, while on the premises of the commercial establishment, to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate the genitals, pubic area, anus, anal cleft or cleavage. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any female person, while on the premises of a commercial establishment located within the town, at which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises, or at which alcoholic beverages are allowed to be brought onto the premises for consumption, to expose to public view that area of the human female breast at or below the areola thereof, or to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance or simulate such areas of the female breast as described in this section. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while on the premises of a commercial establishment located within the town at which alcoholic beverages are offered for sale for consumption on the premises, or at which alcoholic beverages are allowed to be brought onto the premises for consumption, to expose to public view his genitals, pubic area, anus or anal cleft or cleavage, or to employ any device or covering which is intended to give the appearance of or simulate the genitals, pubic area, anus or anal cleft or cleavage. 
(d)  Any person who shall violate any provision of this section shall be guilty of an offense against the town punishable as provided by section 17-88. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall affect any licensing requirement of state law or the town ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1997-08, § 12-4, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 2001-14, 6-20-01; Ord. No. 2012-01, 2-1-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-01, adopted Feb. 1, 2012, amended § 17-54 title to read as herein set out. Formerly, § 17-54 pertained to nudity on premises where alcoholic beverages are offered for sale. 
Cross reference- Adult-only establishment, § 5-96. 
Secs. 17-55-17-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 17-81. - Required. 
    No person shall manufacture, sell, or suffer to be manufactured or sold or keep or suffer to be kept on his premises, in his possession or under his charge for the purpose of sale within the town unless licensed as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1997-07, § 12.1-3, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 17-82. - Number of licenses. 
    Alcoholic beverage licenses within the town shall be limited in quantity as follows: 
(1)  For class A, there shall be a maximum of four licenses; 
(2)  For class B limited, there shall be a maximum of four licenses; 
(2.5)  For class B-H, there shall be a maximum of one license; 
(3)  For class B-T, there shall be none; 
(4)  For B-V, there shall be a maximum of 28 licenses; 
a.  The establishment granted this license must close every day no later than 11:00 p.m. Any establishment that has a pre-existing license that allows a closing time later than 11:00 p.m., and wishes to maintain such later closing time, shall remain subject to all previous conditions, including without limitation, with regard to service of food during all of the time that alcohol is being served and also the limit of no more than six seats at any bar, and no seats at any "service bar." 
b.  The establishment granted this license must offer a full-service menu during all business hours, other than the last hour of opening per day, at which time food must be offered but may be a limited menu. "Full-service" menu shall mean food that is prepared and cooked, not just reheated, on the premises. Every establishment shall submit copies of both their full-service menu and limited menu, if any, at initial application and with each renewal application. The ratio of service of food to service of alcohol must be a minimum of 53 percent of food service by dollar sales, and every establishment shall submit an affidavit signed by the license holder attesting to and setting forth the actual ratio for the previous year, with each renewal application. Failure to maintain such ratio shall be grounds for reduction in bar seats, as set forth in subsection c. below. 
c.  The establishment granted this license shall submit a floor plan which shows the layout, including all tables, seats, bar seats, etc., where alcoholic beverages may be served. Patrons shall be able to order food at every seat in the establishment, including all bar seats. The licensing board shall determine the total number of bar seats, as part of the town's policy goal of maintaining restaurants, and neither bars nor nightclubs, under this class of license. 
d.  The establishment may maintain one or more "service bars" at the discretion of the licensing board. A "service bar" shall mean an area where food and/or alcoholic beverages are prepared but are "served" only to other staff members who then transport such food or drink to patrons. 
e.  Any existing licensed establishment that wishes to increase the number of its bar seats, and that will comply with all of the requirements of this subsection, may avail itself of such increase only with the consent of the license board at a duly noticed hearing, either as an amendment or upon transfer or renewal. 
f.  The council will review the licensee six months from the date of issuance. 
(5)  For class C, there shall be none; 
(6)  For class D, there shall be a maximum of seven licenses; 
(7)  For class D limited, there shall be none; and 
(8)  For class T, there shall be a maximum of one license. 
(Code 1972, § 12-2.2; Ord. No. 1997-05, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 1997-07, § 12.1-14, 7-16-97; Ord. No. 1998-06, 4-22-98; Ord. No. 1999-13, 5-12-99; Ord. No. 2001-13, 6-20-01; Ord. No. 2001-22, 8-22-01; Ord. No. 2004-04, 3-10-04; Ord. No. 2004-41, 1-12-05; Ord. No. 2005-01, 2-2-05; Ord. No. 2005-52, 12-14-05; Ord. No. 2005-55, 1-5-06; Ord. No. 2005-63, 2-7-06; Ord. No. 2006-24, 8-23-06; Ord. No. 2006-04, 10-25-06; Ord. No. 2007-03, 1-31-07; Ord. No. 2007-19, 6-13-07; Ord. No. 2007-39, 12-12-07; Ord. No. 2009-10, 8-5-09; Ord. No. 2010-04, 3-3-10; Ord. No. 2010-05, 3-3-10; Ord. No. 2010-21, 12-8-10; Ord. No. 2011-14, 9-28-11; Ord. No. 2011-15, 9-28-11; Ord. No. 2011-16, 9-28-11; Ord. No. 2013-14, 9-18-13; Ord. No. 2013-18, 12-4-13; Ord. No. 2015-01, 2-25-15; Ord. No. 2015-21, 11-4-15; Ord. No. 2016-04, 3-30-16; Ord. No. 2016-06, 5-4-16; Ord. No. 2016-16, 1-4-17; Ord. No. 2016-17, 1-25-17) 
Sec. 17-83. - Power of liquor license commissioners to issue licenses. 
    The right, power and jurisdiction to issue liquor licenses authorized by G.L. 1956, title 3 shall vest in the town council. In conformity with G.L. 1956, § 3-5-15 and for the purposes of this article and the issuance of such licenses, the town council is hereby constituted as the license commissioners, and the town clerk is hereby appointed and designated as clerk of the license commissioners. The town council, acting as the town's license commissioners, shall have the full power to hear all applications made for liquor licenses within the town and shall have the power to deny or grant such licenses pursuant to and in compliance with state General Laws and the rules and regulations of the liquor control administrator for the state. The town clerk, acting as the clerk of the license commissioners, shall have the responsibility to oversee the filing of liquor license applications and petitions to the town council and shall be responsible for notification and advertising in connection with such license applications, together with all other duties and responsibilities consistent with the laws of the state and the rules and regulations of the liquor control administrator for the state. 
(Ord. No. 1997-07, § 12.1-4, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 17-84. - Application; forms. 
    An application form must be obtained from the town clerk and must be fully completed and returned to the clerk, together with all application processing documentation and the required fee. 
(Ord. No. 1997-07, § 12.1-3, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 17-85. - Notice of application. 
    Notice of application must be given by regular mail in accordance with the state General Laws to all owners of property within 200 feet of the place of business seeking the application. The names and addresses of the abutters are to be submitted by the applicant to the town clerk with the application. The notice is to be given by the clerk on behalf of the board, and the cost thereof shall be paid by the applicant. The notice must state that remonstrants have a right to be heard and state the time and place of the hearing on the application. Written notice need not be given for temporary licenses. 
(Ord. No. 1997-07, § 12.1-5, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 17-86. - Fees; terms. 
    The fees for licenses under this article shall be set out in section 11-1. Such fees shall be assessed on an annual basis. Every license issued under this article shall specify the name and address of the person licensed, or if a corporation, the names and addresses of all stockholders and officers, the address where the show, exhibition or entertainment will take place and the hours, and the expiration date of the license. The term for a license under this article shall not exceed one year and shall begin on December 1. 
(Ord. No. 1997-07, § 12.1-9, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 17-87. - Compliance with other laws. 
    Every applicant for a license under this article shall comply with all laws of the state and all other ordinances of the town. 
(Ord. No. 1997-07, § 12.1-10, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 17-88. - Revocation or suspension. 
(a)  All licenses granted under this chapter may be revoked at the sole discretion of the town council. Sufficient cause to refuse further licenses under this article and to suspend or revoke any licenses issued under this article or deny renewal of a license originally issued under this article shall include but is not limited to the failure of the licensee to strictly comply with the provisions of this article and the laws of the state and of any terms and conditions imposed by the town council on the licensee. Upon denial, suspension or revocation of such license, the licensee shall be ineligible to reapply for a license for a period of two years from such denial, suspension or revocation. 
(b)  Prior to the revocation or suspension of a license, the board of license commissioners shall send notice by mail to the licensee and give the licensee the opportunity to show cause why the license should not be suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 1997-07, §§ 12.1-11, 12.1-15, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 17-89. - Operation without license. 
    In addition to any action pursuant to section 17-88, any person who maintains, operates or conducts any alcoholic beverage establishment within the town without first obtaining a license from the town council, or in any location other than that specified in the license, and any licensee in violation of this article shall be fined pursuant to section 11-1 for each offense. Each day of operation shall constitute a separate offense under this section. 
(Ord. No. 1997-07, § 12.1-23, 7-16-97) 
Sec. 17-90. - Condition of license-Bristol eliminates alcohol sales to youth notices. 
    Every license issued pursuant to this article shall be conditioned upon the continuous display of a conspicuous notice, supplied by the chief of police, warning underage drinkers of police efforts to eliminate alcohol sales to underage purchasers. Such notice shall be displayed, at a height from the floor of 41/2 feet on center, in a conspicuous area, at every point of public ingress to the establishment. This requirement shall apply to all licenses, including those obtained prior to the adoption of this section; provided, that every existing licensee shall post such notice within 30 days of the adoption of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2000-04, 1-26-00) 
Sec. 17-91. - Condition of license operations, July 3-5. 
    Every license issued pursuant to this article shall be conditioned upon the chief of police having the authority pursuant to the provisions adopted by the town council to determine whether and to what extent additional police protection may be reasonably necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public by allowing the licensee to remain open for business during the holiday period of July 3 through July 5. Payment for all police officers assigned by the chief of police shall be the responsibility of the licensee and shall be paid within 30 days of issuance of the invoice. Failure to pay the invoice within thirty 30 days shall result in the imposition of a $100.00 late fee penalty. 
(Ord. No. 2001-26, 10-24-01; Ord. No. 2009-16, 1-6-10) 
Sec. 17-92. - Revocation of granted or renewed license (not issued)-Retail. 
    A retail alcoholic beverage license may be granted or renewed, but not issued, pending full compliance with conditions and criteria necessary for the issuance of said license. The applicant shall have no more than one year after the original granting or renewal of the license to meet all conditions and criteria set forth in the granting or renewal order. If the applicant does not meet all conditions and criteria within one year, the license shall become null and void without further hearing by the town council; provided however, said time period shall not be calculated when the license at issue is involved in litigation, from the date of the commencement of the action to final disposition. 
(Ord. No. 2005-10, 3-16-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2005-10, adopted March 16, 2005, set out provisions intended for use as 17-89. For purposes of classification and to preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as 17-92. 
Sec. 17-93. - Reversion of licenses. 
    All licenses described in article II of this chapter that are issued subsequent to the effective date of this section shall revert back to the town when the license holder no longer seeks to renew the annual license. 
(Ord. No. 2011-17, 9-28-11) 
Secs. 17-94-17-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - UNRULY GATHERINGS 

Sec. 17-100. - Public nuisance. 
(a)  It shall be a public nuisance to conduct a gathering of five or more persons on any private property in a manner which constitutes a substantial disturbance of the quiet enjoyment of private or public property in a significant segment of a neighborhood, as a result of conduct constituting a violation of law. Illustrative of such unlawful conduct is excessive noise or traffic, obstruction of public streets by crowds or vehicles, illegal parking, public drunkenness, public urination, the service of alcohol to minors, fights, disturbances of the peace, and litter. 
(b)  A gathering constituting a public nuisance may be abated by all reasonable means including, but not limited to, an order requiring the gathering to be disbanded and citation and/or arrest of any law violators under any applicable ordinances and state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13 , 8-1-18) 
Sec. 17-101. - Notice of unruly gathering; effective periods. 
(a)  When the police department intervenes at a gathering which constitutes a nuisance under this article, the premises at which such nuisance occurred shall be furnished with a notice stating that the intervention of the police has been necessitated as a result of a public nuisance under this article caused by an event at the premises, the date of the police intervention, and that any subsequent event within the period set forth below on the same premises, which necessitates police intervention, shall result in the joint and several liability of any guests causing the public nuisance, or any persons who own or are residents of the property at which the public nuisance occurred, or who sponsored the event constituting the public nuisance as more fully set forth below. 
(b)  Any notice issued between September 1 and May 31 of any year shall remain in effect until May 31. Any notice issued between June 1 and August 31 of any year shall remain in effect until August 31. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13 , 8-1-18) 
Sec. 17-102. - Mailing of notice to property owner and occupants. 
(a)  Notice of the intervention shall also be mailed to any property owner on the Town of Bristol property tax assessment records and the occupants of the premises and shall advise the property owner and the occupants that any subsequent intervention within the effective periods set forth in section 17-101(b) on the same premises shall result in liability of the property owner and of the occupants for all penalties associated with such intervention as more particularly set forth below. 
(b)  Additionally, notice may be provided to an agent of the owner who controls or regulates the use of the premises, if known. Notice to the owner's agent may be provided by hand delivery or by certified or regular mail sent to the agent's last known address. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13 , 8-1-18) 
Sec. 17-103. - Persons liable for a subsequent response to a gathering constituting a public nuisance. 
(a)  If the police department is required to respond to a gathering constituting a public nuisance on the premises more than once in any effective period set forth in section 17-101(b), the following persons shall be jointly and severally liable for fines as set forth in section 17-104(a): 
(1)  The person or persons who own the property where the gathering constituting the public nuisance took place, provided that notice has been mailed to the owner of the property as set forth herein and the gathering occurs at least two weeks after the mailing of such notice. 
(2)  The person or persons residing on or otherwise in control of the property where such gathering took place. 
(3)  The person or persons who organized or sponsored such gathering. 
(4)  All persons attending such gatherings who engage in any activity resulting in the public nuisance. 
(5)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to impose liability on the resident or owners of the premises or sponsor of the gathering, for the conduct of persons who are present without the express or implied consent of the resident or sponsor, as long as the resident and sponsor have taken all steps reasonably necessary to exclude such uninvited participants from the premises, including landlords who are actively attempting to evict a tenant from the premises. 
(b)  Where a person present with the express or implied consent of the resident or person in charge of the residential unit or the organizer or sponsor engages in conduct which the sponsor or resident or organizer could not reasonably foresee and the conduct is an isolated instance of a person at the event violating the law which the sponsor or resident or organizer is unable to reasonably control without the intervention of the police, the unlawful conduct of the individual shall not be attributable to the sponsor or resident or organizer for the purposes of determining whether the event constitutes a public nuisance under this section. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13 , 8-1-18) 
Sec. 17-104. - Penalties for violation. 
(a)  It shall be a Code violation punishable by a $500.00 fine when intervention at the same location to abate a gathering constituting a public nuisance occurs within any effective period set forth in section 17-101(b) after the property was notified in accordance with section 17-101(a). 
(1)  The violation of this article is punishable by a $500.00 fine against each responsible person, as set forth in section 17-103(a)(1)-(4), including each lessee of the property who was present at the gathering. 
(2)  The person(s) who own the property where the unruly gathering took place will be assessed a $500.00 fine, provided proper notice of a prior violation at the property was provided to the owner pursuant to section 17-102 of this article and the gathering occurs at least two weeks after the mailing of such notice. 
(b)  In addition to the above, the municipal court shall be authorized to order the person or persons in violation to perform community service. For a first intervention, ordering community service shall be discretionary. For a second or third intervention, the municipal court shall, in addition to the monetary penalty set forth above, order the person or persons in violation to perform not less than 25 hours of community service for a second intervention and not less than 50 hours of community service for a third intervention. 
(c)  In addition to the above, the Roger Williams University Dean of Students Office will be notified of any Roger Williams University student in violation of an unruly gathering. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13 , 8-1-18) 
Sec. 17-105. - Right to contest notice of unruly gathering. 
(a)  An owner, occupant, or tenant of the cited premises may contest the issuance of the notice by filing a written petition for review with the town administrator requesting that the town administrator determine whether justification existed for issuing the notice under the provisions of this ordinance. The petition must be filed within ten days after the issuance of the notice or, if the notice is given by mail, within 15 days after the date of the mailing of the notice, and not thereafter. 
(b)  The town administrator shall set a time and date for a hearing to be held no later than 30 days after receipt of the written petition and shall notify the petitioner and the solicitor's office of the hearing date. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13 , 8-1-18) 
Chapter 18 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Boats, docks and waterways, ch. 8; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 25; environment, ch. 10. 
State Law reference- Parks and recreational areas, G.L. 1956, title 32; municipal regulation of parks, G.L. 1956, § 32-3-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Purpose and applicability of article. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to provide rules and regulations for the use of and conduct in the parks and recreation areas of the town. 
(b)  Applicability. This article shall apply to all parks and recreation areas under the jurisdiction of the town unless expressly exempted. For the approval of and issuance of facility use permits, temporary designations, authorizations, granting of approvals and other actions, the approving governing agency shall be the parks and recreation department. 
(Code 1972, § 13-1; Ord. No. 2008-08, 6-18-08; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11) 
Sec. 18-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animals means cats, dogs, horses, any fowl or birds and any living creatures within the jurisdiction of the park or recreation area. 
    Approving governing agency means the parks and recreation department. 
    Director means the director of parks and recreation. In the absence of such employee or a vacancy in the position, the assistant director shall serve as director and in the absence of both, the town administrator shall serve as director. 
    Memorial parks means Bristol War Veterans Honor Roll Garden, Veterans Memorial Park, and Firefighters Memorial Park. 
    Park attendant means any person employed by the Town of Bristol assigned to perform duties or tasks within the park and recreation areas under the direction of the director. 
    Path means any footpath, walkway or other path maintained for pedestrian use. 
    Permit means any written license authorizing an event or activity on park facilities issued by the approving government agency. 
    Personal assistance animal means a dog that has been or is being trained as a guide dog, hearing dog or service dog. 
    Service dog means a dog that has been or is being trained to aid a particular disabled person with a disability other than sight or hearing. 
    Vehicle means any conveyance (except a baby carriage) including motor vehicles, trailers of all types, campers, tricycles, bicycles (motorized or not), sleds, sleighs, pushcarts or vehicles propelled by other than muscular power. Vehicle does not include motor vehicles owned and operated by the town or its agents or employees for purposes of maintenance and enforcement of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 13-2; Ord. No. 2008-08, 6-18-08; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11; Ord. No. 2013-06, 3-27-13; Ord. No. 2017-09, 7-26-17; Ord. No. 2017-12, 9-13-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-3. - Enforcement of article. 
    The town police department and parks and recreation department employees shall, in connection with their duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this chapter. The town police department and parks and recreation department employees shall have the authority to order any person or persons acting in violation of this article to leave the park or recreation area. 
(Code 1972, § 13-8(c) ; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11) 
Sec. 18-4. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $5.00 and not more than $100.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Code 1972, § 13-8(d)) 
Sec. 18-5. - Permits. 
(a)  Required; exemptions. All public meetings, entertainment, tournaments, discussions, orations, nondenominational or interdenominational services or meetings of like kind shall be prohibited except upon written permission from the director. Such permittees shall be bound by the restrictions contained in said permit and by these rules and regulations. The use of any sound amplifying equipment shall also be prohibited except upon issuance of a permit. No person shall interfere with the activities lawfully carried on by such permittees. The parks and recreation department, subject to approval by the town council, may include in such permit those regulations it may, in its discretion, deem advisable in the public interest. Activities sponsored by the parks and recreation department and/or the town council are specifically exempted from permit regulations. 
(b)  Application procedure. Permits shall be obtained by application to the parks and recreation department or their designee in accordance with the following procedure: 
(1)  A person seeking issuance of a permit under this section shall file an application 45 days prior to the proposed activity or use, stating: 
a.  The name and address of the applicant. 
b.  The name and address of the persons, corporation or association sponsoring the activity, if any. 
c.  The day and hours for which the permit is desired. 
d.  The park or portion thereof for which the permit is desired. 
e.  Any other information reasonably necessary to a determination as to whether a permit should be issued under this section. 
f.  Variances required from park rules and regulations. 
g.  Standards for issuance of a permit shall include the following findings: 
1.  The proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public's enjoyment of the park. 
2.  The proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation. 
3.  The proposed activity or uses that are reasonably anticipated will not include violence, crime or disorderly conduct. 
4.  The proposed activity will not entail extraordinary or burdensome expense of police operation by the town. 
5.  The facilities desired have not been reserved for other use on the date and hour requested in the application. 
(2)  Any permit application not filed within the specified time period may be granted or denied at the discretion of the director. Persons seeking a permit in this manner shall illustrate that it was impossible to file in accordance with subsection (b)(1) of this section and that an emergency exists. Such applicants waive all rights to appeal as stated in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Appeal. Within 30 days after the receipt of an application, the director shall tell an applicant in writing of its decision to grant or deny a permit. In the event of a denial, the notification shall include the reason for the denial. Any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal to the town council by serving written notice on the town clerk within five working days of the refusal. The town council shall decide at its next regularly scheduled meeting after receipt of the appeal by the town clerk. The decision of the town council will be final. 
(d)  Applicant bound by park rules and applicable ordinances. A permittee shall be bound by all park rules and regulations and all applicable ordinances fully as though the same were inserted in the permits. 
(e)  Insurance requirements. An applicant for a permit may be required to submit evidence of liability insurance covering injuries to members of the general public arising out of such permitted activities in such amounts as may be, from time to time, determined by the director or his/her designee prior to the commencement of any activity or issuance of any permit. 
(f)  Revocation. The director or his/her designee shall have the authority to revoke a permit upon a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance or upon good cause shown. 
(Code 1972, § 13-3; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11) 
Sec. 18-6. - Fees and charges for park and recreation facilities. 
(a)  Payment required; exception. The charges provided in this chapter are for the activity and park facilities described in this chapter. Nothing in this chapter will be interpreted as modifying or repealing any charges provided by ordinance for other specific facilities such as harbor facilities, etc. No person shall use any park or recreation facility for which a fee is specified in this chapter without paying the fee unless such person has a currently valid pass issued as provided in this chapter. 
(b)  Schedule. The fee schedule will be set by the director with approval from the town administrator and town council. Fee schedules will be available through the parks and recreation department. These fees are for maintenance, electricity, parking and police/security considerations. 
(1)  Fifty dollars security deposit shall be charged which will be refunded in whole or in part after cost of damages, etc., have been deducted from the deposit. If the damage exceeds the security deposit, the person responsible for the damage will be barred by the director from using recreation facilities until full restitution is made. 
(2)  In the event of cancellation the recreation department shall be notified in writing 30 days prior to the reserved date. Failure to do so will result in forfeiture of the security deposit. 
(c)  Group activities for children. For all other group activities for children, including day camps and story hours, the charges will be as follows: 
(1)  Where the park and recreation department provides paid leadership, the department has the authority to waive fees or set a reasonable fee. 
(2)  Where leadership is provided by volunteer donated time, or by any other person or agency other than the parks and recreation department, fees may be waived. 
(d)  Beach parking. Vehicles parking at the town beach shall be charged a fee based on a seasonal fee schedule recommended by the parks and recreation department and approved by the town council. 
(e)  Application for food vendor license. Each person desiring to apply for a license as a vendor to sell food in any park or playground shall file an application therefor with the town council. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location where the applicant proposes to sell food. 
(3)  The types of food proposed to be sold. 
(4)  A description of any buildings or equipment, owned by the town desired to be used by the vendor. 
(5)  The equipment which the vendor plans to use, including not only food preparation and food servicing equipment, but also any cart or building proposed to be used in the operation. 
(6)  The prices proposed to be charged for the various items of food. Any person receiving a vending license under this article shall not change any part of the operation described in the application, including equipment, food to be served or prices, without applying for approval of the change and receiving approval of the change. Each vendor shall pay a fee of $25.00 per day for weekdays and $50.00 per day for weekends and holidays. Licenses to vendors shall be issued by vote of the town council. Each license to each vendor shall be issued for the specific days and places stated in the license. 
(7)  A police background check. 
(Code 1972, § 13-4; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11) 
Sec. 18-7. - Prohibited acts constituting violations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a public park or recreation area to: 
(1)  Mark, deface, disfigure, injure, destroy, damage, tamper with or displace or remove any buildings, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, pavings or paving materials, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof; signs, notices or placards (whether temporary or permanent); monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers; or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property, or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(2)  Damage, cut, carve, mark, transplant or remove any plant, or injure the bark, or pick flowers or seeds of any tree or plant, dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any way injure the natural beauty or usefulness of any area. 
(3)  Climb any tree, walk, climb, stand or sit upon monuments, vases, planters, fountains, railings, fences or upon any other property not designated or customarily used for such purpose. 
(4)  Throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any fountains, pond, lake, stream, storm sewer, or drain flowing into such water, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of such waters. 
(5)  Take into, carry through, put into any park or leave at any park, other than in receptacles provided therefor, any rubbish, refuse, garbage or other material. 
(6)  Tie or hitch an animal to any tree or plant. 
(7)  Ride a horse except on designated bridle trails; horses shall be thoroughly broken and properly restrained, and ridden with due care, and shall not be allowed to graze or go unattended. 
(8)  Cause or permit any animal to run loose, or walk a domestic animal without a leash. Further, the owner or person having custody of such domestic animal shall be responsible for the removal of any animal solid waste. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, it shall be unlawful for any person to permit, keep or otherwise cause a dog to enter upon and/or remain on any of the sports fields, playgrounds and memorial parks within the town, on any day, 24 hours per day, and the town beach and sports complex from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. from Memorial Day through Labor Day and during any town sponsored concert at Independence Park. 
(9)  Park a vehicle anywhere except on a designated parking area. 
(10)  Leave a vehicle standing or parked in established parking areas or elsewhere in the park and recreation areas during hours when the park and recreation areas are closed. Any such vehicle in the park or recreation area during hours when the area is closed shall be towed at the expense of the owner. 
(11)  Leave a bicycle in a place other than a bicycle rack when such is provided and there is space available. 
(12)  Use the parks, park drives, parking places or parkways for the purpose of demonstrating any vehicles, or for the purpose of instructing another to drive or operate any vehicle, nor shall any person use any park area, including parking places, for the repairing or cleaning of any vehicle, except in an emergency. 
(13)  Bring into or have in his possession in any park or recreation area: 
a.  Any pistol or revolver or objects upon which loaded or blank cartridges may be used. Official starts, at authorized track and field events, are excepted from this restriction. 
b.  Any burglar tools. 
c.  Any rifle, shotgun, BB gun, air gun, spring gun, slingshot, bow or other weapon in which the propelling force is gunpowder, a spring or air. 
d.  Have in his possession or set off any fireworks. Permits may be given for conducting properly supervised fireworks in designated park areas. 
(14)  No person shall engage in activity enumerated or described in section 18-5, without a permit, or activities enumerated in section 18-6 without a license, provided that no permit or license shall be required for any activity or event sponsored by the town council or the parks and recreation department. 
(15)  Display any advertising signs or other advertising matter, provided that a sign attached to a vehicle to identify the vehicle, or a sign lawfully on a taxi or bus, is not prohibited. 
(16)  Interfere with or in any manner hinder any employee of the parks and recreation department in the performance of his duties. 
(17)  Offer for sale any article in any park or recreation area, without a license specifically stipulating their right to sell and designating the specific park or area. 
(18)  Kindle, build, maintain, or use a fire except in places provided for such purposes. Any fire shall be continuously under the care and direction of a competent person from the time it is kindled until it is extinguished. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, charcoal fires are prohibited at the Bristol Town Beach. 
(19)  Bring alcoholic beverages other than as may be specifically permitted under article IV, or controlled dangerous substances, drink, or use the same at any time nor shall any person be under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled dangerous substance in a park or recreation area. 
(20)  Solicit alms or contributions for any purpose, whether public or private. 
(21)  Play any game of chance or have possession of any instrument or device for gambling. 
(22)  Take part in the playing of any games or activities except in those areas and at times designated for such forms of recreation. 
(23)  Fail to produce and exhibit any permit he claims to have, upon request of any authorized person who shall desire to inspect the permit for the purpose of enforcing compliance with any ordinance or rule. 
(24)  Any person desiring to use any kind of boat in the park shall abide by the statutes or ordinances relating to boating in public places. All boats shall keep out of the swimming area. 
(25)  Play golf on town fields or hit golf balls in, into or from any park or recreation facility. 
(26)  All swimmers and beachgoers shall obey and abide by the directions of the designated lifeguards and/or the parks and recreation staff members. No floats, rubber tubes, masks, fins or balls are allowed in the beach area. 
(27)  No person shall ride or drive motor vehicles including snowmobiles over or upon any turfed portion of any park, or land owned or controlled by the Town of Bristol, and no person shall ride or drive such motor vehicles over or upon any such areas. 
(28)  Closing hours. No person shall be in any town park during the hours that a park is closed. All town parks shall be closed from sunset to 6:00 a.m., unless the director has agreed that a park can remain open at other times. This subsection includes the following parks: 
Cedar Crest Playground Fatima Drive Sowams Playground Sowams Drive Coelho Playground Hopeworth Avenue Veterans Memorial Park Playground Wood Street Rockwell Park Thames Street Independence Park Thames Street Bristol Town Beach and Sports Complex Asylum Road American Legion Memorial Square State Street Thomas Park Hope Street Union Street Beach Hope Street Walley Beach Hope Street Firefighters Memorial Park Thames Street Manny Sousa Park Thames Street Mt. Hope Boat Launch Annawamscutt Drive Paull Park Sherry Avenue Narrows Beach Narrows Road Veterans Memorial Garden Hope Street Bristol Town Common High Street  
(Code 1972, § 13-5; Ord. No. 1996-12, 7-17-96; Ord. No. 1998-31, 1-6-99; Ord. No. 2004-42, 12-29-04; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11; Ord. No. 2013-06, 3-27-13; Ord. No. 2016-03, 5-4-16; Ord. No. 2017-09, 7-26-17; Ord. No. 2017-12, 9-13-17) 
Sec. 18-8. - Park classification and maintenance. 
(a)  Classification. All parks in the town are hereby classified, for the purpose of maintenance, as follows: 
(1)  The following are class A parks: Bristol Town Beach. 
(2)  The following are class B parks: All others. 
(b)  Maintenance. The following maintenance service shall be provided: 
(1)  Class A park maintenance. Class A park maintenance shall be as follows: 
a.  Well landscaped with trees and shrubs. A considerable amount of manual labor will be needed for proper maintenance. 
b.  Well developed grass will require maintenance which will supply the quality that is desired both aesthetically and for the support of the recreation program. 
c.  Extensive development of park facilities. Recreation buildings, tennis courts, swimming areas, multiuse courts and picnic shelters will be maintained. 
d.  Often, a permanent job station for park caretakers during the growing season may be established. 
e.  Regular and intensive litter control will be provided. 
f.  Regular tree maintenance will be provided. 
g.  Lawns will be mowed regularly. 
h.  Watering or irrigation will be provided for grass, shrubs and plants as required by weather conditions, subject to curtailment during any period of water shortage. 
(2)  Class B park maintenance. Class B park maintenance shall be as follows: 
a.  Regular litter control will be provided. 
b.  Nature areas, green belts, wild flower areas and tree growth areas will be established and maintained. 
c.  Strategic areas along roads and parking areas will be mowed occasionally. 
(Code 1972, § 13-6) 
Sec. 18-9. - Funds management. 
(a)  The director or his/her designee shall be responsible for the collection of and accounting of all fees/income generated at the town beach. These funds will be deposited with the town treasurer at least weekly during the time that the town beach is open. The town treasurer will deposit funds, subsequently, into the general fund. A receipt will be rendered to the parks and recreation department and the funds earmarked by the town treasurer. An internal accounting system will be instituted by the director to act as its internal check as to the funds so earmarked. 
(b)  The director may petition the town council through the town administrator to utilize these funds to supplement its operating or capital budget when an important need arises. It will be the task of the director to prepare the necessary backup documentation and to defend its need for these funds to the town council. The town council's action, if any, will be final. The town council may, with majority vote of its members, approve the need identified by the director and fund the need utilizing these earmarked funds from the general fund or any other town fund the council has at its discretion. 
(Code 1972, § 13-7; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11) 
Sec. 18-10. - Emergency closures. 
    In the case of emergency or at the discretion of the town council, the director or his/her designee may order any portion of the parks or parkways closed to the public if the public interest so requires. 
(Code 1972, § 13-8(a); Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11) 
Sec. 18-11. - Bristol Parks and Recreation special event. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Non-profit: The organization must be registered as a not-for-profit corporation with the State of Rhode Island, or if not registered with the state, the group must have a constitution, bylaws, or mission statement which clearly states that the objectives of the organization are of a non-profit, noncommercial nature. 
    Organization : Any group or athletic league that is submitting a special event or tournament request form. 
    Resident status: Resident status is defined as groups or organizations with membership of at least 51 percent or more Bristol residents. Team rosters and/or proof of individual residence may be required by recreation department staff or town clerk to verify residency status. 
    Tournament/special event: A tournament or special event is any program that may require more than one field, facility, equipment; or may require special involvement from other departments such as fire, police, harbor patrol, rescue, DPW, animal control, et al., beyond an organization's allocation and/or is not part of the regular playing season. 
    Youth: Leagues or groups in which the participants are all under 19 years of age. 
(b)  Priority groups. The Bristol Parks and Recreation Department sets fees for the use of its facilities and to cover the cost of maintaining its parks and athletic fields. Groups are differentiated, and charged, based on their status as non-profit (NP), for-profit (FP), youth, adult, Bristol resident, or non-Bristol resident. Those groups and their associated fees are defined below. 
    Group 1: Parks and Recreation Department youth or adult athletic programs or leagues; town-sponsored or co-sponsored events. 
    Group 2: Non-profit, youth programs, organizations or events with membership of more than 51 percent Bristol residents. 
    Group 3: Non-profit youth programs, organizations or events with membership of less than 51 percent Bristol residents. 
    Group 4: For-profit youth programs, organizations or events with membership of more than 51 percent Bristol residents. 
    Group 5: For-profit youth programs, organizations or events with membership of less than 51 percent Bristol residents. 
    Group 6: Non-profit, adult programs, organizations or events with membership of more than 51 percent Bristol residents. 
    Group 7: Non-profit adult programs, organizations or events with membership of less than 51 percent Bristol residents. 
    Group 8: For-profit adult programs, organizations or events with membership of more than 51 percent Bristol residents. 
    Group 9: For-profit adult programs, organizations or events with membership of less than 51 percent Bristol residents. 
(c)  Fee schedule.

Note: FUF (facility use fees) for all fields are $50.00 per field. 
(d)  Deposit. A deposit of $500.00 is required for all special events and/or tournaments. The deposit will be refunded if the group abides by all field permit use policy rules and regulations, as determined by a Bristol Parks and Recreation staff member during a post-event walk-through inspection of the facility with a representative of the organization. 
(e)  Insurance. All organizations and leagues and resident status entities shall secure and maintain throughout the period of use of the permit, at no expense to the Town of Bristol, a comprehensive general liability policy with policy limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence, issued by one or more companies authorized to do business in the State of Rhode Island. The Town of Bristol and its employees shall be named as additional insured by endorsement. A copy of proof of insurance must be attached to the permit application. 
(f)  Rules. 
(1)  It is the responsibility of the organization president and the individual identified as the person in charge of the permit to enforce the rules and regulations regarding the conduct of the group while on permitted facilities, as well as to ensure that coaches receive and understand that permits must be on site during field use. 
(2)  Parking is allowed only in designated areas. Cars may be towed at owners' expense. 
(3)  No dogs, alcohol other than as may be specifically permitted under article IV, smoking, gambling, fireworks, flammable material, narcotics or drugs are allowed on Bristol Parks and Recreation property. 
(4)  Respect field maintenance personnel. 
(5)  Concession stand operators are responsible for cleanliness 15 feet surrounding the stand. Operators must dispose of packing materials, boxes, containers, etc., in dumpsters. Organizations are also responsible for complying with all license requirements of the Rhode Island Department of Health. 
(6)  Observe all park rules. When driving through parking lots, participants must be watchful for children. 
(7)  At conclusion of games each user group is responsible for picking up trash and debris and depositing it into the proper trash bins. A parks and recreation department staff member will walk through the facility at the end of an event to determine compliance with this rule. 
(8)  Field closures/rainouts/cancellations-Policies shall be established by the recreation director. 
(9)  Groups must provide enough volunteers, designated by a special t-shirt, jacket, or hat, to direct traffic provide visitor information and monitor parking lot. A general guideline for volunteers is one person per 50 participants. 
(10)  The organization must submit proof in the form of a letter from the required safety and security departments, police, fire, and the harbor master, if applicable, that adequate personnel, if necessary, will be present for the duration of the event. 
(11)  The organization is responsible for adherence to all the general laws and ordinances set by the Town of Bristol, including chapter 10, article II on noise. 
(Ord. No. 2006-13, 5-31-06; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11; Ord. No. 2016-03, 5-4-16) 
Sec. 18-12. - Exceptions-Personal assistance animals and service dogs. 
    It shall not be a violation of this chapter to bring any service dog, as required by federal law, or any personal assistance animal, as required by RIGL tit. 40, ch. 9.1, onto any memorial park, sports field or complex, beach, playground, or other public places within the town at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2017-12, 9-13-17) 
Secs. 18-13-18-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-91 et seq. 

Sec. 18-41. - Created; members; terms; compensation. 
    There shall be a recreation board, which shall function within the department of community development, and shall perform the duties and exercise the powers conferred upon it by the town council. The board shall consist of five members appointed by the town council to serve for three-year staggered terms. Of the first members appointed under the Charter, two shall be designated to serve one-year terms, two shall be designated to serve two-year terms, and the remaining one shall serve a three-year term. The council may appoint up to two auxiliary members of the recreation board to serve for three-year staggered terms. Such auxiliary members shall sit as active members when and if a temporary vacancy so requires, upon request of the chairperson of the board. Ex officio members may sit and participate at meetings but shall have no vote. 
(Code 1972, § 13-21; Ord. No. 1999-08, 4-21-99) 
Sec. 18-42. - Authority. 
    The recreation board shall have the authority, within the limits of appropriations therefor, to assist the director with the equipment and management of public playgrounds, athletic fields, swimming pools, bathing places and other community recreation centers, enhance and protect environmental areas, and to conduct and promote recreation, play, sports and physical training for which admission or other fees may be charged. 
(Code 1972, § 13-22; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11) 
Sec. 18-43. - Fees. 
    All fees and payments collected shall be transmitted to the town treasury to be deposited in the general funds of the town. 
(Code 1972, § 13-23) 
Sec. 18-44. - Ex-officio members. 
    The council may provide that a member of the school committee and a member of the town veterans council be ex-officio members of the recreation board. 
(Code 1972, § 13-24; Ord. No. 2005-37, 11-2-05; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-04, adopted March 31, 2011, amended § 18-44 title to read as herein set out. Former § 18-44 title pertained to ex officio members. 
Sec. 18-45. - Employees. 
(a)  The parks and recreation department shall be headed by a director of parks and recreation who shall be appointed by the town administrator from among persons with professional training in recreation/leisure and park development with at least five years experience in the related fields. The duties of said director shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  To supervise and/or coordinate all activities and functions designated by the Charter or ordinance of the town council; 
(2)  To recommend and supervise the necessary personnel for the operation of the department; 
(3)  To report to the town administrator; and 
(4)  Under the supervision/direction of the town administrator, to create applications for grants and supervise the use of such acquired funds. 
(b)  Other employees. There shall be such other assistants, supervisors, playleaders, teachers and other employees as may be necessary for the efficient administration and development of the public recreation system, as requested by the director to the town administrator, subject to the limits of its budget appropriation. All such employees shall be appointed, promoted or dismissed by the town administrator, acting only on the recommendation of the director. 
(c)  Personnel recommendations. Nothing in this section is meant to be construed as restricting the powers of the town administrator in the performance of duties as prescribed in the Charter, nor the director as described elsewhere in this section. The town administrator may accept or reject the personnel recommendations. Should any personnel recommendation be rejected by the town administrator, notification, in writing, shall be made to the director stating the reasons for rejection within five working days. The director may choose to submit a new recommendation or resubmit the original recommendation. 
(d)  Coordinator of senior services. There shall be a coordinator of senior services who shall be appointed by the town administrator. The coordinator of senior services shall report directly to the director of parks and recreation. The duties of said coordinator shall include: Senior programming, meal programs; scheduling and operating a variety of activities, trips, exercise classes and social events. To be a supportive resource for Bristol residents 55+ years of age. To provide for a clean, safe, and welcoming environment at the Benjamin Church Senior Center. To submit a planned budget to the director of parks and recreation annually. 
(Code 1972, § 13-25; Ord. No. 1997-02, 4-9-97; Ord. No. 2008-08, 6-18-08; Ord. No. 2011-04, 3-31-11; Ord. No. 2017-10, 8-23-17) 
Secs. 18-46-18-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALCOHOL USE AND SALE ON TOWN PROPERTY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-01, adopted April 26, 2017, deleted former Art. III, §§ 18-76-18-79, which pertained to tobacco use at youth events and derived from Ord. No. 1996-03, §§ 1-3, 5, adopted Feb. 14, 1996. Subsequently, Ord. No. 2017-01 redesignated former Art. IV as new Art. III, as set out herein. 

Sec. 18-80. - General. 
(a)  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold or consumed on public property in the Town of Bristol without first making application and securing permission, in writing, from the town council. 
(b)  The town council shall consider the applications for the consumption and/or sale of alcoholic beverages on public property only from bona fide non-profit Bristol resident status entities for fairs and festivals, or from town committees for town-sanctioned special events. 
(c)  All applications for the consumption and/or sale of alcoholic beverages on public property shall be received by the council clerk, per the town council meeting schedule, and forwarded to the town administrator, police department, fire department, recreation department, and public works department. These departments shall provide recommendations to the town council, as applicable. 
(d)  Permission, if granted, is limited to malt and vinous beverages only. Distilled spirits are expressly forbidden. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03, 5-4-16) 
Sec. 18-81. - Rules for all entities. 
(a)  For events to be held in public parks or other properties under the regular supervision of the parks and recreation department, the applicant must first secure a facility use permit from the parks and recreation department and provide a copy of this permit when making application to the town council for alcoholic beverage use and sale. 
(b)  For events to be held in public properties not under the supervision of the parks and recreation department, the applicant must obtain permission to use these properties from the town council. 
(c)  All alcoholic beverages must be consumed indoors or in a defined, secure, outdoor or tented area such as a "beer garden." 
(d)  Applicant must provide a diagram of the area to be used and the location of the service and storage of the alcoholic beverages. 
(e)  Applicant must retain and be responsible for the cost of a police detail with number of police officers as specified by the police department. 
(f)  Applicant must assure that recycling is practiced during the event and must coordinate with the department of public works to assure that all recyclables are collected and disposed of properly. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03, 5-4-16) 
Sec. 18-82. - Rules for non-profit Bristol resident status entities. 
(a)  Applicant must provide a certificate of insurance for a minimum of $1,000,000.00 of coverage which names the Town of Bristol as additional insured. 
(b)  Applicant must assure that all persons serving the alcoholic beverages are both of sufficient age and possessing tips training. 
(c)  Applicant must assure that all persons being served alcoholic beverages are over the age of 21. 
(d)  Applicant must conform to all applicable government rules and regulations concerning the purchase, sale, and service of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03, 5-4-16) 
Sec. 18-83. - Rules for town committees. 
(a)  All alcoholic beverages must be provided and served by a third-party caterer who is licensed by the State of Rhode Island for this purpose. 
(b)  Third party caterer must provide a certificate of insurance showing general liability and workers compensation coverage for a minimum of $1,000,000.00 of coverage which names the Town of Bristol as additional insured. 
(c)  Third party caterer must assure that all persons serving the alcoholic beverages are both of sufficient age and possessing tips training. 
(d)  Third party caterer must assure that all persons being served alcoholic beverages are over the age of 21. 
(e)  Third party caterer must conform to all applicable government rules and regulations concerning the purchase, sale, and service of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 2016-03, 5-4-16) 
Chapter 19 - PEDDLERS, HAWKERS AND ITINERANT VENDORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Solicitation, ch. 23; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 25. 
State Law reference- Hawkers and peddlers, G.L. 1956, § 5-11-1 et seq.; authority of town to license peddlers and hawkers, G.L. 1956, § 5-11-18. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Persons exempt from chapter provisions. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall apply to milkmen, nor to vendors of ice or newspapers. 
(Code 1972, § 14-6) 
Sec. 19-2. - Prohibited areas and rules governing peddlers and hawkers. 
    In addition to the general ordinances and laws, all peddlers and hawkers must not vend on school property or within school zones as established by the school department; must not vend on all town recreational areas, the town common and all town parks; must not vend in the downtown area, which encompasses the area surrounded by Church Street, Franklin Street, Thames Street and Hope Street; must not impede the free flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, the town council may by special exception, upon issuance of the license or subsequent request to the town council, permit vending in certain areas of the town including public areas for specific occasions. 
    The chief of police shall, from time to time, submit to the council additional streets and public ways throughout the town which, in his opinion, because of excess traffic and congestion, are unsafe for the public welfare and safety for the selling or offering for sale of merchandise by peddlers or hawkers. 
(Code 1972, § 14-8; Ord. No. 2009-15, 11-11-09; Ord. No. 2012-04, 7-18-12) 
Sec. 19-3. - Display of license required. 
    Any person who shall neglect or refuse, on demand by any police officer or any other person, to exhibit to such officer his license, shall be deemed, for the purpose of this chapter, to be unlicensed and to have violated the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1972, § 14-5) 
Sec. 19-4. - Sale of certain products prohibited; penalties for violation of section. 
    The sale in the town of "silly string," "snappers," and all other similar products by vendors licensed by the town is prohibited. A vendor that sells and/or dispenses such products shall have such items confiscated and be subject to a fine of $500.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1972, § 14-8.1) 
Sec. 19-5. - License forfeiture for violation of town ordinances or state law. 
    Any licensee found violating any ordinance of the town or law of the state, in addition to other remedies or fines, is subject to forfeiture of the license. 
(Code 1972, § 14-9) 
Sec. 19-6. - Peddling similar goods near established businesses prohibited. 
    No peddler, solicitor, industrial caterer or itinerant tradesman of any kind shall sell or attempt to sell his or her products within 300 feet of any business establishment in the town which sells the same products. 
(Ord. No. 2012-04, 7-18-12) 
Sec. 19-7. - Sales prohibited during certain hours in certain areas. 
    No person shall peddle, solicit or canvass on any highway in the town, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. in residential areas and between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight in business areas, as such areas are shown on the zoning map of the town on file in the town clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 2012-04, 7-18-12) 
Secs. 19-8-19-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 

Sec. 19-36. - Required. 
    No person shall hawk, peddle, sell or offer for sale on any street, square or alley within the town any goods, wares, merchandise or other articles and substances, from vehicles or on foot, without first obtaining a license authorizing such person to sell such goods, wares, merchandise or other articles and substances on the streets, lanes, squares or alleys in the town, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and in accordance with G.L. 1956, § 5-11-1 et seq. 
(Code 1972, § 14-1) 
Sec. 19-37. - Application; issuance. 
(a)  All hawkers and peddlers and all persons selling or offering for sale any goods, wares, merchandise and other articles and substances on any street, square or alley of the town shall make application for a license to the town council, even if such person holds a state license under the provisions of G.L. 1956, § 5-11-1 et seq. 
(b)  Upon approval of such application by the town council, the town clerk shall issue a license accordingly to such person to sell such articles and substances in such manner as shall be specified in such license upon any street, square or alley in the town. 
(Code 1972, § 14-2) 
Sec. 19-38. - Fees; exemption from fees; expiration of licenses. 
(a)  Every person to whom a license is issued under this chapter by the town council, before receiving the license, shall pay to the town clerk the fee set out in section 11-1, for any one license for any one year. 
(b)  No license fee shall be charged to any person selling religious books and publications on behalf of Bible, tract or other religious or moral improvement (organization) and which are sold for that purpose and not for any pecuniary profit; nor to any person selling or offering to sell or peddle any articles of household manufacture or articles manufactured with the licensee's own hands, nor to any person who shall receive a license from the general treasurer of the state in accordance with the provisions of G.L. 1956, § 5-11-1 et seq. 
(c)  All annual licenses shall expire at midnight on the day proceeding the official date of the town's annual Independence Day parade as set by the Bristol Fourth of July Committee. All annual license fees shall be prorated in the following manner: licenses issued the day after the annual Independence Day parade through January 3 shall pay the full annual license fee, and licenses issued between January 4 through the day before the annual Independence Day parade shall pay one-half the annual fee. Annual licenses shall not include (1) the day of the Christmas parade as set by the Christmas Festival Committee, and (2) the day of the Labor Day programs. 
(d)  Daily and weekly licenses shall be allowed from time to time as authorized by the town council. 
(Code 1972, § 14-3; Ord. No. 2000-09, 4-19-00) 
Sec. 19-39. - Transferability. 
    No license issued under this chapter shall authorize any person, other than the one named therein, to act thereunder, and no license shall be transferable. 
(Code 1972, § 14-4) 
Sec. 19-40. - Limitations. 
    Depending upon vehicular traffic situations anticipated and in order to safeguard the general health and safety of the public, the town council may limit the number of peddlers' licenses granted, which limit must be established by June 3 of each year. 
(Code 1972, § 14-7) 
Secs. 19-41-19-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ITINERANT VENDORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 19-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Itinerant vendor means and includes all persons, both principals and agents, who engage in a temporary or transient business in this town, either in one locality or in traveling from place to place selling cut flowers, potted plants and nursery stock including Christmas trees, and who for the purpose of carrying on such business, has leased or occupied any building or structure or part of any building or structure for the exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 1996-07, § 1, 4-24-96) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 19-72. - Application of article provisions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to sales of items other than cut flowers, potted plants or nursery stock including Christmas trees, or sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or selling agents in the usual course of business, or to bona fide sales of goods, wares and merchandise by sample for future delivery or to hawkers on the streets, or to peddlers from vehicles, or to sheriffs, constables or public officers of the state selling goods, wares and merchandise according to law, or to bona fide assignees for the benefit of creditors, or receivers appointed in this state selling goods, wares and merchandise in this town; provided, however, that the situs of such goods, wares and merchandise, was in this town prior to such assignment or the appointment of such receiver. 
(Ord. No. 1996-07, § 2, 4-24-96) 
Sec. 19-73. - Prohibited sales. 
    No itinerant vendor shall advertise, represent or hold forth any sale as an insurance, bankrupt, insolvent, assignee, trustee, estate, executor, administrator, receiver, wholesale or manufacturer's or closing out sale, or as a sale of any goods damaged by smoke, fire, water or otherwise, or in any similar form, unless he shall before so doing, state under oath to the town clerk all the facts relating to the reasons and character of such special sale so advertised or represented, including a statement of the names of the persons from whom the goods, wares and merchandise were obtained, the date of delivery to the person applying for the license, and the place from which such goods, wares and merchandise were taken, and all details necessary to exactly locate and fully identify all goods, wares and merchandise to be sold. 
(Ord. No. 1996-07, § 8, 4-24-96) 
Secs. 19-74-19-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 19-96. - Penalty for selling without. 
    Every itinerant vendor who shall sell or expose for sale, at public auction or private sale, any goods, wares and merchandise without a town license therefor, issued as provided in this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00, nor more than $250.00. 
(Ord. No. 1996-07, § 3, 4-24-96; Ord. No. 2017-13, 10-4-17) 
Sec. 19-97. - Penalty for advertising sale without. 
    All persons, both principals and agents, who shall by circular, handbill, newspaper or in any other manner, advertise any sale before proper license shall be issued to the vendor, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with section 19-96. 
(Ord. No. 1996-07, § 4, 4-24-96) 
Sec. 19-98. - Duty to obtain. 
    It shall be the duty of every itinerant vendor, whether principal or agent, before commencing business, to take out a license in the manner set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 1996-07, § 5, 4-24-96) 
Sec. 19-99. - Application; granting; fees; information required. 
(a)  Every itinerant vendor desiring to do business in this town shall upon application in proper form and upon such application being approved by the chief of police, be granted by the town clerk an itinerant vendor's license authorizing such vendor to do business in this town in conformity with the provisions of this article, on the payment of a license fee in the amount of $350.00. 
(b)  Every license shall set forth the name of the licensee and the authority and term which shall not exceed three months granted. The license shall not be transferable nor give authority to more than one person to sell goods as an itinerant vendor either by agent or clerk, or in any other way than in his own proper person; but any licensee may have the assistance of one or more persons in conducting his business, who shall have authority to aid their principal but not to act for or without him. 
(c)  All applications for licenses shall be sworn to, shall disclose the names and residences of the owners or parties in whose interest the business is conducted, and shall be kept on file by the town clerk; and a record shall be kept of all licenses issued upon such applications. All files and records of the town clerk shall be in convenient form and open for public inspection. 
(d)  Any license granted under the provisions of this article may be canceled at any time by the town council, if any false statements shall have been made in the application upon which such license was granted. 
(Ord. No. 1996-07, § 6, 4-24-96) 
Sec. 19-100. - Display.
