(h)  Each occurrence of a violation after the first, and each day that such violation continues, shall constitute a separate violation and may be cited as such. 
(Ord. No. 2018-02 , 2-28-18) 
Sec. 24-135. - Appeals. 
    Any violation charged under this article may be appealed, in writing, to the town administrator within 14 days of receipt of a written notice of violation. The town administrator may waive the individual violation or the requirements of this article on showing of good cause or undue hardship. 
(Ord. No. 2018-02 , 2-28-18) 
Sec. 24-136. - Effective Date. 
    The provisions of this article shall become effective January 1, 2019. 
    The provisions of this article shall automatically expire on December 31, 2020, if not renewed by act of the town council. 
(Ord. No. 2018-02 , 2-28-18) 
Chapter 25 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, alley or other public way in the town saved from repeal, § 1-10(4); any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades in the town saved from repeal, § 1-10(5); boats, docks and waterways, ch. 8; buildings and building regulations, ch. 9; building numbering, § 9-76 et seq.; environment, ch. 10; historic preservation, ch. 14; motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 16; parks and recreation, ch. 18; peddlers, hawkers and itinerant vendors, ch. 19; solicitation, ch. 23; solid waste management, ch. 24; subdivisions, ch. 26; zoning, ch. 28. 
State Law reference- Maintenance of town highways, G.L. 1956, § 24-5-1 et seq.; abandonment by towns, G.L. 1956, § 24-6-1 et seq.; sidewalks, G.L. 1956, § 24-7-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PARKS 

Sec. 25-1. - Placing, depositing or putting merchandise or personal property on sidewalk. 
    No person shall deposit, place or put, or suffer to be deposited, placed or put by any person in his employ, any goods, wares, chattels or merchandise on any sidewalk in the town, except while loading or shipping the same, or actually removing the same into or out of some building or enclosure, or loading the same into or unloading the same out of some vehicle, in such a manner as to interfere with the free discharge of the passengers or operator of a motor vehicle onto such sidewalk, whether such operator or passengers are actually being so discharged at the time or not. 
(Code 1972, § 20-1) 
Sec. 25-2. - Allowing water or other liquid to run onto streets, highways or other public places; exception. 
    No person shall throw or deposit, or cause to be thrown or deposited, or suffer to flow into or upon, any street, highway or public place any water or other liquid which causes any noxious or unhealthy effluvia, or any filthy or dirty water. No water upon any land adjoining a public street or highway shall be permitted to run from any such land upon such street or highway, except spring water, the natural run of which may be upon such street or highway, and rainwater. 
(Code 1972, § 20-2) 
Sec. 25-3. - Bonds prerequisite to use of common. 
(a)  Any person to whom a license is issued for use of the Bristol Common shall first arrange for the posting of penal bond running to the town in the amount of $1,000.00, such bond to be approved by the finance director. Such amount shall be paid to the town if the common grounds, or such portion thereof as are used by such licensee, his or its agents or servants, are not cleared of all debris, refuse, papers, bottles, foodstuffs, scraps and other trash by 8:00 a.m. daily during the use by such licensee, his or its agents or servants, and so cleared also within eight hours after use thereof by such licensee, his or its agents or servants. 
(b)  A bond to be approved by the finance director, shall be required of each licensee for use of the common, to cover any liability to which the town might become subject arising out of the operation or use of the common by such licensee, its agents or servants. 
(c)  Any person to whom a license is issued for use of the Bristol Common shall first arrange for the posting of a suitable bond running to the town, such bond to be approved by the finance director. Such amount or any fraction thereof shall be payable to the town to cover any liability for property damage or personal injuries to which the town is subject by virtue of or arising out of the operation or use of the common by such licensee, its agents or servants. 
(Code 1972, § 20-3) 
Sec. 25-4. - Parades. 
(a)  No band of music, drum corps, company of musicians or other like body of people shall parade in or march through, along or across any of the public streets of the town and play upon or use any musical instruments while so parading or marching, without first obtaining a permit thereof from the chief of police. 
(b)  No chairs, sleeping bags or any other items designated to "reserve space" may be placed in public areas, including streets, sidewalks and parks, prior to 5:00 a.m. on the day of any parade. "Roping-off" or otherwise reserving sections of a public street, sidewalk, or park along any parade route is prohibited at all times. 
(Code 1972, § 20-4; Ord. No. 2002-19, 9-12-02) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 16. 
Sec. 25-5. - Streets, parks or common excavations. 
(a)  Permit required. No person shall excavate or dig into any portion of any of the public streets, parks or common in the town for any purpose, without having obtained a special permit therefor from the town council. The provisions of this section shall not apply to excavating or digging conducted by the state in the construction, improvement or maintenance of state roads, or to corporations having a right to excavate or dig into the public streets of the town under or by virtue of a contract between such corporation and the town, or to persons excavating, digging or cutting roads in emergency situations when no permit can reasonably be obtained. 
(b)  Issuance of permit; terms and conditions. The town council may at any time issue a special permit authorizing any person to excavate or dig into the public streets, parks or common. Before issuing such special permit, he shall first receive from such person a written application setting forth the name and address of such applicant and a designation of the particular portion of public streets, park or common which the applicant desires to excavate or dig into, and a designation of the purpose for which such excavation or digging is to be carried on. Before issuing such special permit the town council shall receive a bond from such applicant running to the town, in such sum not less than $1,000.00 as the town council may fix, with such surety as is satisfactory to the town council. Such bond shall contain a condition that the obligation of the bond shall be in full force and effect unless the applicant shall, upon final completion of work, comply with subsection (c) of this section, and unless the town shall be free and harmless from all loss or damage arising by reason of any fault or neglect on the part of such applicant in the performance of the work. Such special permit shall designate the purpose of the excavating or digging permitted, and shall designate the particular portion of the public street, park or common to be excavated or dug into, and also the time limit within which such excavation or digging shall be completed. A duplicate of such permit shall be delivered to and recorded by the town clerk. No person who has received such special permit shall be authorized to excavate or dig into the public streets, parks or common at any time or place or for any other purpose than the time, place and purpose designated by such special permit. No person who has received such special permit shall do any work, excavating or digging thereunder, except in conformity with such orders, rules or regulations, general or special, established by the town council. 
(c)  Curb-to-curb paving and cold planing. Every person, firm, business or utility digging or making any excavation in any street or highway of the town which has been repaved within five years of the excavation, or who shall cause the same to be done, shall fill up the same as soon as possible thereafter and shall leave such highway or street in as good condition as before the commencement of work. This shall mean the street or highway shall be repaved across the entire right-of-way from curb to curb over the excavated area, and 50 feet on either side of the excavation including cold planing (grinding) and edge matching, with a minimum settlement period of three months and a maximum of six months before permanent repairs are made; and left in a condition satisfactory to and approved by the director of public works. 
(d)  Penalties. Except in emergency situations, any person who excavates, digs or cuts roads without first obtaining a permit to do so shall be subject to a warning for the first offense, a $250.00 fine for the second offense, and a $500.00 fine for all subsequent offenses. 
(Code 1972, §§ 20-5, 20-6; Ord. No. 2007-33, 11-7-07; Ord. No. 2011-12, 9-7-11) 
Sec. 25-6. - Removal of earth, sand or other material from streets, highways or public places. 
    No person shall take and carry away from any street, highway or public place, any earth, sand, gravel, stone, sod, or other material, without permission from the director of public works. 
(Code 1972, § 20-7) 
Sec. 25-7. - Coasting on sleds. 
    No person shall slide or coast on any sled, for amusement, on any street, avenue, sidewalk or passageway in the town, except in areas designated by the director of recreation and chief of police. 
(Code 1972, § 20-8) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 16. 
Sec. 25-8. - Playing ball, throwing stones or missiles in streets. 
    No person shall play at ball or throw any stones or other missiles for amusement, in any of the streets or highways of the town. 
(Code 1972, § 20-9) 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 16. 
Sec. 25-9. - Use of a certain portion of Low Lane. 
(a)  The westerly portion of Low Lane, so called, more particularly described in subsection (b) of this section, is hereby limited to travel by foot unless the town council authorizes otherwise by ordinance. Further, the town hereby declares the westerly part or section of Low Lane to be a public highway and shall maintain the same as a foot path while preserving the natural environmental scenic value of this westerly portion of Low Lane. 
(b)  The westerly portion of Low Lane is more particularly described as follows: 
(1)  Thence: South 00 degrees, 25 minutes, 00 seconds east, along the most westerly end of Low Lane 50 feet to land now or formerly belonging to Rhoda Low; 
(2)  Thence: South 89 degrees, 35 minutes, 00 seconds west, along the land now or formerly belonging to Rhoda Low 398.08 feet to a stake set on top of an embankment; 
(3)  Thence: Continuing on a bearing of south 89 degrees, 35 minutes, 00 seconds west, 18 feet, plus or minus to the mean high-water line of Mount Hope Bay; 
(4)  Thence: Northerly along the mean high-water line of Mount Hope Bay 50.9 feet to the land of Adelaide Nicholson; 
(5)  Thence: North 89 degrees, 35 minutes, 00 seconds east, along the Nicholson land 17 feet, plus or minus, to a stake set on top of an embankment; 
(6)  Thence: Continuing on a same bearing of north 89 degrees, 35 minutes, 00 seconds east, 407.53 feet to a point of beginning. 
The Low Lane right-of-way thus contains 21,015 square feet. 
(Code 1972, § 20-10) 
Sec. 25-10. - Use of sidewalks for dining and other purposes by business establishments; licensing. 
(a)  License required. Business establishments may make application to the town council for an annual license or a temporary day or week license, to use sidewalks abutting their establishments for outside dining or sales. Each application shall contain: 
(1)  The name, address and owner of the business making application. 
(2)  The name, address and owner of the real estate wherein the business is located. 
(3)  A line drawing or plot plan showing the entire sidewalk area, the placement or location of tables, chairs or racks thereon and dimensions of each. 
(4)  Proof of liability insurance from a company licensed to do business in the state and in a form satisfactory to the town solicitor, of no less than $1,000,000.00 protecting the town for all claims and causes of action for personal injury or property damage resulting from use of this license. 
(5)  In addition, the applicant will obtain and file with the application a covering letter of approval from the chief of police. 
(6)  Applicants shall pay a fee for such license as set forth in the fee schedule in section 11-1. 
(b)  Displays of merchandise for sale. Any person displaying merchandise for sale on any public right-of-way or sidewalk is subject to the following provisions: 
A merchant shall be allowed to display goods, wares and merchandise on the sidewalk in front of a retail store in the following manner: 
a.  No more than 50 percent of the linear feet in front of the store shall be used for display purposes. 
b.  The display area shall be no more than 36 inches from the outside wall of the retail store. 
c.  The goods, wares or merchandise in the display area shall not exceed a height of six feet. 
d.  Any retail store located on or at an intersection of two or more streets shall not display any goods, wares, or merchandise in such a manner that will obstruct the vision of any operator of a motor vehicle, pedestrian, or bicycle on or approaching said intersection. 
e.  Regardless of any other conditions, a 36-inch public right-of-way shall be maintained at all times on public sidewalks and thoroughfares. 
f.  All display merchandise on a sidewalk must be removed during such times as commercial promotional events or public celebrations are to take place in an area where a licenseholder conducts his or her business. 
(c)  Outside dining. No license shall be allowed for outside dining if the sidewalk is less than nine feet wide, measured from the curb to the closest point on the outside wall of the building. For sidewalks between nine feet to 12 feet in width, tables and chairs must be placed close against the building in such a manner as to provide a minimum of seven feet of unobstructed passage width for public use. For sidewalks in excess of 12 feet in width, tables and chairs must be placed close against the building in such a manner as to provide a minimum of eight and one-half feet of unobstructed passage width for public use. 
(d)  Additional rules and restrictions. All tables, chairs, racks and merchandise must be removed from the sidewalk or right of way whenever the business is closed. Absolutely no alcoholic beverages are to be served on the sidewalks at any time. The entire sidewalk area in front of a business establishment will be kept at all times neat, clean and with debris immediately removed so as not to cause a hazard or annoyance to pedestrians. No license issued under this section shall be valid on the day of the Bristol Fourth of July Celebration in any year. 
(e)  Revocation of license and penalty for violations. Any infraction of this section will be grounds for immediate revocation of this license. For such cause and subject to later review by the town council, the town administrator may revoke or modify any sidewalk license at any time. In addition, the town council may at any time revoke or modify a sidewalk license without cause. Individuals or businesses found in violation of the provisions of this section are also subject to a fine not to exceed $50.00 for the first offense, a fine not to exceed $100.00 for the second and subsequent offenses in addition to any other fine assessed pursuant to this Code. 
(Code 1972, § 20-11; Ord. No. 1999-22, 12-15-99) 
Sec. 25-11. - Public school grounds closing hours. 
    No person shall be on any public school grounds within the town during the hours that those grounds are closed. All public school grounds, including but not limited to, buildings, playgrounds, recreational facilities and playing fields, shall be closed from 11:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. daily, unless permission is granted by the school district to remain open at other designated times. 
(Ord. No. 2001-03, 1-24-01) 
Sec. 25-12. - Private installation of town sidewalks. 
    Any property owner whose property abuts a town sidewalk may, at his or her own expense, and only by application to the town's department of public works, request to replace any portion of that sidewalk which abuts their property subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Any sidewalk privately installed pursuant to this section must meet town standards and must be approved by the town's department of public works prior to installation; 
(2)  All sidewalks installed pursuant to this section, although privately installed, shall remain the property of the town; 
(3)  The town maintains the right to replace any sidewalk installed pursuant to this section at any time in the interest of the public health, safety, and welfare; 
(4)  Any owner wishing to maintain and/or install a sidewalk pursuant to this section shall be required to maintain sufficient insurance coverage to protect both the town and the applicant from all claims for personal injuries which may arise from the installation and/or use of the sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 2006-08, 4-19-06) 
Sec. 25-13. - Maintenance and repair of privately installed sidewalks. 
    Any owner who installs a sidewalk pursuant to section 25-12 of this chapter shall thereafter be solely responsible for the maintenance and repair of that sidewalk. While the town maintains its ownership of, and its right to replace that sidewalk, the town shall not be responsible in any way for its maintenance or repair. 
(Ord. No. 2006-08, 4-19-06) 
Sec. 25-14. - Commercial and construction dumpsters. 
(a)  Generally . As used in this section the word "dumpster" shall mean any container which is used for the collection and disposal of bulk trash, refuse, recyclable materials or other kinds of waste, and which may be of the open or enclosed variety, and is typically hoisted onto a specifically equipped truck for transporting said waste to a designated facility. Dumpsters are typically used for commercial and industrial land uses. 
(b)  Location of dumpsters . No dumpster shall be placed so that it blocks any public sidewalk. No dumpster shall be located on a public street or alley unless a permit is obtained from the director of the department of public works. If permitted and the dumpster is placed on the public street or alley, the dumpster shall be directly in front of or on the side of the property address utilizing the dumpster. Additionally, a dumpster placed in the street shall: 
(1)  Not be more than 12 inches from the curb; 
(2)  Not obstruct driveways of abutting properties; 
(3)  Not obstruct traffic; 
(4)  Have a reflector or reflective area of not less than 36 square inches at each end. 
Additionally, a dumpster shall not be placed on the public street if on-street parking for vehicles is not allowed at that location. 
(c)  Time limit. The time limits for the maintenance of dumpsters is as follows: 
(1)  Residential zoning districts: During any six-month period a dumpster and any replacement dumpster shall be placed for a total of not more than 14 days in any six-month period if placed on the street and not more than 30 days in any six-month period if placed elsewhere. (The time limits prescribed in this subsection do not apply to private dumpsters that service the regular and ordinary disposal needs of multi-household dwellings.) 
(2)  Commercial zoning districts: A dumpster and any replacement dumpster placed under this section and not in a public street may remain on the site as long as required. A dumpster or any replacement dumpster placed upon a public street may be placed for not more than a total of 14 days in any six-month period. 
(3)  Industrial zoning districts: A dumpster or any replacement dumpster placed under this section may remain on the site as long as needed, but not to exceed a total of 18 months, but not to exceed 14 days if on a public street or sidewalk. 
(d)  Sanitation. The following requirements shall be maintained while the dumpster is on or at the site: 
(1)  The area around the dumpster shall be kept free of debris and litter; 
(2)  Any dumpster into which animal or vegetable waste or material has been dumped or deposited shall be removed or emptied within 24 hours; 
(3)  Any dumpster producing or causing noxious, foul or offensive odors shall be immediately removed or cleaned to eliminate the odor; and 
(4)  A full dumpster shall be removed from the property within two days. 
(e)  Usage. A dumpster shall only be used to contain and remove debris and material generated at the location where the dumpster is placed. 
(f)  Identification. The name and 24-hour, seven days per week telephone number of the owner of the dumpster and/or the company that is responsible for the dumpster shall be displayed in a weather proof manner on the dumpster. 
(g)  Permit required. A permit shall be required for a dumpster. The permit shall be obtained from the director of the public works department after paying the required fee, which shall be set by council resolution. 
(h)  Abatement. Any dumpster not in compliance with this section is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and may be abated by the city at the owner's or responsible person's expense. Abatement shall, at the city's option, include the removal and/or the emptying of the dumpster. 
(i)  Violations; penalties . Enforcement of this section shall be in accordance with section 28-407 of this Code, entitled "Enforcement and penalties." 
(Ord. No. 2006-27, 8-23-06) 
Sec. 25-15. - Sidewalk alcohol service; licensing. 
(a)  License required. Business establishments in the downtown and waterfront zoning districts may make application to the town council for an annual license or a temporary day or week license, to use sidewalks abutting their establishments for sidewalk alcohol service related to outside dining. A license for sidewalk alcohol service is distinct from a license to serve alcohol as set forth in section 17-83. All requirements set forth in section 25-15 are in addition to requirements set forth in section 25-10. Each application shall contain: 
(1)  The name, address and owner of the business making application. 
(2)  The name, address and owner of the real estate wherein the business is located. 
(3)  A line drawing or plot plan drawn to scale showing the entire sidewalk area, the placement or location of tables, chairs or racks thereon and dimensions of each. 
(4)  Proof of liability insurance from a company licensed to do business in the state and in a form satisfactory to the town solicitor, of no less than $1,000,000.00 protecting the town for all claims and causes of action for personal injury or property damage resulting from use of this license. The applicant shall provide proof of such insurance before a license may be issued or renewed under this chapter. 
(5)  In addition, the applicant will obtain and file with the application a covering letter of recommendation from the chief of police and the zoning enforcement officer. 
(6)  Applicants shall pay a fee for such license as set forth in the fee schedule in section 11-1. 
(b)  Minimum required dimensions. No license shall be allowed for sidewalk alcohol service if the sidewalk is less than nine feet wide, measured from the curb to the closest point on the outside wall of the building. For sidewalks between nine feet to 12 feet in width, tables and chairs must be placed close against the building in such a manner as to provide a minimum of six feet of unobstructed passage width for public use. For sidewalks in excess of 12 feet in width, tables and chairs must be placed close against the building in such a manner as to provide a minimum of six feet plus 50 percent of the width of the sidewalk beyond 12 feet of unobstructed passage width for public use. However, the width of unobstructed passage need not exceed eight and one-half feet no matter the width of the sidewalk. 
(c)  The designated area. The area in which tables and chairs may be placed and patrons may be served shall be known as the "designated area." The designated area must be clearly delineated by object(s) such as planters, small wrought iron fences, roping or other appropriate means. All object(s) must remain entirely within the designated area. No part of the outside dining area, object(s) used to delineate the designated area or other objects (e.g., the base of object(s) or the tip of umbrella(s)) shall encroach upon the sidewalk outside the designated area or encroach upon any part of the frontage of any adjacent premises, right-of-way or alley. All patrons must enter and exit the designated area through the business establishment. A sign or signs must be posted in the designated area indicating hours of service. 
(d)  Additional license required. An applicant shall not sell, serve or allow consumption of alcoholic beverages in the designated area without receiving a class B license or amendment to existing license from the "license commissioners" as set forth in section 17-83. 
(e)  Provision of alcoholic beverages. All alcoholic beverages sold, served, or allowed outside of the licensed establishment must remain inside of the designated area. The ratio of service of food to service of alcohol must be a minimum of 53 percent to 47 percent of food service by dollar sales, and every establishment shall submit an affidavit signed by the license holder attesting to and setting forth the actual ratio for the previous year, with each renewal application. Alcoholic beverages shall only be served with food. However, alcoholic beverages shall not be served with carry-out food. An outside host/hostess must be available while service is taking place. The penalty for violating any provision in section 25-15(e), as set forth in section 25-15(g), may include a fine or revocation of the license. 
(f)  Additional rules and restrictions. All tables, chairs, planters, small wrought iron fences, roping, racks and merchandise must be removed from the sidewalk by no later than 10:00 p.m. on Sunday through Thursday, and no later than 11:00 p.m., on Friday and Saturday, provided that the town council may require an earlier closing time in the granting of the license. The entire sidewalk area in front of a business establishment will be kept at all times neat, clean and with debris immediately removed so as not to cause a hazard or annoyance to pedestrians. The following are prohibited in the designated area: cooking of food, unshielded trash or refuse storage, advertisements (exclusive of menus intended to be read from the licensed establishment); outside entertainment, music, speakers or public address systems. No license issued under this section shall be valid for the day of the Fourth of July parade in any year. 
(g)  Suspension or revocation of license and penalty for violations. Any infraction of this section may be grounds for suspension or revocation of this license. For just cause and subject to later review by the town council, the town administrator may immediately suspend any sidewalk license in the interest of public safety. In addition, the town council may, upon a hearing, suspend, revoke or modify a sidewalk license and/or impose fines. Individuals or businesses found in violation of the provisions of this section are also subject to a fine not to exceed $100.00 for the first offense, a fine not to exceed $500.00 for the second and subsequent offenses in addition to any other fine assessed pursuant to this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2014-05, 4-30-14; Ord. No. 2015-05, 4-29-15; Ord. No. 2016-04, 3-30-16) 
Secs. 25-16-25-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROTECTION AND MAINTENANCE OF TREES IN PUBLIC PLACES 

Sec. 25-21. - Purpose and intent. 
    The town council finds that trees are economically beneficial to the town and the community in attracting residents, visitors, and new industry, and further that healthy trees, properly located enhance the value and marketability of property; enhance the quality of life in the community; and promote the stability of neighborhoods by providing a healthy and more beautiful environment in which to live. The town council further finds that the town of bristol has a great variety of both tree and shrub species which should be protected and maintained in order to preserve the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-22. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the tree ordinance of the town. 
    This article regulates the protection, maintenance and planting of trees in public places and authorizes the conservation commission to act as the tree commission. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-23. - Scope. 
    This article shall regulate the protection, maintenance, removal, and planting of trees in public streets, and other public places excluding public school grounds, town parks and the town beach. This ordinance shall not be applicable to the care and control of trees and shrubs on roads under the control of the department of transportation nor those in public parks or grounds which are under the jurisdiction and control of the department of environmental management. Nothing in this ordinance shall be inconsistent with state regulations as set forth in RIGL Title 2. For purposes of this article the term "tree" shall mean any living, self-supporting wood plant that has a well defined stem(s) with a caliper of at least two inches at 4.5 feet from ground level. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-24. - Regulation by the town administrator. 
    The town administrator shall retain jurisdiction for the maintenance and preservation of trees and all forestry functions including the care and removal of trees within the jurisdiction of the town. The town administrator shall review all requests for permission for any planting, removal, or trimming of trees within any public right of way. In reviewing each request the town administrator shall obtain a report from the tree warden. 
    Written permission shall be granted by the town administrator and such permission may include reasonable conditions consistent with the purposes of this article, the master tree management plan described in section 25-28, and the recommendations of the Tree Warden. All planting, removal, or trimming of trees within any public right of way shall be conducted by, or under the supervision of, the tree warden. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-25. - Tree warden-Appointment and qualifications. 
    A tree warden shall be appointed by the town council pursuant by the town Charter and Title 2, Chapter 14 of the Rhode Island General Laws. The tree warden shall be a state licensed arborist, or if not a licensed arborist, within six months of his assuming office, the tree warden shall become a state licensed arborist. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-26. - Same-Term of office and vacancies. 
    A tree warden whose appointment has been approved by the director of the environmental management shall hold office until the first day of march in the year following his appointment and until his successor is duly appointed and approved. Any vacancy that may occur in the office of the tree warden shall be filled by the town council by the appointment of some person to serve for the remainder of the term subject to the approval of the director. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-27. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the tree warden shall conform to those duties and responsibilities outlined in G.L. §§ 2-14-1-2-14-10 as may be amended and include the following: 
(1)  Enforce all provisions of state and local laws for the preservation of trees and shrubs in accordance with this article. 
(2)  Be responsible for all planting, removal, or trimming of trees within any public right of way within the town. 
(3)  Shall serve as a member of the tree commission. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-28. - Authority of the Bristol Conservation Commission function as tree commission. 
(a)  The Bristol Conservation Commission existing as an advisory commission under the authority of the town council shall function as the tree commission. The tree warden shall be a member of the tree commission. 
(b)  The tree commission shall prepare in accordance with this article a master tree management plan (master plan) and recommend the same to the town council for adoption. The master plan shall be a five-year systemized tree management plan which makes recommendations for the regulation of the cultivation and planting of trees. The master plan shall be revised every five years. The goals and recommendations of the R.I. Urban and Community Forest Plan, State Guide Plan Element No. 156 shall be used as a guide when developing the master plan. The five-year master plan shall include, but is not limited to the following: 
(1)  Tree inventory and/or management plan; 
(2)  Tree planting plan; 
(3)  Tree maintenance plan; 
(4)  Plans for a public education program; 
(5)  Budgetary forecast; and, 
(6)  Funding opportunities. 
    The tree commission shall also prepare an annual action plan (yearly plan) which shall include specific details on maintenance needs, planting needs, public education and an annual evaluation of the previous year's activities. 
(c)  The commission shall prepare budgetary recommendations annually and recommend the same to the town council for adoption. 
(d)  The tree commission shall be responsible for developing administrative guidelines as a supplement to this article which will address the day to day procedures and specifications for tree protection, maintenance, removal and planting of trees in public places. 
(e)  The tree commission shall communicate and work with civic and public interest groups concerned with tree care, management, preservation, and planting as well as with public utility companies and coordinate their activities with all necessary town officers, commissions, and boards in the following areas: 
(1)  The development of administrative procedures to regulate and manage day to day forestry functions in public places. 
(2)  Assurance that all forestry functions are carried out consistent with the insurance of public safety, protection of the aesthetics of public places, and the preservation of the value and health of Bristol's trees. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-29. - Protection of trees within public rights-of-way. 
    The following special restrictions shall apply concerning any tree located in a public right-of-way within the scope of this article: 
(1)  No person shall deposit, place, store, or maintain any stone, brick, sand, material, concrete, or other materials that may impede the free passage of water, air, and fertilizer to the roots of any tree growing therein except by written permit from the tree warden. 
(2)  No person shall preclude the percolation of water or nutrients and gaseous exchange vital to a tree's survival by placing any impervious materials within the confines of the tree well opening. 
(3)  No person shall move any building or any other large object that may injure public trees or parts thereof without first obtaining the written approval of the tree warden. 
(4)  All trees within a public right-of-way that are within 30 feet of any excavation or construction of any building/structure or street work shall be guarded through the length of the project with good substantial frame or box not less than four feet high. The owner(s) of the property where the excavation or construction occurs shall be responsible for compliance with this provision of the article. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-30. - Enforcement replacement, penalties. 
(a)  All trees removed, destroyed or damaged as a result of unauthorized activity shall be replaced at the expense of the responsible person or persons. Replacement of trees shall be made with 3.5 to 6 inch caliper trees as directed by the tree commission following consultation with the tree warden. The total replacement in caliper inches shall equal the total caliper inches removed. All new and/or transplanted trees and shrubs shall be guaranteed by the responsible person for one year. 
(b)  The tree warden shall investigate suspected violations of this article. Upon determining that a violation exists, the tree warden shall within 15 days give written notice of the violation to the person or persons responsible. A copy of such notice shall also be sent to the tree commission. 
(c)  The person(s) have five days to respond to any notice of violation. A person receiving a notice of violation may either deny in writing that a violation exists and request reconsideration by the tree warden, citing specific reasons for this request, or cause the violation to be cured. Where a reconsideration is requested, the tree warden shall respond promptly in writing citing facts of the case and applicable ordinance provisions. If the owner fails to take any action in a timely manner monetary penalties may be assessed. 
(d)  Any person(s) found in violation of this article may be fined up to $500.00 for each offense, such fine to inure to the town and be made a part of the tree planting account. The fine shall relate to the seriousness of the offense. Each day of the existence of any violation shall be deemed a separate offense. The tree warden is hereby empowered to levy such fines, with written appeal thereupon to the municipal court. 
(e)  Wherein a 15-day period a responsible person fails to remove the violation and/or pay all fines in full that have been levied, the tree warden shall either cause the violation to be cured, or file an action in the municipal court to (i) compel payment of all fines, and/or (ii) institute other appropriate action in the municipal court to prevent, enjoin, abate or remove such violation, or compel compliance with the provisions of this article. Any costs associated with correcting the violation and/or any unpaid fines and court costs may be filed by the town as liens on the property, except where the municipal court provides otherwise. Appeals from decisions of the municipal court shall be in accordance with section 2-216 of the town code. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-31. - Emergencies. 
    The requirements of this article may be waived by the director of public works in the case of emergencies such as winter storms, tropical storms, hurricanes, or other natural or manmade disasters so that they in no way shall hinder private or public works to restore order to the town. All emergencies shall, to the degree practical, follow the standards of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-32. - Exemptions. 
    The requirements of this article shall not apply to decisions of the director of public works or his/her designee in carrying out the duties and responsibilities of his or her office. Routine and/or emergency activities of the department of public works, which may be required to ensure the public safety, shall be exempt from the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-33. - Interference with the tree warden. 
    No person shall hinder, prevent, delay, or interfere with the tree warden or any of his or her assistants while they are engaged in carrying out the implementation of this article; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed as an intent to prohibit the pursuit of any remedy, legal or equitable, in any court of competent jurisdiction, or the protection of property rights by the owner of any property within town. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-34. - Effective date. 
    This article and any amendment thereto shall be declared to be of immediate necessity for the preservation of public peace, health and safety and shall be in full force and effective from and after its passage and publication as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-35. - Severability. 
    If any one or more sections of this ordinance shall for any reason be adjudged unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, the judgment shall not effect, impair, or invalidate the remaining provisions. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Sec. 25-36. - Relationship to other ordinances. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to restrict, amend, repeal, or otherwise limit the application or enforcement of the zoning ordinance or the subdivision and land development regulations of the town. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 3-28-01) 
Chapter 26 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the town saved from repeal, § 1-10(8); any subdivision ordinance saved from repeal, § 1-10(12); buildings and building regulations, ch. 9; historic preservation, ch. 14; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 25; zoning, ch. 28; environment, ch. 10. 
State Law reference- Land Development and Subdivision Review Enabling Act of 1992, G.L. 1956, § 45-23-1 et seq. 

Sec. 26-1. - Adoption of rules and regulations by planning board. 
    The town planning board is hereby authorized and empowered to adopt, modify and amend rules and regulations governing and restricting the platting or other subdivisions or development of land within the town, and to control such subdivisions according to such rules and regulations. Such rules and regulations shall not be adopted, modified or amended until after a public hearing thereon shall have been held as specified in G.L. 1956, § 45-23-4. These rules and regulations and any modifications or amendments thereto shall be published and copies thereof, when adopted, shall be filed with the town clerk and shall be available for public inspection. 
(Code 1972, § 21-1) 
Sec. 26-2. - Approval of subdivision plats by planning board required. 
    When the planning board shall have adopted rules and regulations pursuant to this chapter, any person who shall thereafter subdivide any land in the town shall make a plat thereof, to which shall be attached the tax collector's certificate that all taxes due on the land described in such plat have been paid for a period of five years preceding the date of filing and that there are no outstanding tax liens thereon, and submit the plat to the planning board, which shall approve, modify and approve or disapprove such plat within 45 days after the submission thereof in final form; otherwise, such plat shall be deemed to be approved and a certificate to that effect shall be issued by the planning board on demand. Such plat, when endorsed as approved by the planning board, shall be recorded in the land records of the town, and shall be assigned a number by the town clerk, beginning with the number 400; and any number or combination of number and letter heretofore assigned by the town clerk to a plat recorded before December 12, 1949, is hereby approved and confirmed as the true and legal number of such plat. 
(Code 1972, § 21-2) 
Sec. 26-3. - Relocation, improvement, etc., of rights-of-way. 
    Existing unimproved rights-of-way, public or private, shall not be relocated, rough graded or otherwise improved, unless a plan thereof, reviewed by the planning board and bearing its endorsed final acceptance, shall have been recorded with the highway plats in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1972, § 21-3) 
Sec. 26-4. - Construction of streets, utility services and other public improvements. 
    Streets, sewers, water mains, utility services or other public improvements constructed shall be in accordance with the rules, regulations and requirements of the planning board. No such construction within any subdivision shall be undertaken until a plat thereof shall have been finally accepted by the planning board. 
(Code 1972, § 21-4) 
Sec. 26-5. - Compliance with subdivision requirements prerequisite to issuance of building permits. 
    Building permits duly complying with the requirements of the building and zoning regulations of the town, if requested in areas subdivided after December 12, 1949, shall be issued only for locations fronting on streets or ways shown on officially approved subdivision plats, endorsed with the final acceptance of the planning board and duly recorded in the town clerk's office. 
(Code 1972, § 21-5) 
Sec. 26-6. - Platting board of review. 
(a)  A platting board of review is hereby created, which shall consist of five members, each to hold office for the term of five years. Appointments shall be by the town council and each appointee shall hold office until his successor is chosen and qualifies. In case any vacancy shall occur in such board from any cause, the appointment to fill such vacancy shall be for the unexpired term. 
(b)  The platting board of review shall have the same type of powers and duties with respect to hearings, witnesses and records as the zoning board of review. The platting board of review may, in appropriate cases and subject to appropriate conditions and safeguards, make special exceptions to the rules and regulations of the planning board, in harmony with the general purpose and intent of such rules and regulations or where such exception is reasonably necessary for the convenience and welfare of the public. Appeals to the platting board of review from the rejection of any plat by the planning board may be taken, in accordance with and under the conditions set forth in G.L. 1956, §§ 45-23-15 to 45-23-18. The board of review shall also have the powers specified in such sections and shall exercise the same in accordance with its provisions. The concurring vote of four members of the board of review shall be necessary to reverse any decision or determination of the planning board. 
(Code 1972, § 21-6) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees, § 2-91 et seq. 
Sec. 26-7. - Judicial review of determinations. 
    Any person, whether or not previously a party to the proceedings, aggrieved by a decision of the platting board of review, a decision of the planning board from which no appeal lies to the board of review, or by the failure of the planning board to take final action with respect to any plat within the required time, may appeal to the superior court for the counties of Providence and Bristol in the manner and subject to the conditions set forth in G.L. 1956, § 45-23-20. 
(Code 1972, § 21-7) 
Sec. 26-8. - Publication of board and committee rules. 
    All rules and regulations promulgated by any board or committee of the town shall be forwarded to the town council for filing, and published under this chapter of the Code. 
(Code 1972, § 21-8) 
Sec. 26-9. - Utility connections at lot boundaries. 
(a)  In addition to road requirements as established by the planning board and its rules and regulations, it shall be a requirement on all new plats wherein roads are to be built, that at the time the finished road surface is installed, all service and utility connections, such as, but not limited to, water, sewer, telephone, electric, drainage, fire hydrants and street lights, shall be made available at the lot boundary line, so that effective connection may be made without disturbing the finished road surface. All such utilities shall be underground whenever possible. 
(b)  No building permits shall be issued on plats approved after the effective date of this section unless the above provisions have been made. 
(c)  There shall be no transfer or sale of lots on plats approved after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives unless the above provisions have been made. 
(d)  Any violation of this section shall be fined $100.00 per occurrence and each day shall constitute a new occurrence. 
(Code 1972, § 21-9) 
Chapter 27 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Town council's authority re taxation, § 207(b). 
Cross reference- Any appropriation ordinance or any ordinance levying or imposing taxes saved from repeal, § 1-10(6); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-10(7); any ordinance creating special districts or assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-10(13); any ordinance granting specific tax exemption saved from repeal, § 1-10(14); administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-176 et seq.; fees and charges, ch. 11. 
State Law reference- Taxation, G.L. 1956, title 44. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 27-1. - Veteran's exemptions. 
(a)  Entitlements and amounts. For the purposes of this subsection, see section 27-9. 
(b)  Qualifications. For the purposes of this subsection, see G.L. 1956 §§ 44-3-4, 44-3-4.2, and 44-3-5, as amended. 
(Code 1972, § 21.1-1; Ord. No. 2006-09, 3-29-06) 
Sec. 27-2. - Freeze on real property taxes for certain persons. 
(a)  There is hereby established a freeze on the rate and valuation of taxes on the principal residence located in the town to any person who is 65 years or older, or if not 65 years or older, that taxpayer's spouse who is domiciled with him, shall be 65 years or older; who is 50 years or older and who is the widow/widower of a taxpayer who, prior to death, had qualified for, and was entitled to relief hereunder, and who was domiciled with such decedent taxpayer on the date of death. Such taxpayer shall reside in the town for one year prior to filing the claim for relief. 
(b)  To qualify for relief, the taxpayer shall have total household adjusted gross income, as such term is defined for federal income tax purposes, for the preceding calendar year of less than $10,000.00. 
(c)  The tax shall be calculated by fixing the tax at the tax rate as levied on such real property during the year in which the taxpayer became age 64. The rate shall remain regardless of the taxpayer's age, date of application or date of qualification. 
(d)  The taxpayer shall apply annually for tax relief on a form prepared by the tax assessor. The application shall be filed between January 1 and May 15 for any year in which the benefits are claimed. The taxpayer shall file any supplemental information necessary to satisfy the claim. Upon approval, the tax relief shall take effect in the next forthcoming roll. 
(e)  The owner of such property or a tenant for life or for a term of years who meets the qualifications heretofore enumerated shall be entitled to pay the tax levied on such property for the first year in which the claim for tax levied on such property for the first year in which the claim for tax relief is filed and approved. For each subsequent year the taxpayer shall meet the qualifications hereafter enumerated, the taxpayer shall be entitled to continue to pay such tax or such lesser amount as is levied. No further applications will be accepted subsequent to March 15, 1994. 
(Code 1972, § 21.1-2) 
Sec. 27-2.1. - Deferral of taxes. 
    Upon proper application therefore and subject to conditions hereinafter set forth, payment of a portion of the taxes on a qualified property as defined herein, owned and occupied by a qualified resident of the Town of Bristol age 65 or older, is deferred until the property is disposed of by reasons of death of the qualified owner-occupant or by the reason of transfer or conveyance as hereinafter set forth. The portion of taxes deferred under this section is the amount of any taxes due in the year for which the deferral is claimed which exceeds the taxes due and payable in the base year, provided however that for applications filed in 2004 and 2005 for persons otherwise qualified in 2004, the base year shall be the year based upon the assessment of December 31, 2002. 
(Ord. No. 2004-29, 8-25-04) 
Sec. 27-2.2. - Application. 
    An application for tax deferral shall be presented to the tax assessor on or before the last day upon which sworn accounts of their ratable estate are required to be filed pursuant to Chapter 5 of Title 44 of the Rhode Island General Laws for each year for which such deferral is claimed, provided however that in the initial year of this program a timely application may be filed by October 1, 2004. Such application shall be on a form provided by the tax assessor and shall be accompanied by such other forms of evidence as the tax assessor may reasonably require to establish eligibility for the deferral program. All applications must be signed by all persons or entities having a present legal or equitable ownership interest in the property. 
(Ord. No. 2004-29, 8-25-04) 
Sec. 27-2.3. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply: 
    Base year. The year before the year for which the application for deferral of taxes is first claimed. 
    Household income. Total income from whatever source derived, including but not limited to realized capital gains, pension, annuity, retirement and social security benefits received by all persons living in the dwelling except the live-in caretaker or care-giver, who has another primary residence. Household income shall be determined on the basis of the calendar year ending with the date of assessment for the tax year for which the deferral is claimed. 
    Resident. A person legally domiciled within the town for a period of at least 20 years ending with the date of assessment for the year for which the deferral is claimed and who continues to be legally domiciled in the town during the period for which the deferral is claimed. Residency must be for at least nine months per annum. Mere seasonal or temporary residence in town, of whatever duration, shall not constitute domicile for the purposes of this section. Absence from the town for 12 months shall be prima facie evidence of termination or abandonment of domicile. The burden of establishing domicile in the town shall be on the applicant. 
    Qualified property. An owner occupied, single-family residence, with no accessory family dwelling unit or commercial component or use. 
    Qualified resident. A resident of the Town of Bristol who: 
(1)  Is 65 years of age or older as of the assessment date for the year for which the deferral is claimed; 
(2)  Is one of the lawful owners of the property for which the deferral is claimed and has continuously been a lawful owner of that property for a period not less than 20 years ending on the date of assessment for the year for which the deferral is claimed; 
(3)  Occupies the subject property at his or her principal residence; 
(4)  Who has a household income of not less than $10,000.00 but not more than $50,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2004-29, 8-25-04) 
Sec. 27-2.4. - Payment. 
    The amount of any taxes deferred pursuant hereto shall be a lien on the property from the date of assessment and shall be payable upon the occurrence of any one of the following: 
(1)  Within six months of the death of the qualified resident, (subject to exception set forth in section 27-2.6). 
(2)  Transfer or conveyance of the property to any one other than a person who was a qualified resident and joint applicant at the time the deferral was first claimed. 
(3)  Written request of the applicant to be removed from the program. 
(Ord. No. 2004-29, 8-25-04) 
Sec. 27-2.5. - Title. 
    If title to the property is held by two or more persons, the terms " qualified resident ", " owner-occupant " and "applicant" shall refer to all such persons. Each such person must meet the eligibility requirements provided in this section, except in the following cases: 
(1)  In the case or property held jointly by husband and wife, the property, if otherwise eligible for deferral shall not be disallowed upon the grounds that one spouse is not 65 years or older or has not resided in Bristol for the required 20 years. 
(2)  A deferral under this section shall not be disallowed if the owner-occupant has only a life estate in the property or if the property is in the name of a parent or one or more children or a living trust for the benefit of the otherwise qualified resident and the owners submit an affidavit that the qualified resident is principal owner or present beneficiary and title is held in that manner for estate planning purposes only. 
(Ord. No. 2004-29, 8-25-04) 
Sec. 27-2.6. - Transfer to widow/widower. 
(a)  In the event that the death of a qualified resident results in title being vested in a surviving widow or widower and at the time of said death the widow or widower is a qualified resident, said death shall result in only the following portion of the deferred taxes becoming due and payable: 
(1)  Those taxes which would otherwise have been due and payable in the years prior to the lawful marriage of the qualified resident and the surviving widow/widower. 
(b)  The remainder of the deferred taxes become due and payable; 
(1)  Within six months of the death of the widow/widower. 
(2)  Transfer or conveyance of the property to anyone other than a person who was a qualified resident and joint applicant at the time the deferral was first claimed. 
(3)  Written request of the applicant to be removed from the program. 
(Ord. No. 2004-29, 8-25-04) 
Sec. 27-2.7. - Other exemptions. 
    Any applicant qualifying for tax deferral pursuant to this section shall remain eligible for any and all tax exemptions allowed by the town for which they are eligible and have qualified at the time of enrollment in the tax deferment program established hereby. Provided however that such exemptions shall not be increased by any automatic annual increase set forth in any local laws or ordinances during the period in which taxes are deferred. 
(Ord. No. 2004-29, 8-25-04) 
Sec. 27-2.8. - Regulations. 
    Subject to the approval of the town administrator and the town council the tax assessor shall formulate and adopt regulations for the administration of this program which shall not be inconsistent with the provisions hereof and which may govern requirements of the program including, but not limited to: form and recordation of lien, manner of establishment of title, form of application and requisite supporting documents. 
(Ord. No. 2004-29, 8-25-04) 
Sec. 27-3. - Disabled persons' qualifications and exemptions. 
(a)  A disabled person's exemptions shall be in accordance with section 27-9. 
(b)  A disabled persons' qualifications shall be in accordance with G.L. 1956, § 44-3-15.2. 
Sec. 27-4. - Exemptions for motor vehicles with wheelchair lifts. 
(a)  Any resident of the town shall be exempt in the amount prescribed by section 27-9 on any one motor vehicle that has been specially adapted with a wheelchair lift for use by an individual with a disability that requires a wheelchair lift. This exemption shall apply to not more than one motor vehicle owned and registered for noncommercial use by a resident of the town. 
(b)  Any person claiming an exemption under this section shall have presented to the assessor, on or before the last day on which sworn statements may be filed with the assessor for the year for which the exemption is claimed, evidence that he is so entitled to the exemption. 
(Code 1972, § 21.1-4) 
Sec. 27-5. - Tax stabilization incentive for industrial, commercial, and manufacturing facilities. 
(a)  Purpose. For the purpose of encouraging economic growth in the Town of Bristol, the town council adopts the following tax stabilization ordinance for new and improved commercial and manufacturing developments. 
    The phase-in of taxes will provide a benefit to the town by reason of the willingness of the commercial or manufacturing business to: 
(1)  Locate in town; or 
(2)  Expand facilities with an increase in employment; or 
(3)  Retain or expand facilities and not reduce the workforce; or 
(4)  Improve facilities that will result in long-term economic benefits to the town. 
(b)  Tax schedule. 
(1)  The town council in its sole discretion is authorized but not required to phase-in, over a period of up to five years, but not more than ten years, the taxes due upon certain commercial and industrial properties in accordance with following schedules. 
a.  Five-year program. Tax stabilization phase-in as follows: 
Five-Year 
Program Percent Exempt 
from 
Taxation Year 1 100 Year 2 90 Year 3 80 Year 4 70 Year 5 60  
b.  Ten-year program. Tax stabilization phase-in as follows: 
Ten-Year 
Program Percent Exempt 
from 
Taxation Year 1 90 Year 2 80 Year 3 70 Year 4 60 Year 5 50 Year 6 40 Year 7 30 Year 8 20 Year 9 10 Year 10 0  
(2)  The first year of exemption shall begin on December 31 of the year following the post construction review and issuance of a certificate of occupancy. 
(c)  General rules and standards. 
(1)  Existing buildings and/or structures and land shall be taxed at 100 percent of its assessed value. The incentive authorized by this section shall be available only to new buildings and structures or new additions to existing buildings or structures, with a cost of $250,000.00 or greater; and, substantial improvements/rehabilitations costing more than 50 percent of the assessed value of the existing building or structure. Those new buildings, structures, and additions costing $250,000.00 to $499,999.00 may be considered for a five-year incentive program and those costing $500,000.00 or greater may be considered for either a five-year or a ten-year incentive program. 
(2)  The tax stabilization phase-in shall be for business, commercial, and industrial; and, shall not be for residential uses. 
(3)  In the case of commercial or industrial condominiums, the phase-in of taxes shall occur in the following manner: 
a.  Phase-in for the value of the building that will contain condominium units accrues to the owner of the building at the time of its final inspection; 
b.  Phase-in for the value of each condominium unit to the owner of the condominium unit upon receipt of the certificate of occupancy. 
In the case of multiple buildings on one parcel, the incentive will be considered for each building as they are applied for. 
(4)  To continue to be eligible for the phase-in, the buildings or structures shall be occupied pursuant to a duly issued certificate of occupancy. 
(5)  The property owner must be current on the property taxes for the subject property to be eligible to make an application. 
(d)  Additional conditions of participation. 
(1)  Tax stabilization for eligible properties shall run with the land and be transferable to new owners, providing that the taxes due are not delinquent. All transfers of continuing participation must register with and be approved by the tax assessor. Any tax stabilized property which is transferred shall not be retroactive. 
(2)  If a property owner whose tax has been stabilized pursuant to this section becomes delinquent in payment of taxes the town council shall have the authority to review and terminate the tax stabilization agreement. 
(3)  The town council shall have the authority to revoke an exemption granted hereunder prior to the expiration thereof in the event of fraud or misrepresentation by an applicant regarding any statements or representations contained in the application or the materials provided therewith. 
(e)  Procedure. 
(1)  An application for tax stabilization shall be submitted to the department of community development prior to the building permit being issued. 
(2)  The application shall be forwarded to the building official and the tax assessor and the tax assessor will conduct a pre-construction review of the property in order to determine the assessed valuation of the property prior to the improvements. 
(3)  The application will be forwarded to the town clerk for the town council's consideration. 
(4)  Upon completion of the improvements, final inspection and issuance of the certificate of occupancy from the building official, the tax assessor will conduct a post-construction review to determine the taxable assessed value added to the property. The tax assessor will then notify the applicant of the added value and the schedule of phased-in taxable value as determined by the town council. 
(Code 1972, § 21.1-5; Ord. No. 1996-18, § 21.1.5, 8-28-96; Ord. No. 2006-32, 10-25-06; Ord. No. 2012-07, 11-14-12; Ord. No. 2013-01, 1-23-13; Ord. No. 2015-10, 7-8-15) 
Sec. 27-6. - Wholesalers' inventory exemption. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Inventory or stock in trade means the merchandise kept on hand for sale under normal or regular course of wholesale business. 
    Wholesaler means and includes a person, partnership, corporation or other business entity engaged in the business of selling goods for subsequent resale by its customers. Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no distinction shall be drawn between: 
(1)  A wholesaler all or a portion of the sales of which are sales to one or more customers affiliated with the wholesaler; and 
(2)  A wholesaler the sales of which are exclusively sales to customers not affiliated with the wholesaler. A wholesaler shall be considered affiliated with customers if its control is controlled by or is under common control with the customers. 
(b)  Calculation of wholesale and retail sales percentages. If a wholesaler sold inventory or stock in trade both at wholesale and at retail in the preceding calendar year, the tax assessor shall assess on the same basis as a retailer's inventory or stock in trade as of December 31 of that year, to the extent permitted by applicable law, notwithstanding any freeze or assessed valuation or exemption permitted under this section, that portion of inventory or stock in trade of the wholesaler which shall be equal to the percentage of the wholesaler's total sales during the preceding calendar year that were at retail. For the purposes of this section, sales at retail shall not include sales to employees of the wholesaler or to the employees of its affiliates. If retail sales are less than one percent of total sales during the calendar year, it shall be deemed that no sales were made at retail during the year. All sales of the wholesaler to a customer which is an affiliated entity shall be deemed to be retail sales for purposes of this section if more than half of the dollar volume of the sales of the affiliated entity are made within the town. 
(c)  Duration of exemption. For 25 years after this section is passed and approved, the tax assessor shall exempt a wholesaler's inventory from taxes where the wholesaler requests the exemption from the tax assessor and complies with verification procedures as established by the tax assessor. 
(Code 1972, § 21.1-6) 
Sec. 27-7. - Exemption of persons over the age of 65 years. 
(a)  Entitlements and amounts. For the purposes of this subsection, see section 27-9. 
(b)  Qualifications. For the purposes of this subsection, see G.L. 1956, § 44-3-13(i). 
(Code 1972, § 21.1-7) 
Sec. 27-8. - Exemption of persons who are visually impaired. 
(a)  Entitlements and amounts. For the purpose of this subsection, see section 27-9. 
(b)  Qualifications. For the purposes of this subsection, see G.L. 1956, § 44-3-12. 
(Code 1972, § 21.1-8) 
Sec. 27-9. - Entitlements and amounts. 
(a)  Exempted valuations. Pursuant to this chapter, the following valuations are hereby exempted for those residents who are qualified: 
Elderly 65-69 ..... $12,500.00 
Elderly 70-74 ..... 15,000.00 
Elderly 75 and older ..... 17,500.00 
Veteran ..... 12,500.00 
Widow of veteran ..... 12,500.00 
Prisoner of war ..... 24,225.00 
Widow of prisoner of war ..... 24,225.00 
Gold star parent ..... 11,350.00 
100 percent military disabled ..... 16,175.00 
Widow of 100 percent military disabled ..... 16,175.00 
Partial military disabled ..... 3,300.00 
Widow of partial military disabled ..... 3,300.00 
Specially adopted housing ..... 15,700.00 
Widow of specially adopted housing ..... 15,700.00 
100 percent disabled ..... 8,075.00 
Visually impaired ..... 9,700.00 
Wheelchair lift ..... 4,850.00 
(b)  Maximum amount. Pursuant to G.L. 1956, § 44-3-25.1, the maximum exemption from taxation for residents of the town under any provisions of this chapter, or G.L. 1956, § 44-3-1 et seq. shall not exceed the sum of $50,000.00 of valuation in a given calendar year. 
(c)  Income cap for 100 percent disabled exemption . To qualify for the 100 percent exemption, a totally disabled person must have a gross income less than $20,000.00 per year. 
(d)  Hardship exemption. Pursuant to G.L. 1956 § 44-3-3, the tax assessor has the discretion to grant an exemption from property tax for any single family residence owned by an individual or family that has a gross income of less than $12,000 per year. 
(e)  Termination. All exemptions shall terminate upon either the conveyance of the subject property, by death of the person exempted, if applicable, or by such person moving from the town. 
(f)  Exemption tax rate. Pursuant to RIGL 1956, § 44-3-27.1, each exemption granted on property by any of the provisions of this section is at the current tax rate or a rate equivalent to $20.00 per $1,000.00 of valuation, whichever is greater. 
(Code 1972, § 21.1-10; Ord. No. 1999-05, 3-10-99; Ord. No. 2004-18, 6-23-04; Ord. No. 2005-49, 7-20-05; Ord. No. 2015-19, 10-21-15) 
Sec. 27-10. - Deferment of partial payment of tax for the low-income. 
(a)  Pursuant to G.L. 1956, § 44-3-20.2, the town shall provide that the payment of property taxes on a single family dwelling, owned and occupied by the applicant, who shall meet certain income guidelines, shall be partially deferred until the property is disposed by reason of transfer or conveyance of any of the applicant's interest or by reason of death of the applicant; provided, however, any taxes so deferred shall constitute a lien on the real estate similar to G.L. 1956, § 44-9-1 et seq. 
(b)  The income guidelines shall pertain to income of every nature and description and shall be deemed to include the aggregate gross income of the applicant and all other persons over the age of 21 years residing with the applicant. The aggregate gross income shall be less than $18,000.00 per year. It is further provided that the deferral shall not be allowed unless the applicant shall have presented to the assessor, on or before the last day on which sworn statements may be filed with the assessor for the year for which the foregoing is claimed, due evidence that he or she is entitled, which evidence must be resubmitted annually for each year which the applicant desires the deferral to continue. 
(c)  The amount deferred shall not exceed $25,000.00 of valuation and the deferral shall be in addition to any and all other exemptions which the applicant may be entitled to, except as provided in G.L. 1956, § 44-3-16. A duly recorded lien shall be filed with the recorder of deeds for each year the deferral continues. The recorded lien shall not accrue interest. 
(Ord. No. 1996-16, § 21.1-7, 9-5-96) 
Sec. 27-11. - Retail inventory tax phase out. 
(a)  Pursuant to G.L. 1956, § 44-3-29.1, the town shall provide for the phase out of the stock in trade or inventory of retailers. 
(b)  Notwithstanding G.L. 1956, § 44-3-29.1(d), the rate schedule for the eight-year phaseout of the personal property tax levied on retail inventory shall be as follows: 
Based upon 
December 31st of Tax Rate 1998 $15.70 1999 $13.95 2000 $12.20 2001 $10.45 2002 $ 8.70 2003 $ 6.95 2004 $ 5.20 2005 $ 3.45 2006 and thereafter No tax authorized  
(Ord. No. 1999-15, 6-23-99; Ord. No. 2000-11, 5-10-00) 
Sec. 27-12. - Volunteer firefighter/EMS tax incentive program. 
(a)  Purpose. The town recognizes that volunteering to be a fire fighter is one of the most demanding volunteer activities an individual can undertake due to significant fire service training requirements and time taken away from family, work, and other volunteer activities. The town desires to retain its cadre of volunteer fire fighters to provide the services necessary for the public health and safety of the town as well as to recruit new volunteers. Therefore, the town ordains tax incentives to volunteer fire fighters as set forth herein. 
(b)  Tax abatement. The town may grant a tax abatement to members of the Bristol Volunteer Fire Department ("fire department"). Said qualifications shall be reviewed and approved by the town council annually commencing in 2018. 
(c)  Available amount of relief. The town council may reduce the real property tax obligation or motor vehicle and trailer excise tax obligation of volunteer firefighters and emergency medical services personnel up to $2,500.00 for any fiscal year. The fire chief shall prepare a sliding scale of abatements for town council approval based on the qualifications of the applicant. 
(d)  Eligible volunteer. The tax abatement may be made available to volunteers on a sliding scale provided the following minimum eligibility requirements are met as determined by the fire chief: 
(1)  Completion of recruit school and participation as an active firefighter; 
(2)  Training to the hazardous materials operation level; 
(3)  Attendance at a minimum number of drills per year; 
(4)  Attendance at a minimum number of emergency responses per year; 
(5)  Maintaining a minimum medical training level of CPR and first aid; 
(6)  If a line officer, presence at a minimum number of department drills; 
(e)  Additional incentives. The amount of the abatement may be increased (up to the amount provided for in subsection (c) hereof) for individuals who earn the following achievements: 
(1)  Firefighter I/II certification; 
(2)  Fire officer certification; 
(3)  Fire instructor certification; 
(4)  Length of service milestones; 
(5)  Rank achievements; 
(6)  Accredited EMS or Fire certifications. 
(f)  Requirements of service. Individuals shall be entitled to a tax abatement only if he or she shall have been certified by the fire department to be eligible in accordance with established policies, rules, and regulations for the year for which the abatement is claimed, together with due evidence that he or she is entitled to such abatement. 
(g)  Eligible property. Eligible property shall not include property for which taxes are delinquent. To be eligible, a property must: 
(1)  Be any real or personal property for which the eligible volunteer holds title; or 
(2)  Be any real property for which a person or legal entity other than the eligible volunteer holds title, provided that such real property shall be the eligible volunteer's principal residence, and provided that such eligible volunteer shall provide documentation to prove to the satisfaction of the assessor that the eligible volunteer currently pays or is legally obligated to pay town property taxes on such real property; or 
(3)  Be any personal property for which the title is held by a person or legal entity other than the eligible volunteer, provided that such eligible volunteer shall provide documentation to prove to the satisfaction of the assessor that the eligible volunteer currently pays or is legally obligated to pay town property taxes on such personal property. 
(4)  In the event that a person applying as active status does not own property within the town, a cash equivalent as approved by the town council may be paid up to the minimum amount eligible to be earned. 
(h)  Reporting period. The calendar year 2018 shall be deemed the initial reporting. On or before January 31st of each year commencing with 2019, the fire chief shall provide to the town council an accounting of all eligible participants as well as a census of current and new volunteers during the reporting period. 
(i)  Application of abatement. The tax abatement earned for any given year shall be credited as a reduction in the tax obligation of the following fiscal year. 
(j)  Application. Any eligible volunteer, or his or her authorized agent, shall file an annual application for tax relief under this article with the town assessor prior to March 15th on a form or forms prescribed and furnished by the town. The applicant or his or her authorized agent shall sign a sworn affidavit affirming the accuracy of the statements in the application. When the town assessor is satisfied that the applicant qualifies under this article, the assessor shall compute the amount of such tax relief and provide a full report to the town council before April 10th, and cause certificates of tax abatement to be issued in such form as to permit the tax collector to reduce the amount of tax levied against the eligible volunteer and make proper record thereof, and a copy thereof shall be delivered to the applicant. The tax abatement shall be applied proportionately to the tax payments. 
(k)  Review of application. The assessor may, at any time, inquire into the right of the applicant to an abatement or any continuation of the abatement and, for that purpose, may require the filing of a new application or submission of such proof as he or she shall deem necessary to determine the right of the applicant to an abatement in the original instance or any continuance of the abatement. 
(l)  Characterization of abatement. The amount by which a person's tax liability is reduced shall not be considered income, wages, or employment for the purposes of taxation. 
(m)  Expiration date. This section and all of its benefits shall expire July 1, 2019 unless re-enacted by the town council prior thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2018-01 , 1-31-18) 
Secs. 27-13-27-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAX EXEMPTION FOR SOLAR ENERGY SYSTEMS 

Sec. 27-26. - Findings. 
    Pursuant to RIGL § 44-3-21, as amended, solar energy systems may be exempt from taxation. The town council finds as follows: 
(1)  That it would be in the public interest to exempt from taxation certain solar energy systems as provided for in section 27-28; 
(2)  Tax exemptions should be reserved for solar energy systems designed primarily to generate approximately the same amount of energy consumed on the subject property; 
(3)  Tax exemptions should not be available to individuals or entities using solar energy systems primarily to produce energy for sale unless the energy generated and sold is in an amount substantially offset by energy purchased for use on the subject property. 
(Ord. No. 2016-05, 4-13-16) 
Sec. 27-27. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Average consumption shall mean 125 percent of the average electric consumption on the property for the qualifying period or 125 percent of the estimated electrical consumption on the property certified by affidavit from a licensed professional engineer.
